headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Twenty-First Century Fox Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conf
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Twenty-First Century Fox Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello everyone, and welcome to our Second Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; James Murdoch, Co-chief Operating Officer; John Nallen, our Ch
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello everyone, and welcome to our Second Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; James Murdoch, Co-chief Operating Officer; John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer. First, we'll give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, then we'd be happy to take questions from the investment community.
This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to Twenty-First Century Fox's business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended December 31, 2014, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ, and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filings.
Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and the reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing. 
Finally, please note that certain financial measures used in this call, such as segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share, are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release.
And with that, I'm pleased to turn it over to John.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Reed. As you have seen in today's earnings release, we reported another good quarter of financial results led by double-digit revenue and EBITDA growth at our Cable Networks. Note that due to the sale in November of our DBS businesses t
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Reed. As you have seen in today's earnings release, we reported another good quarter of financial results led by double-digit revenue and EBITDA growth at our Cable Networks. Note that due to the sale in November of our DBS businesses to Sky, our reported financial results include the consolidation of these businesses this year for our partial quarter of ownership as compared to a full quarter consolidation the year ago. So to provide a more meaningful comparative analysis, we are providing total company adjusted revenue and adjusted EBITDA that excludes the DBS businesses in all periods. Most of the comments that follow will be on this adjusted basis, and there are press release provides the reconciliations between the reported results and this adjusted basis.
So second quarter adjusted total company revenues were $7.4 billion, up 10% compared to the second quarter a year ago, reflecting double-digit increases in our Cable Network and Film segments. 
Adjusted total segment EBITDA for the second quarter was $1.7 billion, up 12% over the $1.51 billion from the year ago. This increase reflects strong results of the Cable Network segment, improvements led by costs at the Television segment and similar film contributions to a year ago. Note that unfavorable foreign currency movements reduced our overall total EBITDA growth rate in the quarter by 6 percentage points.
From a bottom-line perspective, we reported income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $6.2 billion as compared to the $982 million we reported in the second quarter a year ago. This year's results include $5 billion of gains reported in Other net, which was principally from the company's sale of the DBS businesses to Sky. Also included in this year's equity earnings of affiliate results is net after-tax income of approximately $100 million related to Sky's gains on the sales of certain of its investments, partially offset by their purchase price amortization and expenses related to their acquisition of Sky Italia and Sky Deutschland.
Excluding net income effect of these net equity gains and last year's gain for participating in Sky share repurchase program as well as the amounts reflected in Other net, second quarter adjusted earnings per share was $0.53 this year versus $0.33 in the prior year. This quarter's adjusted earnings per share includes the recognition of various tax benefits of approximately $250 million or $0.12 per share. For the remainder of the fiscal year, we expect our tax rate to approximate 31%. Also note that the net income and EPS contributions of the DBS segment in each year were not significant.
Now let me provide some additional context at the performance -- on the performance of a few of our businesses, and let's start with the Cable Network segment, where overall total segment revenues increased 14% from last year, highlighted by a 16% increase in affiliate revenues and 8% advertising revenue growth.
With respect to affiliate revenues, domestic affiliate fees increased 19%, primarily from higher average rates led by the RSNs, FX and FOX News, as well as increases from the conversion of our new channels, FS1 and FXX. The inclusion of the YES Network this year also contributed to our growth, and excluding the contribution from YES, we had a low double-digit domestic affiliate fee increase. Our reported international affiliate fees were up 7%, reflecting strong underlying local currency growth of about 20%.
The second quarter Cable segment advertising revenue growth of 8% reflects domestic advertising increases of 11%, led by the FX Network's, FS1 and FXX. Reported international advertising grew 5%, but we had 10% growth on a local currency basis driven by strong year-over-year increases at STAR.
Total cable segment EBITDA in the second quarter of $1.16 billion was up 12% over the prior year, reflecting the strong revenue growth, which was partially offset by a planned 16% increase in expenses, primarily related to higher sports rights and entertainment programming costs. The negative impact from the strengthening U.S. dollar impacted the segment growth rate by 6%.
EBITDA at our domestic channels increased 13% from higher contributions at our established networks, as well as the impact of consolidating the YES Network this year.
EBITDA at Fox Sports 1 was below last year, reflecting the planned increased programming costs associated with the inaugural broadcast of the major league baseball playoffs.
Reported international channel EBITDA contributions increased 8% as strong double-digit local currency growth at both FIC and the STAR entertainment channels was partially offset by the continued investment we're making in STAR Sports and the negative impact from foreign exchange rates.
At our Television segment, second quarter EBITDA was $290 million, an increase of $72 million as compared to the prior-year result. This higher contribution is primarily due to lower programming costs reflecting the absence of X Factor this year, the movement of Glee into the March quarter and the shift of the baseball league championship series to Fox Sports 1. Total segment revenues were consistent with the year ago quarter as strong retransmission consent revenue growth was offset by a 3% decline in advertising revenues. This ad revenue decline is primarily due to lower general entertainment ratings at the broadcast network and stations, offset in part by higher local political ad revenues related to the midterm elections.
Turning to our Film segment. We reported second quarter EBITDA of $336 million, a similar result to that of a year ago, as higher film studio contributions were offset by fewer Television series deliveries. Total segment revenues in the quarter increased $276 million or 11%, driven by several successful theatrical releases, including Gone Girl and The Maze Runner. The majority of these higher theatrical revenues were offset by increased releasing cost for both these films as well as Exodus and Night at the Museum 3.
Before I turn to guidance, let me make a couple of capital-related comments. We ended the quarter with $10.1 billion in cash and $19.1 billion in gross debt, and the cash position reflects the net proceeds from the sale of Sky Italia and Sky Deutschland during the quarter.
With regard to the stock buyback, we repurchased approximately $2.9 billion of FOXA shares from July 1 through today, and we're on plan to complete the $6 billion buyback within the 12-month time frame we previously announced.
And today, the company increased its dividend and declared a semiannual dividend of $0.15 per share. This translates to a $0.30 dividend on an annual basis, a 20% increase over the previous dividend payout.
Now let me address our guidance update for fiscal 2015. As a reminder, for guidance purposes, we are excluding the DBS businesses for the entirety of all periods, resulting in a base EBITDA for fiscal 2014 of $6.29 billion.
On last quarter's earnings call, we mentioned that we had seen some puts and takes as against our original expectations for fiscal 2015 with the negative variances at that time primarily relating to the strengthening dollar and underperformance at the broadcast network as against our original expectations. Since that update, these trends have continued and at levels above what we expected.
Over the last 3 months, the U.S. dollar has appreciated significantly, further reducing the translated U.S. dollar earnings from our international businesses, most notably from the FOX International Channels. Assuming exchange rates stay where they are today, the strength in dollar has now further reduced our fiscal 2015 EBITDA expectations by an additional $100 million plus, resulting in a total full year effect across the company of around $250 million versus last year.
At our Television Broadcast business, the network and the stations, we now know that market and rating challenges were more significant than we expected. 
On the entertainment side, Empire and American Idol are doing well competitively, but our ratings overall have underperformed and our expectation that the national and local ad markets would gain momentum going into calendar 2015 has not occurred. 
On the sports side, our biggest college football games in the quarter were all lopsided wins, with an average score of 52 to 10, thereby impacting the viewership.
At our Film segment, we continue to anticipate the full year contributions will exceed our original expectations, but now by a lesser amount than we thought 3 months ago, primarily reflecting lower-than-anticipated box office results from our holiday releases, as well as closing on the transfer of our Shine business to the Endemol joint venture earlier than we expected. This will result in the elimination of Shine's EBITDA contribution for the rest of the year as it moves to our Equity Affiliate line.
Despite our change in expectations around currencies, broadcast TV and our Film segment, our domestic cable network businesses continue to perform right in line with our expectations.
So considering these factors and based on all of the assumptions inherent in our current projections, we now expect that our total segment EBITDA percentage growth rate for fiscal 2015 will be toward the lower end of the mid-single-digit range, above the $6.29 billion total segment EBITDA base level for fiscal 2014.
With that, let me turn it over to Chase.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Let me begin by standing on John's comments [indiscernible] 2015 guidance. The reality is that the majority of our businesses and key initiatives are on track and are in a competitive position is strong than it has ever been in almost every
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Let me begin by standing on John's comments [indiscernible] 2015 guidance. The reality is that the majority of our businesses and key initiatives are on track and are in a competitive position is strong than it has ever been in almost every area. However, a few issues, foreign currency and broadcast advertising shortfalls became too large to offset us. Let me address these issues first and talk about the larger picture.
There isn't a lot to add to what John said about the current our practical hedging strategies help manage the risk. Hedging alone will mitigate further fluctuations, not currency impact to date. The broadcast side, network and station, primarily entertainment rating shortfalls at our network exacerbated by adverse industry trends, the linear network rating and the Television advertising market, which combined leave our expected ad revenues well short of plan.
Looking forward to 2016 
[Technical Difficulty]
I'll start again, so I don't know what -- whether any of that came on. Let me begin by expanding on John's comments on fiscal 2015 guidance. The reality is that the majority of our businesses and key initiatives are on track and our competitive position is as strong as ever in almost every area. However, 2 issues, foreign currency and broadcast advertising shortfalls, simply became too large to offset. Let me address these issues first and talk about the larger picture.
There isn't a lot to add to what John said about the currency issues, we are practical, we are addressing hedging strategies to help manage the risk, but hedging will only mitigate further fluctuations, not the currency impact to date.
On the broadcast side, network and stations, the issue is primarily entertainment rating shortfalls at our network, exacerbated by adverse industry trends and linear network ratings in the Television advertising markets, which, combined, leave our expected ad revenues well short of plan.
Looking forward to 2016, we expect these same themes to continue. The majority of our businesses are strong and on track, however, currency moves this year will adversely impact 2016 profits by about $200 million, which is on top of the approximately $250 million hit to expected 2016 profits from currency shifts last year, a total hit of about $450 million to our original 2016 projection in August 2013.
We also expect the next 12 months to be a period of investment in new programming at our broadcast network. In addition, we anticipate the industry trends backing advertising will be slightly larger than previously expected, as both advertising and viewership continues to migrate to digital platforms.
Our original target for 2016 profits was $9 billion, which adjusted for the deconsolidation of the Sky's and Shine, will be about $8 billion. Clearly, our Broadcast business is not where we expected it to be at this time, and external market forces like currency have been more unfavorable than expected. While we still expect solid double-digit growth overall next year due to the strength of most of our businesses, the challenges in currency and broadcasting now lead us to an expected 2016 profit in the mid-$7 billion range.
We're obviously disappointed to fall short of our targets for this year and next, we take these targets seriously. However, our overall goal is not to get a short-term profit target but to build shareholder value, which will be determined by the overall momentum and competitive strengths of our businesses and how well they're positioned to grow and succeed in light of broader economic technological and global trends. If our goal will to hit the short-term profit target, we'd pursue efforts like cutting marketing and programming cost at the expense of future profits. We'll not do that because we believe shareholder value is built through long-term growth.
In terms of that overall goal, we could not be more excited about the future. First, as noted earlier, most of our businesses and key initiatives are on target and competitively as strong as ever. Affiliate revenues and retransmission fees, which are the foundation for future growth, are on or ahead of our plans. Among key initiatives, we begun to once again reset the FOX News rate to reflect its importance in the market with new agreements now in place with 4 MVPDs represent over 1/4 of the market and Fox Sports 1 now its affiliation agreements in place with all major MVPDs reflect the new FS1 rate.
Our domestic and international cable channels group, which represent about 70% of our profit, are on track on a local currency basis, as with the new channel initiatives launched in the last few years. 
Our new sports and entertainment channels continue to build in their leadership position with truly unique and focused brands around the world. For example, FX has really left competing basic cable networks behind with programming that makes it appear the premium networks, while FXX is at an exciting new dimension to that group as the fastest-growing networking cable.
Our Film and Television businesses had great momentum and continue to distinguish themselves as industry leaders. Our Film business finished calendar 2014 with record-breaking worldwide box office. We've locked up key sports content around the world through the rest of this decade to assure access to this critical content and provide cost stability.
Even in the earlier noted areas where we face challenges, we're excited about the future. At our Broadcast business, our issues have been ones of execution, not structure. The foundation is in place with retransmission revenues ahead of plan with significant room to grow and our major sports rights are in place under long-term contracts.
Our challenges in the networks entertainment programming. After a few tough years, we believe we've turned the corner with a new network management team who inherited our current broadcast issues that has brought fresh momentum and energy to the business. It's always a tough business to predict, but we are excited about new hits like Empire and Gotham, as well as the dynamic slate of new event programming. Our competitors have already shown what a difference a couple of hits can make.
While I think in time to get the Broadcast business to where it should be in terms of profitability. The next year plus will be a period of investment, with the priority focused on building hit shows, not maximizing profit. The profits will follow. We still believe our Broadcast business has a strategic and financial future that is as promising as ever. The time when the value of hit programming continues to grow exponentially, our broadcast network plays a unique role in launching defining events like Empire.
Turning to the broader industry issues. The digital transition continues to be a glass half-full story for us. The movement of advertising dollars and shift our consumer viewing is clearly going to continue as I think it is fair to say that this trend recently has been a bit faster than many expected. These issues will put short-term pressure on our business but represent longer-term exciting growth opportunities that we were able to deliver more efficient and effective capabilities to advertisers, better monetize viewership on digital platforms and create new offers consumers -- for consumers on these platforms. Our content and brands are the ones consumers and advertisers want to access to first and foremost, and we are committed to building the capabilities to meet that demand.
Recent initiatives like the restructuring of our ad sales organization and the acquisition of True X are focused on that goal.
In closing, let me touch on the return on capital and our balance sheet. We are well aware that the recent completion of the Sky transaction once again has our balance sheet at an overly liquid position. We will complete our $6 billion buyback as planned, although that will still leave us with excess liquidity. Between now and fiscal year, our board will continue to consider next steps. Our priorities for capital remain the same: Invest in our core businesses to grow long-term value, opportunistic flexibility and return of capital to shareholders. We continue to pursue our goal of achieving an efficient balance sheet, but we'll do so in a deliberate manner. Quite simply, our goal continues to be building shareholder value by growing our businesses while returning capital to shareholders, and we believe we are on track to achieve that goal. Thank you. I'll turn it back to Reed.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess my question deals with investment in the business and maybe, James, you can talk about STAR in India in particular and help us think about the profit potential of that business. I think a while ago you guys had laid out a plan for EBITDA growth th
componenttext: I guess my question deals with investment in the business and maybe, James, you can talk about STAR in India in particular and help us think about the profit potential of that business. I think a while ago you guys had laid out a plan for EBITDA growth there but the currencies have moved against you. Help us think about the opportunity there particularly in light of some of the non-rupee denominated cost you have on the sports side. And a similar question maybe, Chase, on FOX network. It sounds like you're planning to sort of double down, I don't know if that's the right phrase, but invest more in content entertainment and push the programming. Can you give us some color on sort of how big you want to go and what we should be thinking about in terms of programming cost growth at FOX over the next couple of years?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. James, do you want to. . .
componenttext: Sure. James, do you want to. . .

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben. I think the last time when we talked about sort of the profit to the pathway for the Indian business, actually since then the currency has been reasonably stable over the last sort of 7 or I guess 9 months now. So I don't think that's had an
componenttext: Thanks, Ben. I think the last time when we talked about sort of the profit to the pathway for the Indian business, actually since then the currency has been reasonably stable over the last sort of 7 or I guess 9 months now. So I don't think that's had an additional impact going forward from what we saw then. But essentially, the STAR entertainment business, the local language business and the regional language business there, is a very profitable business today, a very attractive business. And really we're investing a lot of those profits to build the sports business alongside that, which we think really have a transformational effect on the business since the acquisition of the half interest of ESPN STAR Sports that we didn't own previously. And I think what we're seeing now is really the peak year of investment. In fact, these coming quarters, with the Cricket World Cup and a series of events, really making that heavy investment right now. But we see that turning reasonably quickly, and we have pretty good certainty on what those rights costs look like for the STAR Sports business. We're launching 2 new sports channels, 2 HD channels, actually just in the next month, to continue to grow the portfolio. And we think over 5-year basis, this business at STAR India is a very, very profitable business, we think it can get to north of -- I've said in the past, certainly north of $500 million to profit and do it with some pace and some velocity. And I think investing in programming and investing on for our customers is a theme that you'll see everywhere around the business. We really think that's the business that we're in and something that is super important for us, it's going to deliver a lot of long-term growth domestically here as well as around the world.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the FOX, on the Network side, broadcasting, it's not doing a doubling down I think in many ways what I'm trying to communicate is much our priority. I think our priority is really building hits first and foremost and I guess it's why I made the comment
componenttext: On the FOX, on the Network side, broadcasting, it's not doing a doubling down I think in many ways what I'm trying to communicate is much our priority. I think our priority is really building hits first and foremost and I guess it's why I made the comment. If we wanted just improved profits, we'd squeeze programming and squeeze marketing and we don't think it's the right move. So I don't get me in many ways. I think it is making sure we've got a bench of programming as we try and develop these hits. I think this year we felt we were a little thin in terms of having programming available. I think we always know every show is not going to work and we got to make sure we have appropriate flexibility to build. But I think what we're really talking about is stabilizing the Broadcast business and providing a platform to grow. But I think that real growth comes in the next couple of years, not the next 12 months. So I think the next year will be a period of more stabilizing that business and putting it on a path to grow. But I think I'm talking more priorities. And I think to the degree it's pending in reality, some of our more expensive programming, something like Glee is ending its run. So obviously there are some costs that will go away, will not recur, as we invest in new shows. But I think if what the investment is probably having a bit more flexibility and a bit more the bench of programming to launch next year to enable us to have a few more shots at creating the hits that are the foundation for future. Obviously Empire and Gotham give us some exciting building blocks to grow off, but it's not significant increase in cost. Again, I'm probably speaking more to what we think is the priority for the coming year.

componenttext: Let me ask James to, first, I wanted philosophically, what's your view of participating in a product like the DISH offer, which may not carry all of your channels, especially RSNs? And then on the FOX side, given that Gary are there now, how does the FOX studio play in that need to maybe have a more bench strength? Shift in cell phone hours at the network?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess we've take them -- I'll start first. Look, I think these digital platforms are obviously very important part of our future. We're spending a lot of time sort of trying to engage with third parties, doing our own analysis on what makes sense for us
componenttext: I guess we've take them -- I'll start first. Look, I think these digital platforms are obviously very important part of our future. We're spending a lot of time sort of trying to engage with third parties, doing our own analysis on what makes sense for us in terms of developing them. I'm not going to comment on any one particular offer. And we don't -- certainly we don't have announcements today. We are working on a lot of things. I think we'll announce something when essentially we're ready to do it. I expect this to be an area where we are busy and do move forward, but we're not going to sort of make press releases. I think what's most important and I'm not sure offers that sort of resonate with the consumer. I mean I think a lot of what's been out there so far seems to be, whether it's driven by transactions or deals or something or other considerations, I think we want to see can we bring things that are additive to our business, and I think at the start we have to make sure what we do in this space as we do in other places, is that additive to our business, but brings new opportunities and interesting experiences to consumers. And whether that's through a richer experience, a better interface, more choice. Again, I think what we offer consumers today in many ways is a pretty attractive proposition. But clearly there's segments we are not reaching in the right way and there are opportunities for us to expand and grow that pie. And we are going to be active there. But we're going to be thoughtful about it as well and make sure it's done in a way that is additive to our business as a whole is the way that we go forward. And on TCFTV, I think it's an important part, one of the core strategic reasons for putting it together is increasingly I think it's we're not alone in this. A lot of the upside of what a network represents in terms of launching programming is realized on the products, on the content side of it. So the real win-win for us is to launch content that we own. It doesn't mean we're not going to have third-party content on our network, we will, because realistically we want to have the best content possible. It doesn't mean we're not going to sell content to third-party networks, we will do that as well. But clearly, the sweet spot is using our network to be able to create assets that we own. And I think by putting them together under one roof, we think we certainly create, it makes those opportunities more available to us and certainly I think streamline that decision-making, make the ability to identify needs and ensure we're doing everything possible to maximize the opportunities to launch a hit show is done by having that studio and the network together. But it is one of the core benefits that we look to in putting the studio and the network under Gary and Dana's leadership.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015

componenttext: From the line of Doug Mitchelson with UBS.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chase and James, we've a lot of focus in the past to fiscal '16 given the setup from the Analyst Day. I'm wondering, by fiscal '16, how much of the growth cycle is complete for FOX? You already talked about broadcasting star so maybe just thinking about y
componenttext: Chase and James, we've a lot of focus in the past to fiscal '16 given the setup from the Analyst Day. I'm wondering, by fiscal '16, how much of the growth cycle is complete for FOX? You already talked about broadcasting star so maybe just thinking about you mentioned Fox Sports 1 and FOX Sports 2 has all deals done, there's always concerns with the RSNs not being part of the packages, whether traditional or online. And where are we sort of as you look forward beyond fiscal '16, how much of the growth has been captured? How much is left? And then just quickly for John, if you could break down the local currency international affiliate fee revenue growth of 20% for us, what were the drivers, that would be helpful.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we honestly our best growth is ahead of us. I mean, in all -- and that's obviously certainly applies to some of the newer initiatives like FS1 or sports internationally, but I cited I think upfront talked about FOX News, which I think just get str
componenttext: I think we honestly our best growth is ahead of us. I mean, in all -- and that's obviously certainly applies to some of the newer initiatives like FS1 or sports internationally, but I cited I think upfront talked about FOX News, which I think just get stronger and we are once again resetting that business. FOX business, I think, we're just really moving to now to really full competitive distribution. So when I look at our portfolio of channels, both the established ones and the newer ones, I think a lot of growth in international marketplace clearly as you look at it around the world, has got -- is certainly somewhere midstream in terms of reaching any reaching its full potential, varies by region, but there's an enormous amount of growth, we talked before about India, where that is in terms of what we think that business can be as we move through this decade. I think, ultimately, I really mean what I said when I talked about the digital platforms and us taking advantage of those, both directly and through outher parties. I think for those who have -- we really believe must-have content is going to sweet spot in the digital world. People it's the content people want to Rochester refer the RSNs. The reality ends up being sports comes at a cost but are also the product that's most in demand. And I think hit product is going to grow exponentially in value and importance and I think those that have the heavy breadth that hit unique content will be ideally positioned to take advantage of all these platforms and create new offers and new compositions for consumers. And opportunities to engage more directly with consumers in terms of developing those offers, monetizing the viewership, developing databases and the like. So I think in many ways, I think it will a lot of it is short-term pressure because the pressure short-term it will take time to build the vehicles to replace the short-term pressures. But as we go forward, I think it's an area of tremendous growth for us. I mean, I think those with -- and again, get unique content brands at that scale have a really in the sweet spot to take advantage of these things. So I think our core businesses have a lot of growth left here and overseas in their traditional models, not that some of those models are maturing, but our business is clearly, when we look at what we're doing with FOX News, look at where we are with retransmission rates and the potential there, we think the value of our content holds up. Yes, you'll still certainly as we said, I think the cable bundle really is pretty much in line with our expectations. I said before, probably spring. But I think it's got real legs to it and still is going to be a cornerstone for a long time. But as we go forward, these digital platforms really open up a whole new dimension in growth on top of the opportunities we have within the traditional model.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Doug, dealing with your question on the local currency affiliate revenue growth international, it was led by the FIC STAR had growth, nice growth but FIC led it and business break down inside of that, is in our sports channels, it was primarily distri
componenttext: And Doug, dealing with your question on the local currency affiliate revenue growth international, it was led by the FIC STAR had growth, nice growth but FIC led it and business break down inside of that, is in our sports channels, it was primarily distribution gains, whereas in our entertainment channels it was blended between both distribution gains as well as rate increases.

componenttext: Coming from the line of Anthony DiClemente with Nomura.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have one question for James and one for Chase. James, over the past year or so, other media companies have made strategic investments internationally in order to achieve more global scale, perhaps scale that FOX already has. So for example, Channel 5, E
componenttext: I have one question for James and one for Chase. James, over the past year or so, other media companies have made strategic investments internationally in order to achieve more global scale, perhaps scale that FOX already has. So for example, Channel 5, Eurosport and Teller Media. As you look to sustain your growth in markets outside the U.S., can you just give us a sense for how you're balancing organic investment versus M&A? And then for Chase, you noted the strong ad growth domestically from the FX Network's in the quarter. Does seem like ratings at FXX have picked up nicely, but FX ratings themselves have seen to hit a soft spot. So I know you guys have moved some content from FX to FXX, but just wondering is there any concern on those networks? And can they establish their own distinct identities from each other?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony. It's James here. First of all, I would say our bias generally is to and particularly given the position we have in markets outside the U.S. today, is generally to invest in ourselves and to continue to execute and operate these businesses
componenttext: Thanks, Anthony. It's James here. First of all, I would say our bias generally is to and particularly given the position we have in markets outside the U.S. today, is generally to invest in ourselves and to continue to execute and operate these businesses where we have a reasonable position. I think it's fair to say that we're pretty happy with the mix that we have around the place. It's a -- we've completed a number of transactions over the last number of years from the acquisition of the Asianet business and local regional -- local regional languages in India, which really gave us a new dimension to that business, through the acquisition of our partner stakes in ESPN STAR Sports and Fox Pan-America Sports and so on. And I think we'll continue to look at acquisitions where we can simplify our business, where we can really a dimension and really add velocity and pace to the business. But we're not looking to fill a whole bunch of gaps,  if you will. I think we have a good position internationally. And to Chase's point before about long-term growth, I think it's really one of the drivers of our long-term growth when we look at our emerging markets position, particularly in India, i n parts of Asia and other parts of Asia. And in Latin America, we feel very, very strong about the position. That's not to say that we will rule things out. We'll look opportunistic publicity at a variety right of things, as you would expect. But we generally, at this point, I think would have a bias towards investing in ourselves other than kind of bolt-on kind of tactical things that can help us accelerate.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think at FX, first I think it's pretty much where we expected. I mean I think we expected for a couple of years as we are trying to build FXX side-by-side with FX, we were going to stretch it a bit. So I don't think that's a surprise to us and ramp
componenttext: And I think at FX, first I think it's pretty much where we expected. I mean I think we expected for a couple of years as we are trying to build FXX side-by-side with FX, we were going to stretch it a bit. So I don't think that's a surprise to us and ramp up programming to fill out 2 channels, obviously going from 1 to 2 does put some strain on it. We actually feel great where whole thing is. I mean I guess when I look at FX, I probably look at it first competitively, not in absolute sense. And this question whole cable industry is the well reported is dealing with the issue of traditional rating declines. I think FX has held up really well, and I think actually i's programming continues to if anything, distinguish itself from certainly its basic cable competitors more and more. And I love some of the shows they got coming this year, I think there great stuff. So I think we feel very good, I think we feel great about it [indiscernible] very good. I mean I think we knew there was going to be some pressures and competitively I think it's very strong and weren't dealing with the same pressures on ratings that the broader industry is and I think competitively have doing well.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Come from the line of Jessica Reif Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Come from the line of Jessica Reif Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So my 2 questions, it's 2 different ones. First on Truex. Can you talk a little bit how you can best utilize that business to drive advertising to kind of move the needle? And then the second question, can you go back to the currency impact. I know you we
componenttext: So my 2 questions, it's 2 different ones. First on Truex. Can you talk a little bit how you can best utilize that business to drive advertising to kind of move the needle? And then the second question, can you go back to the currency impact. I know you were just asked the question on acquisitions, but given this strength of the dollar, does it change at all you're thinking about making acquisitions outside the U.S.? Or does it change the way you might think about the buyback given the reset on fiscal '16 guidance if there's an impact on your stock price, would it make you accelerate? I mean how are you thinking about opportunistically the impact of currency?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica. This is James. On Truex, it's a little early, you'll see over the coming weeks and months some further kind of development in terms of the closing of the Truex transaction and how that I think it's embedded in a business. We're very excit
componenttext: Thanks, Jessica. This is James. On Truex, it's a little early, you'll see over the coming weeks and months some further kind of development in terms of the closing of the Truex transaction and how that I think it's embedded in a business. We're very excited about it and really for us it's about investing in the capability around ad innovation that we can service and the company as it does service multiple clients in the industry, but also it's going to be really think we can hopefully accelerate the rollout of new technology and some new ad products that we think are really at the forefront of thinking around how you monetize digital viewership, how you monetize timeship to viewership. And as we see the screening share of time shift to viewing continue to grow, vis-Ã -vis DVRs, really you have to remember that we're really just in very, very foothills of monetizing that viewership and that viewership is very, very large. It's a material percentage, above what our life plus 3 or life plus 7 viewing is. So it's really about monetizing the streaming environment and being able to accelerate with new ad products for other clients, other broadcasters as well as for ourselves, but there'll be more on that going forward. Fundamentally, it's about the acquisition capability within the networks group and we think it can move the dial over time.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think on the buyback, Jessica, it's John, no, and I don't think currency changes at all, changes our view on how we look at the buyback. As Chase indicated, we're scheduled to complete the current buyback. We'll assess it again at the end of the year. I
componenttext: I think on the buyback, Jessica, it's John, no, and I don't think currency changes at all, changes our view on how we look at the buyback. As Chase indicated, we're scheduled to complete the current buyback. We'll assess it again at the end of the year. I don't think current markets where we are is going to change our velocity of the buyback for the remainder of the year. And we'll continue to look to invest in ourselves, as James referred to, and to be opportunistic around opportunities that come up. But there's no current plan to change the pace, velocity or size of the current authorization.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: With respect to your question on whether or not currency would change our view on M&A, a strong dollar would mean, because at the end of the day, I think we're always going to be looking at opportunities around the quality of the businesses and how they'r
componenttext: With respect to your question on whether or not currency would change our view on M&A, a strong dollar would mean, because at the end of the day, I think we're always going to be looking at opportunities around the quality of the businesses and how they're really performing and the currency overlay of that is largely secondary.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes I mean  I think in terms of currency, I mean we probably look at the health of the region and the market. I mean probably not comment I guess you're looking at Europe, you obviously see got up sort of some degree of concerns about how Europe navigates
componenttext: Yes I mean  I think in terms of currency, I mean we probably look at the health of the region and the market. I mean probably not comment I guess you're looking at Europe, you obviously see got up sort of some degree of concerns about how Europe navigates the short-term. I think certainly there's a lot of international markets, we feel great about I mean India being a case in point, we still developing markets, still broadly very excited about. But clearly, got to be cognizant of what's going on in countries and certainly the currency issues we had in a place like Argentina are a reflection of sort of broader economic issues. So I think we always take broader economic issues, long-term broader economic issues into account in terms of the evaluating where we were going to invest. Again, I think most return investments I don't want to repeat it, would be in the form of building businesses, not making large international acquisitions.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Will come from the line of Richard Greenfield with BTIG.
componenttext: Will come from the line of Richard Greenfield with BTIG.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just first off kind of just housekeeping question. Looking at the solidness of your subscriber revenue streams that showed itself in the first half, when you look at the back half of the year given the reduction in full year guidance, can you just give
componenttext: So just first off kind of just housekeeping question. Looking at the solidness of your subscriber revenue streams that showed itself in the first half, when you look at the back half of the year given the reduction in full year guidance, can you just give us a sense, you talked about the currency, but what type of domestic ad market are you looking at for broadcast networks, stations and cable? Can you just give us some color on just it sounds like those numbers obviously down pretty substantially at least for the broadcast stations and networks, but just some sense of order of magnitude? And will cable also feel that effect versus the strength you had this quarter? And then just kind of a big picture question for I don't know for all of you. When you look at the rationale for the Time Warner acquisition attempt over the summer, it seemed to us that a direct consumer business with all of the content the combined companies would have had versus selling your content to Netflix was a huge potential benefit. As you look at kind of what's going on in advertising and you look at the kind of the strength that Netflix keeps growing, does it make it that much important to kind of revisit that transaction, work out some form of relationship with Time Warner, just because both of you could both in this ad market and the change in consumer, you both could use each other more than ever before?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess a little color, I mean on the first part I guess it's a little more color on the second half, I mean given there's ad market common of the ad markets I guess you cited that. What I'd say side of the ad markets we look at that them today. Nationall
componenttext: I guess a little color, I mean on the first part I guess it's a little more color on the second half, I mean given there's ad market common of the ad markets I guess you cited that. What I'd say side of the ad markets we look at that them today. Nationally, I guess they're okay, probably not where we might have hoped them. I think we came into this quarter hoping there'll be up, probably a bit more, of renewed budgets and the like probably this quarter feel probably like the fourth quarter, like the December quarter, maybe some rays of light to gives you a little  hope the national market to be a little better. But I guess I'd say it's not as robust as we would've hoped in terms of a rebound, but it's okay. Upfront pricing is still a premium to the scat. The scatter pricing is a premium to the upfront pricing. So it's okay. I would say the local markets are probably softer than the national markets. I think the local markets, from a market perspective as we look at what our expectations are for this year, I think the local markets took up the market factors had a bigger hit. I guess what as you look at sort of what surprised a little more visibility to sort of the adjusted guidance, I mean there's really sort of probably 3 buckets in aggregate that are sort of changes from when we last looked at it and it's currency, it's the Broadcast business and the content piece John touched on and they're probably all about equal, I mean sort of probably the better part of how these round numbers about probably $100 million in each. So I think we talk about the currency being $100 million, I think broadcast. Again the content which is a combination of Shine being clearly a significant event and then to a lesser extent, the Christmas releases that didn't pan out. In the broadcast piece, it's sort of it's probably our biggest rating it was already took. In the first quarter we knew our ratings were short. And to a large degree, our content upside offset the ratings shortfalls. Probably ratings are a little bit worse, but that our expectations in the quarter. But that sort of $100 million is probably a bit of ratings, sports as John touched on was a little soft. I mean our 2 big conference championship games were blowouts, the 2 biggest regular season games, I mean John gave each average clearly all didn't pan out, the NFL was attach behind in our big 4 gains in the last quarter, that was the $100 million is up a little bit. And clearly, the station market, we are expecting sort of and I think we talked about it going into the year, low single -- we weren't expecting much, but we were sort of expecting a low single-digit 1% to 2% market growth and probably looks like now a low to mid decline -- no, low mid-decline percentage. We do $1 billion in 6 months in that business, so if you got a 5% swing, it's $50 million. So if you had the broadcast pieces up and say it's $50 million in stations and $20 million to $25 million in the sorts and the biggest piece being the college games and another piece on the ratings on top of what really was largely we anticipated in the September quarter, that sort of give you the pieces and the offset we had in content went the other way, with Shine being pulled out and a couple of Christmas pictures not being what we thought they'd be.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Time Warner?
componenttext: Time Warner?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Time Warner, no, we are not. I won't give my move on spiel, but we've moved on. So now, we -- Time Warner was not a necessity for us and the issues we're facing today, we feel very excited by it. I do mean I think we have what we have a breadth of content
componenttext: Time Warner, no, we are not. I won't give my move on spiel, but we've moved on. So now, we -- Time Warner was not a necessity for us and the issues we're facing today, we feel very excited by it. I do mean I think we have what we have a breadth of content that enables us to navigate the space. You talked about Netflix, I think from the get-go, our approach to the SVOD space, Netflix in particular, specifically, the SVOD space in general, has been to be disciplined about it, to make sure we participate in that business, adhering to sort of rules that first and foremost defend the value, enable us to continue to grow our core businesses, which is the networks and make sure we're enlarging our overall pie and not cannibalizing our core businesses in an adverse way to the extent of short-term dollars. So we have been disciplined in terms of which we do it. The reality, our recent SVOD deals had been actually with Amazon or Hulu plus. So I think that's a positive, that you've got a more competitive marketplace than you've had there. But we will and will continue to ensure that we are not going to take actions that would prioritize short-term profits from a sale at the expense of the health of our long-term businesses. I think we've been through to that to date in these things and we will continue to ensure that we grow our overall business, and that's certainly the -- a rule, principal we'll stay true to as we develop the opportunities of the digital platforms. We think they're real opportunities to develop ways to offer our products in new and exciting ways and we have to figure out what are the right models for those, we're doing a lot of work on it. We're obviously engagingly with some third parties. We did announce we concluded a deal with Sony. We are talking to others. But in all these cases, we're going to ensure we do things that enables us to grow our overall business, not cannibalize it. And we think we have the franchises and the content that puts us in a leadership position to be must-have content with essentially not carrying meeting, at great package that doesn't have a content in, but I think our content at its core is content that really is central to the video business. And we are confident in our ability to navigate that and to ensure an exciting future for us.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015

Would the relationship sort of be the same for fiscal '16 as well as fiscal '15, like kind of equal contribution to the hit and original guidance? And the second question is, you guys launched interesting new initiative with some partners for local ratings kind of beta aimed at the Dallas market, the new queen rating service. Can you talk about that effort, why you launched it and what your ambitions for it are.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean I think I mean I guess first on '16, I'd say I think we talked about currency number next year being another approximately $200 million hit. Clearly, the Broadcast business goes forward off that base that we in. 2015  will provide a base to go
componenttext: Yes. I mean I think I mean I guess first on '16, I'd say I think we talked about currency number next year being another approximately $200 million hit. Clearly, the Broadcast business goes forward off that base that we in. 2015  will provide a base to go forward. So in many ways, that carries through and probably, we are a little bit look I think in the Broadcast business where we are, it's a little behind, we're behind a few years behind the curve, we expected to be on. I think we believe the values we talked about in the Broadcast business will be there, but we're not in the growth in the point of the growth curve we expect to be on. As we said, we're probably investing a bit more in sort of focusing on stabilizing the business next year as opposed to prioritizing growing profits. So that is so certainly the Broadcast business will carry through. The one that I say is in the film issues were really onetime. I mean Shine, we expected Shine to be out a year ago we didn't but certainly when we talked about this year, we expected Shine to be out in '16 and the films there are always onetime event. So there's nothing recurring about the content piece.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: On new ratings.
componenttext: On new ratings.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the new ratings, look, we think I'm not going to make the measurement issue a scapegoat for all the issues. So I think there's a valid issue. I think don't think we're happy with the measurement tools that exist out there, particularly  as all this vie
componenttext: On the new ratings, look, we think I'm not going to make the measurement issue a scapegoat for all the issues. So I think there's a valid issue. I think don't think we're happy with the measurement tools that exist out there, particularly  as all this viewership continues to move in new and different places. And we're going to do everything we can to try and get them more accurate and accurate and improved ways ability to measure viewership. And so we're going to continue to pursue any opportunities that present us the ability to do it as well as with Nielsen, certainly, continue to work with them. But clearly we think there are issues in terms of the actors the measurement and the ability of our current measurement tools to keep up with really where the viewership is going. I mean, it is clearly moving to places that really aren't being captured and adequately measured today. So I think we have to be proactive if not trying to find solutions.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Will come from the line of Vasily Karasyov with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Will come from the line of Vasily Karasyov with Sterne Agee.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think my question is for James. James now and then we see this argument from investor that there is an oversupply of content out there because of both for scripted entertainment and sports as the result of networks producing more SVOD services and so on
componenttext: I think my question is for James. James now and then we see this argument from investor that there is an oversupply of content out there because of both for scripted entertainment and sports as the result of networks producing more SVOD services and so on. So clearly, the company, you don't believe that. So I wonder if you can tell us what you think as the flaw is in this oversupply argument? And if you think it's even ever possible for it to happen in one of the categories?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much and I'm sure Chase will want to weigh in on this as well. But look I think there's no question that there's an absolutely enormous amount of original production going on right now. I mean I think it's less driven by the SVOD services, it'
componenttext: Thanks very much and I'm sure Chase will want to weigh in on this as well. But look I think there's no question that there's an absolutely enormous amount of original production going on right now. I mean I think it's less driven by the SVOD services, it's really just driven by cable network programmers getting into dramatic series production by and large and increasing volumes, and the numbers are still going up. But I think it's really important to remember that one hour of scripted television is very, very different from another hour of scripted Television. So the total volume isn't really the question, the right question is what are you making, how do you make it great, how do you stand out? And can you be a place that can attract the great show runners, the great writers, the great talent to come into incredible work? And I think we are very, very confident that creatively the teams across 21st Century Fox companies can continue to execute, they've been executing very well, but it's not really a question of a volume game, it's a question of how do you make stuff that's genuinely distinctive in that environment where you have so much consumer choice. And I think the thing that exacerbates the competitive kind of dynamic around it is that with the availability of streaming platforms and the availability of vast libraries of scripted programming, you're really competing with not just what's on in the same hour but you're competing with everything that's come before. And that's something that's it's a great creative talents but one that we feel is our core business to try to write to and to try to get great people to do that.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I guess I think all light had simplistically is, but there's not certainly an oversupply of hit programming, and that's all about it, maybe [indiscernible] realistically, there is an oversupply of media programming, but our goal. And I think
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I guess I think all light had simplistically is, but there's not certainly an oversupply of hit programming, and that's all about it, maybe [indiscernible] realistically, there is an oversupply of media programming, but our goal. And I think the real question is who is positioned, and there's a ton of product out there, so a ton of competition, who's positioned, best positioned, to create the hit programming of tomorrow. And who has the assets and the breadth and relationships and the scale. I think there'll be winners and losers. I think the business you see today will not be what the business looks like in a few years. And I do think there'll be winners and losers and I think who are going to be the winners, partners that are positioned, have the best opportunity and the best position to create the hits of tomorrow and we think we're in a great place. So -- and that's our goal.

componenttext: I think they're down a touch. I mean, not sure it's 1%, but it's sort of they're down a touch and that pretty much is in line with our expectations. We think whether it's a combination of millennials and economic pressures at the margins, We'd expected it and I think right now what we're seeing is pretty much in line with our expectations.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a good relationship. We're obviously navigating new times. And certainly, we're committed to working with them. We value the relationship with the affiliates. We value the business model with them. There was no question in a world of dual revenue wor
componenttext: It's a good relationship. We're obviously navigating new times. And certainly, we're committed to working with them. We value the relationship with the affiliates. We value the business model with them. There was no question in a world of dual revenue world where we believe our programming is what drives the subscription side of it. We are navigating new arenas to create the terms of commerce for us between them. And so I think not surprisingly, there's some of those get to be conversations with some friction in them. But we've had a good and healthy relationship and I think our goal is we've been able to do. I mean really most of our affiliates, we've continued to find to work with and have continued and our goal is to continue to find ways to work with them. So I think we're any time you're sort of navigating new business models and that's been really I mean is what we're doing with them, I think there'll be some frictions as you work through it. But our goal is to find something, goal is to find a fair solution. we think our programming is valuable. We think it deserves to be -- we deserve compensation for that programming and recognize fair is in the eyes of beholder, but that's what we're looking and expecting to get, it's fair compensation for our programming and that's our goal is going to work that out with them. What was the second question?

componenttext: Incentive options, look, I mean I think certainly something we're taking seriously, we are engaged in and some of the numbers get thrown around certainly are pretty interesting. If you look at the auctions just concluded and it certainly probably adds to that interest. So we don't know enough but there's still stuff to be flushed out. But certainly, we are fully engaged. So I think we certainly are fully engaged and I want to understand or what the opportunity there. There's certainly a number of signs that say it could be interesting.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one please. Chase, I think the growth at the domestic cable networks is noteworthy in the backdrop of the broader narrative you guys discussed around the ad market. And when we look at your next call, the market's going to be talking about the upfron
componenttext: Just one please. Chase, I think the growth at the domestic cable networks is noteworthy in the backdrop of the broader narrative you guys discussed around the ad market. And when we look at your next call, the market's going to be talking about the upfront. So with the viewing of content moving to multiple platforms and the revenue impact related to the measurement issues, do you have a view on the potential to deemphasize the upfront process or maybe information flow given the backdrop that markets also changing how they buy?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think. I mean certainly sitting here, we're not going to be projections about the upfront, but I don't think sort of 4 months away from now you'll be dramatically different approach what we have. But we are certainly changing how we're approaching
componenttext: I don't think. I mean certainly sitting here, we're not going to be projections about the upfront, but I don't think sort of 4 months away from now you'll be dramatically different approach what we have. But we are certainly changing how we're approaching the ad market. I mean as I touched on, we have restructured our entire ad sales organization. And in many ways, the primary reason for doing that was to position us to deal with the world going forward. I mean, the rust comp costs that came out but the objective is that secondary consideration that those were just efficiency moves. Our objective in reorganizing and restructuring the ad sales organization was to position us to deal with the world we expect to be competing in, which again has this viewership moving at places and advertisers. Not surprisingly wanting a lot of the attributes of efficiency and effectiveness that come with additional platforms. We estimate have to make sure we are positioned to take advantage of that. So I think that's a priority. I'm not sure our will be doing it starting today, not even the upfront, the upfront is part of that process. But certainly, the way we are approaching the entire ad market is in the state of transition. I will say in the digital, why lot of money is clearly a lot of desire there. I think 1 of the things we hope to do and I think our content because it would put it and help is still unclear to what degree our advertisers are getting value out of the digital market place. In many ways, that may be R&D spending which probably has a logic to it. But I think it's unclear in many places are they getting value for that spending? Or are they chasing just sort of goals in terms of attributes without knowing where they're getting the value for it? So I think I hope we can add dimension that sort of enables them to ensure by having content that really a sweet spot, that we're able to really deliver on the value that gets associated with those digital platforms.

componenttextpreview: Yes I mean as I said, it is a topic the board is engaged in broadly, it's buybacks, dividends. I don't want to get too far in front of the board in terms of talking about plans or initiatives. I think all I'd really say is, just generally, we've been clea
componenttext: Yes I mean as I said, it is a topic the board is engaged in broadly, it's buybacks, dividends. I don't want to get too far in front of the board in terms of talking about plans or initiatives. I think all I'd really say is, just generally, we've been clear. We think return of capital to shareholders is an important part of our overall philosophy. And the dividend, we look at our business, we've confidence in our business, and we think it's appropriate and we certainly thought this move is appropriate. I think we discuss further what's the balance between buybacks and dividends and overall speed of with which we return the capital through those various vehicles. But I think it is something we're committed to and again we will certainly be board meeting next week and we'll continue to discuss where we should be and it's a process we take seriously.
