componenttextpreview: I mean, incentive options, look, I mean, I think, it's certainly something we're taking seriously, we're engaged in and some of the numbers that get thrown around certainly are pretty interesting. If you look at the auction that just concluded and it cert
componenttext: I mean, incentive options, look, I mean, I think, it's certainly something we're taking seriously, we're engaged in and some of the numbers that get thrown around certainly are pretty interesting. If you look at the auction that just concluded and it certainly probably adds to that interest. So we don't know enough but there's obviously still stuff to be flushed out. But certainly, we are fully engaged. We've got a big station group. And in reality, 2 big station groups, if you include MyNet as a group. So we've got a lot of stations and a lot of spectrum. So I think, we certainly are fully engaged and want to understand more what's the opportunity there. There's certainly a number of signs that say it could be interesting.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Will come from the line of John Janedis with Jefferies LLC.
componenttext: Will come from the line of John Janedis with Jefferies LLC.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one please. Chase, I think, the growth at the domestic cable networks is noteworthy in the backdrop of the broader narrative you guys discussed around the ad market. And when we look at your next call, the market's going to be talking about the upfro
componenttext: Just one please. Chase, I think, the growth at the domestic cable networks is noteworthy in the backdrop of the broader narrative you guys discussed around the ad market. And when we look at your next call, the market's going to be talking about the upfront. So with the viewing of content moving to multiple platforms and the revenue impact related to the measurement issues, do you have a view on the potential to deemphasize the upfront process or maybe information flow given the backdrop that marketers are also changing how they buy?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think -- I mean, certainly, sitting here, I'm not going to make any projections about the upfront, but I don't think, sort of 4 months away from now, you'll be -- we're going to have a dramatically different approach. Look, we have -- we are c
componenttext: No, I don't think -- I mean, certainly, sitting here, I'm not going to make any projections about the upfront, but I don't think, sort of 4 months away from now, you'll be -- we're going to have a dramatically different approach. Look, we have -- we are certainly changing how we're approaching the ad market. I mean, as I touched on, we have restructured our entire ad sales organization. And in many ways, the primary reason for doing that was to position us to deal with the world going forward. I mean, there were some costs that came out but the objective, that's the secondary consideration that those were just efficiency moves. Our objective in reorganizing and restructuring the ad sales organization was to position us to deal with the world we expect to be competing in, which, again, has this -- has viewership moving to other places and advertisers, not surprisingly, wanting a lot of the attributes of efficiency and effectiveness that come with additional platforms. We have to make sure we're positioned to take advantage of that. So I think, that's the priority. I'm not sure if in terms of we'll be doing it starting today, not even the upfront, so the upfront is part of that process. But certainly, the way we're approaching the entire ad market is in a state of transition. I will say, in the digital, a lot of money -- clearly, there's a lot of desire there. I think, 1 of the things we hope to do and I think our content, because it's so important it can help is still unclear to what degree our advertisers are getting value out of the digital marketplace. In many ways, they may be what is R&D spending which probably has a logic to it. But I think, it's unclear, in many places, are they getting value for that spending? Or are they chasing sort of goals in terms of attributes without knowing whether they're getting the value for it? So I think, I hope we can add a dimension that sort of enables them to ensure by having content that really we think is a sweet spot, that we're able to really deliver on the value that gets associated with those digital platforms.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Comes from the line of Barton Crockett with FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: Comes from the line of Barton Crockett with FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the dividend in the context of your comment earlier that you're now in an overcapitalized position. It's great and encouraging to see the 20% hike in the recurring dividend. So I was wondering if you can talk about what drove the ana
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the dividend in the context of your comment earlier that you're now in an overcapitalized position. It's great and encouraging to see the 20% hike in the recurring dividend. So I was wondering if you can talk about what drove the analysis that got you there? And as you look at your capitalized position, what are your feelings about maybe using more of that for dividend, either recurring or special?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as I said, it is a topic the board is engaged in broadly, it's buybacks, dividends. I don't want to get too far in front of the board in terms of talking about plans or initiatives. I think, all I'd really say is, just generally, we've been c
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as I said, it is a topic the board is engaged in broadly, it's buybacks, dividends. I don't want to get too far in front of the board in terms of talking about plans or initiatives. I think, all I'd really say is, just generally, we've been clear, we think return of capital to shareholders is an important part of our overall philosophy. And the dividend, we look at our business, we have confidence in our business, and we think it's appropriate and we certainly thought this move is appropriate. And I think, we'll discuss further what's the balance between buybacks and dividends and overall speed with which we return the capital through those various vehicles. But I think, it is something we're committed to and we will, again, we will certainly -- we have a board meeting next week, and certainly, we'll continue to discuss where we should be and it's a process we take seriously.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that will come from the line of Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And that will come from the line of Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the broadcast network, your earlier commentary about reinvesting in it and hoping to stabilize the Broadcast business. I guess, if you can give us some color on how constrained you are from an inventory perspective with make goods to ta
componenttext: Just a question on the broadcast network, your earlier commentary about reinvesting in it and hoping to stabilize the Broadcast business. I guess, if you can give us some color on how constrained you are from an inventory perspective with make goods to take advantage of maybe some improvement in demand down the road? How far out are those make goods sort of eating up inventory, how much flexibility you have in them?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, in the Broadcast business, we don't really have a make good issue in it. I mean, you probably -- again, we probably don't have -- probably one of the facts is we don't quite have the inventory we might have for the scatter market, we're in the s
componenttext: Actually, in the Broadcast business, we don't really have a make good issue in it. I mean, you probably -- again, we probably don't have -- probably one of the facts is we don't quite have the inventory we might have for the scatter market, we're in the scatter market, but from a make good perspective, we don't really have anything that would be out of the ordinary course for us on a make good. We have opportunity as the years goes along through various vehicles and events at times to address obviously our -- obviously, we are short on our ratings, so they're not where we expected, and so we have to deal with that. But we're pretty good at dealing with that on an ongoing basis, not letting it stockpile. And that's certainly true today, where we are.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2015

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Twenty-First Century Fox Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. Now I'd like to turn the conference over to our hos
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Twenty-First Century Fox Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. Now I'd like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; James Murdoch, Co-chief Operating Officer; and John Nallen, ou
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; James Murdoch, Co-chief Operating Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer.
First, we'll give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, and then we'll be happy to take questions from the investment community. This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to Twenty-First Century Fox's business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended March 31, 2015, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filings. 
Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing. 
Finally, please note that certain financial measures used in this call such as segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release.
And with that, I'm pleased to turn it over to John.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Reed. Before we get into the specific earnings commentary, just a reminder that because of the sale of our DBS businesses to Sky this past November, our reported financial results for the third quarter this year do not include the consolidation of
componenttext:
Thanks, Reed. Before we get into the specific earnings commentary, just a reminder that because of the sale of our DBS businesses to Sky this past November, our reported financial results for the third quarter this year do not include the consolidation of these DBS businesses as compared to a full quarter consolidation a year ago. So similar to last quarter, to provide a more meaningful comparative analysis, we are providing total company adjusted revenue and adjusted EBITDA, which excludes the DBS businesses in all periods.
Now turning to the quarter results. Third quarter total company revenues were $6.8 billion, up $84 million compared to the year ago adjusted result, reflecting double-digit increases at our Cable Networks segment and mid-single-digit increases at Film. This growth was mostly offset by lower Television segment revenues where the prior-year results included approximately $350 million in revenues from the broadcast of the Super Bowl.
Total segment EBITDA for the third quarter was $1.68 billion, a 3% reduction versus the adjusted EBITDA from a year ago of $1.73 billion. This year's result reflects continued strong underlying Cable Network segment contributions and higher Film segment contributions. These increases were more than offset by reduced Television segment results, reflecting last year's Super Bowl broadcast as well as this year's impact of the investments in our new sports channels in India. Additionally, this quarter reflected the most unfavorable year-on-year comparisons so far of foreign exchange rates. And as a result, our overall total EBITDA growth rate was reduced by approximately 7 percentage points in the quarter.
From a bottom-line perspective, on a GAAP basis, we reported income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $990 million as compared to the $1.07 billion we reported a year ago. Equity earnings were $160 million higher than a year ago, primarily reflecting this year's inclusion of our share of Sky's gain on the sale of Sky bet. Excluding the net income effects of Other net, as well as certain adjustments to equity earnings, including eliminating the gain on the Sky bet sale and eliminating last year's gain from participating in Sky share repurchase program, third quarter adjusted earnings per share were $0.42 this year versus $0.47 in the prior year.
Now let me provide some comments on the performance at our businesses. Let's start with the Cable Networks, where our total segment revenues increased 14% from last year, highlighted by a 15% increase in affiliate revenues and 9% advertising revenue growth.
With respect to affiliate revenues, domestic affiliate fees increased 20%, primarily from higher average rates led by the RSNs, FX and FOX News, as well as increases from the conversion of our new channels, FS1 and FXX. The inclusion of the YES Network for the full quarter this year also contributed to our growth. Excluding the contribution from YES, we had a mid-teens domestic affiliate fee increase.
Our reported international affiliate fees were up 2%, reflecting an underlying mid-teens local currency growth rate, which was mostly offset by unfavorable foreign exchange movements, particularly in Latin America and in Europe.
The 9% total cable ad revenue growth from the quarter was led by our international channels, where reported international advertising grew 24%, reflecting 29% growth on a local currency basis. This growth was primarily driven by increases at STAR from this year's broadcast of the ICC World Cup.
The third quarter domestic advertising revenues were at similar levels to a year ago, with increases of the sports networks, FOX News and FXX, essentially being offset by lower ad revenues at FX and in National Geographic Channel due to lower ratings.
Total Cable segment EBITDA in the third quarter of $1.23 billion was up 5% over the prior year, reflecting the solid revenue growth, which was partially offset by a planned 19% increase in expenses, primarily related to higher sports rights and entertainment programming costs. Around 60% of the increase in expenses came from STAR Sports, most notably, the cost of the Cricket World Cup rights. The negative comparative effect from the strengthening U.S. dollar impacted the segment growth rate by around 5%. EBITDA at our domestic cable channels increased 21% from higher contributions at FOX News and from our sports channels, including the impact of consolidating the YES Network for the full quarter. This EBITDA growth was partially offset by lower contributions from the FX Networks due to increased programming costs.
At the international channels, despite local currency growth at FIC, our reported international channel EBITDA contributions declined 60%, driven by both the sizable planned Cricket investment we made at STAR Sports as well as the overall negative impact from foreign exchange rates, especially from Latin America.
At our Television segment, third quarter EBITDA was $141 million, roughly half the contribution generated in the third quarter a year ago. This decline principally reflects the absence of the revenue and earnings from the Super Bowl broadcast in the prior year, as well as higher entertainment programming costs this year from a higher volume of original series, including Glee and Empire. Excluding last year's Super Bowl, segment revenues were consistent with the year-ago quarter as strong retransmission consent revenue growth was offset by a 7% decline in ad revenues due to lower general entertainment ratings at the Broadcast network.
Turning to our Film segment. We reported third quarter EBITDA of $382 million, an 8% increase over year ago results as higher film studio contributions more than offset lower Television production results and the unfavorable impacts of foreign currency. Total segment revenues in the quarter increased $110 million or 5%, driven by several successful theatrical releases, including Kings Men and Taken 3, as well as home entertainment revenues from Rio 2 and The Fault in Our Stars.
The reduced contributions from Television production are largely due to lower SVOD revenues this year reflecting last year's multiseries sale to Amazon, which included 24 and The Americans.
Now before I turn to guidance, let me make a couple of capital-related comments. We ended the quarter with $9.3 billion in cash and $19.1 billion in gross debt. These balances reflect strong cash generation from operating activities in the quarter alone of approximately $1.8 billion and share repurchases in the quarter of $2.1 billion.
Subsequent to the quarter, we've continued to actively repurchase shares. From July 1 through today, we've repurchased approximately $5.25 billion of FOXA shares and we have approximately $1.25 billion remaining on our current authorization. So we're on plan to complete the $6 billion buyback within the 12-month timeframe that we previously announced.
Now let me address our guidance update for fiscal 2015. And as a reminder, for guidance purposes, we are excluding the DBS businesses for the entirety of all periods, resulting in a base EBITDA for fiscal 2014 of $6.29 billion.
On our last quarters earnings call, we indicated that the strengthening dollar would have an adverse impact on our EBITDA growth for the year based on exchange rates at that time. Since that call, the dollar, on average, has continued to strengthen although in recent days, it's begun to weaken against certain currencies. So this volatility makes it difficult to forecast with precision the impact on our results, but we estimate that foreign exchange rates could have up to an incremental 1 percentage point negative impact on our growth rate. Absent this potential impact, we are maintaining our guidance for our total segment EBITDA percentage growth rate for fiscal 2015 to be at the lower end of the mid-single-digit range above the $6.29 billion total segment EBITDA base level for fiscal 2014.
With that, let me turn it over to Chase.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Our results continue to be driven by competitive strength at our Cable Networks, strong affiliate fee growth and leadership in our content businesses, while we face headwinds due to both foreign currency and the turnaround efforts at our Bro
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Our results continue to be driven by competitive strength at our Cable Networks, strong affiliate fee growth and leadership in our content businesses, while we face headwinds due to both foreign currency and the turnaround efforts at our Broadcast business. Our third quarter results were further impacted by the absence of the Super Bowl this year and significant investments at STAR Sports in India, particularly the Cricket World Cup.
We will address our guidance for the next fiscal year on our year end call in August. Therefore, I want to use the next few minutes address some specific issues.
As I noted a minute ago, we continue to have strong underlying growth at our cable channels driven by higher affiliate fees. We also continue to close agreements that meet or exceed our expectations for new and existing agreements. At the same time, there's increasing noise in the market about new over-the-top offers, skinny bundles and other new options for consumers to access content. It is important to provide a bit of insight when considering these issues.
First, we believe the current pay-TV ecosystem is strong and the consumers continue to value choice and breadth and content. While we're seeing a small decline in pay-TV subs, we believe the vast majority of customers will continue to want a bundle of channels that is priced appropriately as opposed to a limited number of premium priced channels.
Second, our existing carriage agreements are carefully constructed, not only provide us with a fair value for our content, but also specify the terms in which our channels are packaged and distributed. Many agreements provide limited flexibility for customer retention or experimentation with alternative packages. Any plans to distribute our package or channels in other ways would require a significantly different pricing structure. Even with this, we do expect there'd be more choices for consumers. This means more competition for our content. It also provides us opportunities to expand our business by providing consumers a better experience and connecting with customers we may not reach today. Not everyone will benefit from these changes. We continue to believe that content will be the ultimate beneficiary of the growth of digital platforms and, that within the content world, those with must-have brands and content at scale will be the true winners. As both existing MVPDs and new entrants try to construct new consumer offers, those with broad hit content and unique brands will be best positioned to come out on top. We believe we are uniquely positioned to be such a winner.
In the U.S. and, increasingly, internationally, we built our business around 5 key brands: Fox Sports, FOX News, FX, National Geographic and FOX, each of which is a market leader with unique strengths. At FOX sports, we've locked up key local national and international rights well into the next decade. Our Regional Sports Networks add a critical dimension to our sports business that truly distinguishes us. The sheer popularity of the RSNs have made that business a pillar of strength second to none for us. We've used our scale, experience and broad affiliate agreements to enable us to continue to grow these businesses.
FOX News and FX have also established themselves as true industry leaders. FOX News is as dominant as ever, leading CNN, MSNBC and HLN combined in primetime viewers. At the FX Network, the quality, breadth and distinctiveness in the programming really make it a premium channel residing in the basic cable space. Additionally, our FXX channel has essentially doubled its viewership from a year ago. National Geographic is one of the most recognized brands in the world. While the channel is still a work in progress, we believe we haven't come close to tapping its true potential.
The FOX Network is clearly on a turnaround in the entertainment side. Nonetheless, it continues to be a driving force with enormous upside. The sports side of the network has been further strengthened this year by adding the FIFA World Cup and U.S. Open Golf to our portfolio of NFL, MLB and NASCAR events. 
On the entertainment side, this season's Gotham and, more recently, Empire, give us momentum as we head into next week's upfront and Dana Walden and Gary Newman are given the business a fresh energy and excitement. We are not the first broadcast network to fight through a turnaround, and we're confident we are on our way.
The breadth and strength of our brands and content are also going to be critical as we navigate the changes to the advertising side of our business. Our product has never seen such demand. However, we don't yet have the ability to effectively monetize the growing viewership. We also need to realize the consumers in the digital world are not going to be captivate viewers that will sit through 16 minutes of ads an hour. Advertising will have to be more effective and engaging to justify a premium. We'll need to work more closely with advertisers to connect with consumers in ways they value and enjoy. 
Both the recent reorganization of our channels ad sales group and our true x acquisition are steps in this direction.
There'll be short-term challenges such as those we're experiencing today in the advertising side of our business which can create pressure as we work to develop new business models. However, for those that navigate this transition successfully, the media industry that emerges on the other side will be one with enormous growth potential and an incredibly exciting future. One of the keys to success will be the ability to be disciplined in the face of industry noise and to be willing to invest and build on positions of strength even in the face of uncertain times. This is a time to prioritize long-term gains over short-term pain. We need to resist the temptation to react the short-term disruptions that we can air long-term future. In many ways, it's a time to double down. We will also continue to invest aggressively in original content. Many have asked if the current level of original content adoption is sustainable. The obvious answer is that it is if we create the best content. We contend the winners in the content will be those with the management and infrastructure to maximize the value of that content. Our proven track record, management bench strength, deep roster of talent relationships, unique library and worldwide set of leading industry network industry-leading networks will enable us to monetize content second to none.
We also need to control a much wider set of rights to the content we distribute. Today's slicing and dicing rights are over. In order to create the best consumer experience and maximize the value of our content and networks, we need to have the flexibility to come to the broader set of rights. The best path to controlling own destinies is to create our own product. We will clearly continue to work with third parties, but the sweet spot is undoubtedly where we own and distribute our own content. Our leadership position in content gives us a big advantage in achieving that goal. In closing, we believe we are incredibly well-positioned and are confident that today's challenges represent real opportunities for the future. Thank you.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say there's a dramatic change. I mean, probably, the ad market is probably we're a little better in April. I mean right now you have the quiet that always exists sort of before the upfront, so it's sort of heading into the upfront, the judge ri
componenttext: I wouldn't say there's a dramatic change. I mean, probably, the ad market is probably we're a little better in April. I mean right now you have the quiet that always exists sort of before the upfront, so it's sort of heading into the upfront, the judge right now. But I think they are okay. I mean, clearly, we're going to a transition here. Advertisers without doubt have more choices they want more flexibility in some ways. You could say the upfront we're about to go into while important is probably a bit of antiquated practice given where the world is heading. Advertisers want more flexibility. I think for us, I think it's increasingly important, that's why we restructured our group that we really work with advertisers to figure out how we create unique opportunities with unique messages that resonate. I think there's a degree more energy in it. But again, I think everybody's still trying to navigate this new space. There's no question everybody wants the attributes that are associated with the digital world. I think in some ways the promises ahead of the reality. And I think some of that reality has got to get fleshed out and people have to understand. We have to do a better job of prioritizing, monetizing that viewership. I mean, we've taken steps. Certainly, it's become a not immaterial part of our business but it's got to get -- we're in the middle of the first inning what we need to do in terms of monetizing that ad inventory, we need to develop the capabilities to do it. But a lot of it's sort of prioritizing, focus and working with these advertisers to develop the right messages and the right communications for those advertisers.

componenttextpreview: I was actually thinking about that advertising question and how different the upfront will be this year. And I was just wondering, if how are you guys approaching it given I mean there's obviously the measurement issues, but you also what will be the curr
componenttext: I was actually thinking about that advertising question and how different the upfront will be this year. And I was just wondering, if how are you guys approaching it given I mean there's obviously the measurement issues, but you also what will be the currency be? Do you think there'll be more cross platform? How this programmatic plans with this year? And then since you restructured your ad division, do you think that most of deals will be across broadcasting cable?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Again, these changes usually are more incremental. I mean people are these are of the world is going to be, but people have to do business short-term, so I think the change will be more incremental in nature but clearly, we know that direction it's headin
componenttext: Again, these changes usually are more incremental. I mean people are these are of the world is going to be, but people have to do business short-term, so I think the change will be more incremental in nature but clearly, we know that direction it's heading. I think all those things will be a bigger factor than they've been in the past, but it's going to take time. Again, you're sort of in a lot of ways we haven't developed a lot of the capabilities, not just measurement but technology and other things to measuring effectiveness, capabilities, deliver on the promise of it. We're better than we were, but it's still really early days. So I think all those things would be a part of it. Certainly, all the trends, you're talking currency, we need to clearly C3 we said before, the answer in C7  in the answer they're all directionally the answer of starting to measure the viewership outside the linear network. We've got a long, long way to go to really monetize every viewership in every shape and form we can to work clearly with the reorganization to work with advertisers, to find ways. I think certainly, we will be much more looking across. I mean the purpose of putting our ad sales together was to sell across our platforms. So and in many ways, we're going to create unique relationships with advertisers. What we want to do is use you did make franchise we have across the breadth of them. That's how we create something that really takes advantage of our unique content and brands is to give an advertiser an ability to access customers across all our franchises and to develop then unique messages that resonate. Again, I think it's increasingly important we find ways to make advertising not an encumbrance to consumers but value-added part of the experience. That's part of what through to us it's an ability to make the advertising experience one that is more valued. And part of the value is making more relevant. But all those things have to be part of directionally where we're going. We're not going to get there in the next 2 months, but certainly we expect to make steps and in all honesty, we've made steps to date, but we have a long, long way to go.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just had 2 questions. Chase, I know you said you wanted to address the guidance on the next call, but you did talk about a mid-$7 billion target for EBITDA for fiscal '16 on your last call. I guess I was just wondering what the confidence level is in stil
componenttext: Just had 2 questions. Chase, I know you said you wanted to address the guidance on the next call, but you did talk about a mid-$7 billion target for EBITDA for fiscal '16 on your last call. I guess I was just wondering what the confidence level is in still achieving that kind of number for next year? And then also had a follow-up question on advertising. What specifically are you seeing on scatter pricing right now? If you could talk about that. And do you see C7 as being the predominant currency? And does that even matter? Or do you end up just with lower pricing on C7 versus C3?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess in terms of the guidance, as I said, we really do plan to address that at year-end. We're just beginning our budget reviews now, I mean actually the first budget meeting is later this week, so we haven't even had the first one. And as you get clos
componenttext: I guess in terms of the guidance, as I said, we really do plan to address that at year-end. We're just beginning our budget reviews now, I mean actually the first budget meeting is later this week, so we haven't even had the first one. And as you get close to do it, we got to get a handle on there will be things that affect the budgets, such as the ongoing strength of the dollar, we'll have visibility to that; updated views on the ad markets post the upfront specifics and our content release schedule; level of investments in content; all those things will come through. So I think we've historically, which is why we give the guidance sort of at year-end that we've gone through to get a handle on it and I think that's probably where we're going to stick with it. Scatter market, I mean the pricing's actually been pretty good. I mean I think probably the volume probably is not quite as strong as pricing. But pricing actually in the scatter market pretty good. I think in terms of currency, I'm not going to predict C3 versus C7. I think probably the second part of your question, it's probably more relevant, I mean it matters, but at the end of the day, I think neither one is the answer and there probably will be some dynamics of pricing factored what you put into it. What we need to do is make it a priority to monetize viewership, all the viewership that's occurring, which is why we neither needed C3 nor C7 is the answer. To some degree, the product has to have really almost sold in a different way, it has to be sold in a premium basis, I mean not just queuing up with what we're selling linearly. We need to worlds going to have, it's going to have different ad loads and going to have different advertising messages with different capabilities that hopefully should be much more attractive. And in some degree we have to move to figure out how we get paid for the premium value of the advertising that can exist in the marketplace going forward. And so things like C3 and C7 to me are small steps but they're not the answer. They're not irrelevant, so we do want to capture more of that viewership in the manner we can through at least reflecting the expanding viewership in all these digital platforms. But that's not the end goal. The end again goal is to figure out how do we get fairly compensated for the product that really is a product that everybody wants. At the end of the day, product that consumers and advertisers all want to deal with is our product. We need the ability we need to be able to build the capability to monetize the popularity of that viewership. And again, C7 is not an answer, it's a small step in the right direction. But just a small step.

componenttext: So Chase, at you [indiscernible] 2 years of investing in cable networks followed by a period of strong margin expansion and we're almost at the end of that 2 years of investment and you went out of your way today to talk about investing to be able to position of strength, time to double and down, expand the business by offering better experience in reaching customers you don't reach today. I feel like there's sort of dancing around the over-the-top strategy for the company. And what I'm wondering is, are you suggesting investors brace for another investment cycle stacked on the end of this last one? And what do you think we should consider Fox's over-the-top strategy likely to be going forward? Any sense of cadence around this would be helpful.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't read more probably overreading things into it. I mean, I guess probably the investing comment that is going and it's not solely speaking to this, probably is a comment first and foremost about the FOX Network. I mean clearly the FOX Network, I
componenttext: I wouldn't read more probably overreading things into it. I mean, I guess probably the investing comment that is going and it's not solely speaking to this, probably is a comment first and foremost about the FOX Network. I mean clearly the FOX Network, I mean you could we report segment, so it's not a secret. The FOX Network is not where we think it should be and where we plan for it to be. We think we've got some nice momentum with Empire and Gotham and a couple of things coming. We like the sports franchises we've added. We still look at FOX Network as a business that should be the shining light that it's at the top of the pyramid that drives our business forward. Clearly, it's not performed at such. It's taken its ratings declines in the last few years or not that we planned on. We're excited about new management team. We made the changes to drive that business and I think it's so I think certainly it's that in the case in point probably is the most is probably the clearest case in point is, I think thing, we think that's a great business. And we think we need to continue to have the backbone to invest to drive that business to what it can be as opposed to saying how do we sort of hit a profit target in the next year for the FOX Network as opposed to investing to enable it to get to the right place 3 years from now. So I think it's probably talking more about that type of investment. I think I guess the only other comment I'd make is, in general, you go back the Analyst Day, the world is fluid. I mean I think you've got to be opportunistic and you got to make judgments as you get to various places in time as what's the right decision, what's the competitive marketplace, what are the other industry dynamics that have occurred and how do you manage your business to build long-term value from what you know today. And certainly, today, and I'm not facts, it's not making any judgments about margins or anything else as opposed to, today, clearly, there have been -- I think there have been changes in the marketplace. Certainly, the impacts on ratings across Cable Networks have probably been larger than one would've expected a year ago, including me. I wouldn't have -- I think some of those shifts have been larger than would have anticipated, we saw the trends coming. And I think as the world evolves, you've got to adjust to it. And I think a lot of our businesses, things like investing in sports and FS1 is pretty much right on plan. The produce programming is still a work in progress and we are bringing in new executive, we announced in to be the point person for that. We knew creating programming takes time, some of its works, some of it hasn't. And we actually feel great about where it is and we're pretty much where we expect it to be. So I think in general, I think their business is clearly aren't where we expect it to be, the broadcast network. Obviously, the international channels have taken the competitively closer where we are, the financials aren't where we expect it to be because of the currency. But more broadly, I think we are continuing to adhere to things we talked about and -- but we're always I think we said it at the Analyst Day, I think you always want I think it's important that you continue to aggressively compete in the world as you know more as the world evolves. I think in terms of over-the-top, I think over-the-top is a very important part of our future. Now that being said, as I said in the prepared comments, we still think most consumers are going to want to bundle a programming. I don't think they want to buy Ã  la carte, they want to buy a bundle of programming. We think there'd be more people, more players offering bundles of programming. I think those bundles have to be ones that are concocted with the consumer in mind, not something that is artificially concocted by the content owner and a distributor that doesn't really make sense, the alignment of what that content is doesn't make sense to a consumer. So you have to figure out. You're going if these over-the-top players are going to be what are they bringing in many ways certainly bringing a better consumer experience. I think in some ways, the Netflix and Hulus are sort of cases in point of a better value of a better consumer experience. I mean, and I think go in the flip side and say the struggle TV Everywhere have been an example of the challenge you have when you don't create the right consumer experience. So I think there can be over-the-top players that bring a new consumer experience that again, at its core, is still offering a bundle of programming and not exactly what's out there it's that if you want to make sure you must have valid that has to be in that bundle if you're creating a bundle that really resonates with that consumer and we do still think consumers want proactive choice that we've got the content that will be a central part in any of those over-the-top bundles but I think bringing obviously the competition is good but bringing a better, bringing better experiences to the marketplace. If people can develop better user interfaces, that's a positive. And I mean I always front DIRECTV when I was there, one of the reasons DIRECTV I think competed successfully against the cable industry was it was better experience. I think the easy-to-use and simplicity are probably some of the most underappreciated assets in the business. Actually we're excited about it. We've got probably amongst any of our peers have more firsthand experience in dealing directly with businesses internationally, that deal directly with consumers that create consumer interfaces and manage relationships with consumers so we think over-the-top for us specifically is an interesting opportunity. We think working with third parties to create more competition and new experiences is an important opportunity. We also think there are customers that again I think the predominant majority will want a bundle. I think there are consumers that probably are interested in alternatives, everybody talkies about the millennials. And I think the ability to create packages or offers that they speak to that generation is also an interesting opportunity. Obviously there are consumers we don't reach today and we want to be and additive way, I think it's important everything we do is adding to the pie, not cannibalizing the pie, create offers that speak to customers that want something different, we think that will be a relatively small minority but it's important for us to do and we look forward to developing all of that.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That will come from the line of David Bank with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: That will come from the line of David Bank with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chase, James, John, I think -- so, look, Chase, I think, has been talking a fair amount this in a number of his comments that there has been focus on a lighter bundle. I think for us, particularly on the sort of very nascent OTT MVPD side, we are trying t
componenttext: Chase, James, John, I think -- so, look, Chase, I think, has been talking a fair amount this in a number of his comments that there has been focus on a lighter bundle. I think for us, particularly on the sort of very nascent OTT MVPD side, we are trying to navigate this and we don't have much to extrapolate from. We have what basically the sling is kind of out there, Sony PlayStation view is out there, there's a lot of speculation around what might be an Apple. And FOX has a lot I think of relatively kind of average price must-have programming, not outside the mean, the broadcast network ONOs, news, general entertainment, even national sports. But we don't really know where the RSNs fit in and we don't have a lot of data to base them on, I guess outside of sling and Sony, if you can talk about that. But how do you see the distribution landscape shaping up for the RSNs in OTT MVPD world? What's your confidence that the distribution model sustains itself?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't actually, in all honesty I don't think I look at the RSNs really as I guess this geographically different, so they're different in that across I think our RSNs in aggregate cover 70% of the country. So in somewhat you can say the RSNs for us a
componenttext: No, I don't actually, in all honesty I don't think I look at the RSNs really as I guess this geographically different, so they're different in that across I think our RSNs in aggregate cover 70% of the country. So in somewhat you can say the RSNs for us are a national business. And I do think that strength in RSNs is a distinguishing feature for us against a lot of the other people. But I don't actually look at it, I think the RSNs represents great must-have content. And I think that it is as important as any content that exists in a local market for a large segment of consumers. Obviously, any piece of content is relevant to everybody but is content second to none. It is, and I think in some ways, I guess we judge its importance when we -- as we engage with our distributors in the marketplace. And it has continued to be a critical part of our business. It continues a critical pillar of driving our business forward. Obviously, some others have stumbled in it. I think we've proven a capability, sort of the L.A. and Houston points to we've proven a capability that we know how to manage, we know how to manage, I think our scale helps this and most of our agreements in place are long-term. I think over 80% of our agreements are into the 20s. And we know how to continue to renew them in terms that work I think we've renewed about 20% of our team deals in the last couple of years. So it's a business that and again we bring a lot of strength that would enable us to make these instances work and that others on a lot of bases obviously our established relationships with MVPDs are all part of that. So in many ways, I just look at it is some way we'd look at the other channels, the other channels we have and being one if not the most important drivers in the business. And we do think again that those array of channels are going to be our must-have content for consumers out there.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's James here just to add David, it's consistent with the overall strategy for the last number of years in the business, which has been to concentrate meaningful investment in programming, be it entertainment, news, sports or actual programming that is
componenttext: It's James here just to add David, it's consistent with the overall strategy for the last number of years in the business, which has been to concentrate meaningful investment in programming, be it entertainment, news, sports or actual programming that is arranged around really big brands and distinctiveness that really matters. And I think we see the RSNs as sort of a separate category from that. It's really beat in part and parcel of how we approach the marketplace both in the United States and in other markets as we've invested in sports around the place. And to Chase's point, the result of the RSNs and the results in our sports businesses around the world are validating that more as opposed to less.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think it's always the noise around RSNs is really come off a couple of specifics. I think the single team RSN, I don't think they've been a great thing, and I think that's not really the business we built. And there are couple of places where I thin
componenttext: And I think it's always the noise around RSNs is really come off a couple of specifics. I think the single team RSN, I don't think they've been a great thing, and I think that's not really the business we built. And there are couple of places where I think pricing obviously the places we passed on across the continent. I think you have to be disciplined to make judgments. So I think if you manage it properly and again I think the sort of 1 team RSNs are sort of more limited phenomenon that have created broader noise. And I think some degree positively, some of the events of the last year plus have been sobering for the business. And I don't think in many ways, helpful in terms of get us over in some of the 1 team sort of open ended euphoria.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: One team and single market, which is hard.
componenttext: One team and single market, which is hard.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

componenttext: We'll go to the line of Michael Nathanson with Moffat Nathanson.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have one for Chase. Let me focus this question on U.S. cable networks. The cost growth as you predicted at Investor Day, the past 2 years have been of investment spending with double-digit cable cost growth. I wonder now you almost done with that invest
componenttext: I have one for Chase. Let me focus this question on U.S. cable networks. The cost growth as you predicted at Investor Day, the past 2 years have been of investment spending with double-digit cable cost growth. I wonder now you almost done with that investment cycle, what's the right way to think about cost growth domestically at cable going forward? Because in the past before the cycle started, you guys were mid to high single digit expense growers us. So that I think one of the questions people to get is what's normalized spending post the investment cycle?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that I mean if everything was ordinary course, obviously, again our broadcast network is not where we wanted to be. So if you said the cable networks, I think probably back to that is probably sort of what you'd expect. And again, we've sort of ha
componenttext: I think that I mean if everything was ordinary course, obviously, again our broadcast network is not where we wanted to be. So if you said the cable networks, I think probably back to that is probably sort of what you'd expect. And again, we've sort of had to ramp-up in sports and the ramp-up to take FX from 1 to 2 networks, but I think once you get past that, I think what you have before is sort of what it comes back to. And again, that's dependent on new opportunities. Obviously, they'll dictate new plans, but just in the world as defined as it is today, back to where it was.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me ask you about buybacks. I see if you go back and look at the $2 billion plus you spent this quarter, maybe the highest buyback quarter almost ever in previous News Corp. And given your $9 billion of cash in your books and you accelerated to t
componenttext: Okay. Let me ask you about buybacks. I see if you go back and look at the $2 billion plus you spent this quarter, maybe the highest buyback quarter almost ever in previous News Corp. And given your $9 billion of cash in your books and you accelerated to this quarter, what does that say about your goal for the next couple of years on buybacks? Is the $6 billion the right run rate? Or can we expect people stock prices and the cash generation that you'll start accelerating the rate of buyback?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean we're not going to make predictive comments, I think we've said that we're going to continue to hear it pretty much we'll address the next buyback when we get through this buyback, we'll address it with the board before obviously year-end and we'll
componenttext: I mean we're not going to make predictive comments, I think we've said that we're going to continue to hear it pretty much we'll address the next buyback when we get through this buyback, we'll address it with the board before obviously year-end and we'll announce what we plan to do on that year end call. But we're not going to ahead of the board that's a cycle we're in that we're going to stick with.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That will be from Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.
componenttext: That will be from Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

componenttext: When you look at your hit shows like Empire, Gotham, can you give us some color how much you think you can leverage those hits in the upfront in terms of getting better pricing across your lineup? And also now you have a better sense of the lineup is for next year I guess any color on how we expect programming expense and network next year?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to put a number to them. Look, I guess what is clearly true in today's world is hits are more valuable than ever, sort of second rate product is mediocre product is less valuable and hits are more valuable than they've ever been. So when you
componenttext: I'm not going to put a number to them. Look, I guess what is clearly true in today's world is hits are more valuable than ever, sort of second rate product is mediocre product is less valuable and hits are more valuable than they've ever been. So when you get a phenomena like Empire, it's great, it obviously is product that with all the platforms and all the abilities to access content wherever you want, it many ways becomes must-have content for tremendous important I'm not going hits just continue to increase in importance. Look, we're excited -- we'll have I don't want to get -- 5 days from now the whole schedule will be out. We couldn't be more excited by it. Dana and Gary obviously bring an incredible track record to the business the they've proven themselves over a decade plus at the studio side, and I think we really will have some exciting things to talk about on Monday and I'll let them sort of address them.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Will come from Tim Nollen with Macquarie.
componenttext: Will come from Tim Nollen with Macquarie.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig in a little bit into your international network. A lot of the questions here have been focused a bit more on the U.S. side. But understanding the cricket investments that you've made recently and how that's gone for you, could you possibly
componenttext: I wanted to dig in a little bit into your international network. A lot of the questions here have been focused a bit more on the U.S. side. But understanding the cricket investments that you've made recently and how that's gone for you, could you possibly breakout between STAR and FIC kind of what proportion of your incremental costs are on sports versus nonsports program? I guess what I'm getting at is, other than knowing that the Cricket World Cup the big sporting events have been major focus is for you, what more is to be done on general entertainment programming? And how should we think about the cost pace of your investments in international networks of their? Please.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the international side, clearly the ramp up in costs and those channels have been in sports. And it's actually true both at FIC and STAR but most notably, at STAR. As Chase said, as we look forward in India in particular. There will be more cricket inv
componenttext: On the international side, clearly the ramp up in costs and those channels have been in sports. And it's actually true both at FIC and STAR but most notably, at STAR. As Chase said, as we look forward in India in particular. There will be more cricket investment as the BCCI determines its tournaments. But we'll continue -- I don't think the expectation in India on the entertainment side to be a massive or very significant increase in the programming investment on the entertainment side. But FIC, we continue the strategy of investing in those networks. So FIC will continue to see programming increases on the entertainment side.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's James here. I think this road in terms of how those investments have gone, I think over the last little while is we really bad that in the acquisition of the sports networks, the ESPN share and India STAR Sports as well as the Pan American Sports bus
componenttext: It's James here. I think this road in terms of how those investments have gone, I think over the last little while is we really bad that in the acquisition of the sports networks, the ESPN share and India STAR Sports as well as the Pan American Sports business in South America, it's really added a new dimension to all of the international channels businesses, including FIC and START. And it's done well. And even though the investment in cricket for example has been very heavy, the results have been tremendous and we've seen record viewership. We saw an incredible from an audience perspective some really incredible results and that's particularly in India of over 600 million viewers for the World Cup. And also that's a real platform to build new sports off of as well. So in the last year, investment not just in Cricket but in the body, in domestic professional football, soccer in India and the investment in sports across Asia and Latin America has been very, very effective both with our affiliates but also at advertisers and most importantly, for customers.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: It sounds like by talking to previous comment you made that you're very happy with the state of progress for your national network, STAR and FIC both with heavy sports costs, I don't want to say done, but a lot of that being done in the last year or 2. Is
componenttext: It sounds like by talking to previous comment you made that you're very happy with the state of progress for your national network, STAR and FIC both with heavy sports costs, I don't want to say done, but a lot of that being done in the last year or 2. Is it safe to say it's a smoother investment process from here?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think as you look at it over the next couple of years, you see the ramp-up kind of normalize and we'll see, in particular where we have a real investment a loss on the sports business in India that normalizes. You really start to expose the underlying p
componenttext: I think as you look at it over the next couple of years, you see the ramp-up kind of normalize and we'll see, in particular where we have a real investment a loss on the sports business in India that normalizes. You really start to expose the underlying profitability of the entertainment business, and that's really what drives the sort of double benefit as that goes towards much greater profitability. The other regions are less pronounced with respect to that shift.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean I guess I'd also say because when you talk about sort of touched business that's maturing and the reverse is true. I mean if you go to a place like Asia in general, if you go to India in many ways, sports is giving us an ability to play a bigger ro
componenttext: I mean I guess I'd also say because when you talk about sort of touched business that's maturing and the reverse is true. I mean if you go to a place like Asia in general, if you go to India in many ways, sports is giving us an ability to play a bigger role in shaping the whole market place. And so the digitalization is defining the packages, how you sell, how you various content is offered and paid for by consumers, is all still being billed. I mean across Asia, in many ways the next generation growth is coming onto these over the top digital platforms. And in some places like Japan sort of cable I mean cable mature at sort of 20% to 25% penetration in all the energy now is coming in various subscription digital platforms. So these are businesses. So yes, I think we've got a good handle on it. But you need to understand, these are in many of these places these are businesses that are still very much in early stage growth forms and a lot of the business models and rules and practices are all still being developed. And again, one of the value adding key content like sports is it gives us a unique role if these things are being developed and the prepared comments, I think those things you want to make sure you're strong as those markets take shape and form and new evolve.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're going to the line of Michael Morris with Guggenheim.
componenttext: We're going to the line of Michael Morris with Guggenheim.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions about domestic sports. One of the questions we get is about there being such an increase in inventory lately and that the demand is not there to match it on the advertising side. So would you be willing to share in the past quarter w
componenttext: A couple of questions about domestic sports. One of the questions we get is about there being such an increase in inventory lately and that the demand is not there to match it on the advertising side. So would you be willing to share in the past quarter what the advertising broadcasting at cable what the growth look like for your sports products versus general entertainment? And then as we look into '16, I know that you're not giving guidance or changing the guidance. But generally speaking, when you think about the operating profit outlook at the Cable Networks, how much of that do you expect to come from your sports businesses versus the other businesses?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Outlook, [indiscernible] for the quarter.
componenttext: Outlook, [indiscernible] for the quarter.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess sports general, I mean it includes the RSNs. And certainly FS1 is pretty much on track for us. I don't know that we have a percentage, I don't give up percentage, I don't think we break it down like that. But certainly, a significant part of the o
componenttext: I guess sports general, I mean it includes the RSNs. And certainly FS1 is pretty much on track for us. I don't know that we have a percentage, I don't give up percentage, I don't think we break it down like that. But certainly, a significant part of the overall Cable Network. I think in terms of advertising, sports in general, and again, it's not one-size-fits-all, we have an array of sports and right now we're selling golf in the World Cup and it's probably exceeding our expectations. One of the benefits about sports is clearly some of the things that exist on scripted entertainment in terms of being able to most people don't watch live sports 3 days later. So some of the -- and to some degree, there aren't a lot of substitutions. If you want the Women's World Cup our debt U.S. Open, then there isn't really a second choice that's going to satisfy you if you don't watch that. So I think those attributes have stood the test of time pretty well. I don't actually -- I'm not sure there's obviously been some expansion in the NFL adding Thursday night. I'm not sure I guess going beyond that, trying to think what would be the real expansion in sports inventory in the marketplace.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Other than news sports channels, selling events the reason we invest in premium events that deliver those unique mass audiences is because they continue to maintain their premium pricing.
componenttext: Other than news sports channels, selling events the reason we invest in premium events that deliver those unique mass audiences is because they continue to maintain their premium pricing.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean we have more sports inventory but to some degree, it's not new inventory. I mean the U.S. Open was in the marketplace. So we may be selling more inventory, but I don't think that from a marketplace perspective it's looking at it the same way and I
componenttext: I mean we have more sports inventory but to some degree, it's not new inventory. I mean the U.S. Open was in the marketplace. So we may be selling more inventory, but I don't think that from a marketplace perspective it's looking at it the same way and I think sports continues to distinguish itself pretty well. Different sports are in different, not one-size-fits-all fares, obviously, the different story is around different sports.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Michael, this is John. Just in the quarter, realize the comp of the Super Bowl out of this. But from a broadcast side, advertising was healthy in sports. There wasn't any dramatic trend one way or the other. And then on the regionals, as you probably
componenttext: And Michael, this is John. Just in the quarter, realize the comp of the Super Bowl out of this. But from a broadcast side, advertising was healthy in sports. There wasn't any dramatic trend one way or the other. And then on the regionals, as you probably know, such a substantial amount of that business is affiliate fee driven advertising, doesn't really move the needle one way or the other on it.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rating although ratings have been great realistically both the NBA and the NHL and for all probably exceeded our targets and MLB is off to with both our national and regional MLB product, again, a lot of games that's not true for all. But in general, it's
componenttext: Rating although ratings have been great realistically both the NBA and the NHL and for all probably exceeded our targets and MLB is off to with both our national and regional MLB product, again, a lot of games that's not true for all. But in general, it's off to a great start.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So overall, I would characterize the sports market for us in the quarter as pretty good.
componenttext: So overall, I would characterize the sports market for us in the quarter as pretty good.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That will come from Anthony DiClemente with Nomura.
componenttext: That will come from Anthony DiClemente with Nomura.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 2. Talking about moving to over-the-top for the RSNs, I'm just wondering, the right structures seem to change a bit with the leaks. I'm thinking of MLB for in market streaming rights. And I just wanted to ask about that. I think there's been some t
componenttext: I have 2. Talking about moving to over-the-top for the RSNs, I'm just wondering, the right structures seem to change a bit with the leaks. I'm thinking of MLB for in market streaming rights. And I just wanted to ask about that. I think there's been some tension between Fox Sports and MLB in terms of getting MLB games streamed in market. And I think you guys would prefer to authenticate those games. And I think if I have it right, they prefer to keep them open and eliminate the authentication. So just wondering if you could talk a little bit about that and give us a sense for what you're thinking about the value of those rights? And then just kind of along that theme, you guys have a number of valuable and growing streaming digital properties inside the company. I mean just as many of your big cat media peers do. I'm referring to FOX NOW, Fox Sports Go, FX Now, or any of those streaming apps gaining critical mass where it might make sense for you guys to give us more disclosure around users, growth in users, hours watched, things like that, things that might be helpful to us in order to maybe highlight the value of the viewership or just value of those businesses as they sit inside of the corporation?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the rights issues, I don't think there's as much tension as you apply obviously there are issues in every sports we do business with, there are always issues, it work through. Clearly, we'd like to resolve, we'd like to expand the offering we have in t
componenttext: On the rights issues, I don't think there's as much tension as you apply obviously there are issues in every sports we do business with, there are always issues, it work through. Clearly, we'd like to resolve, we'd like to expand the offering we have in the marketplace to provide really the experience consumers want. We're engaged with baseball. We hope -- we believe we will -- and I don't think we don't have a dramatically different views as our plans as you imply, I'm not going to get too deep into it, I just say we're actively engaged and I think we're confident we're in baseball. We will get to a place that works for both of us and enables us to bring to consumers the experience they want. And but it's -- sometimes these things take time. But we are working on it.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on your second question just about disclosure around on these digital assets and performance metrics there, I think some of it kind of goes back to some questions that we addressed earlier on in this call around currency, around what metrics and measu
componenttext: And on your second question just about disclosure around on these digital assets and performance metrics there, I think some of it kind of goes back to some questions that we addressed earlier on in this call around currency, around what metrics and measurements are going to be important and are going to emerge not just for us but for the industry. I do think we see very, very encouraging audience growth on the digital side of the business both in terms of authenticated streaming apps like you mentioned fox.com, FOX NOW, FX Now and so on. And also joint venture with Disney and Comcast, Hulu is really experiencing some great growth and really monetizing high-quality video views in new extended we think is very, very encouraging. So I think we will get to a place probably pretty soon where we will want to talk more regularly about some of those metrics, but the definition of those metrics between what advertisers care about, what we care what, but the ad products are and how we measure and report streams, hours, unique viewers, et cetera are all things that we're kind of knotting through right now.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go to the line of David Miller with Topeka Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go to the line of David Miller with Topeka Capital Markets.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the Big Ten network. I think this is a really special asset and I'm a little surprised you guys never call it out. I mean it really equates to kind of a Panamerican national RSN just given all the Big Ten alumni that are out there. So w
componenttext: Just a question on the Big Ten network. I think this is a really special asset and I'm a little surprised you guys never call it out. I mean it really equates to kind of a Panamerican national RSN just given all the Big Ten alumni that are out there. So would you be willing to just kind of talk of any statistics you might be willing to share on the call in terms of what the addressable market is for big Ten alumni that are out there? And what the penetration rate of the network has been thus far?  My understanding is it's been a huge success with Big Ten alumni but I'm just wondering what the penetration rate has been thus far and are you getting pricing power from the MVPDs?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, you're right, we don't think will disclose facts in any individual network, it's been great, we love the Big Ten. And it's been a great relationship on the business. It's been a great success, probably our most recent efforts and to some degree
componenttext: Certainly, you're right, we don't think will disclose facts in any individual network, it's been great, we love the Big Ten. And it's been a great relationship on the business. It's been a great success, probably our most recent efforts and to some degree, the Big Ten is always sort of had 2 footprints, it's sort of the in market geographies that where the schools are and then the wider universe that exists, consumers in Florida and Arizona are obviously outside the Big Ten markets. I think we distribution has been great. I we've achieved every goal we set out for. Our most recent initiative was to expand it Northeast with and Maryland coming on, essentially hit or exceeded every target we had for so widening out that what I call the in market footprint for the Big Ten. We think it would continue to be great upside. The Big Ten continues to distinguish itself, look how you Ohio state, you look at March Madness, the strength in the history of those schools is just second to none and we think that is truly a unique conference with unique institutions and continues to have great upside, it continues to be an exciting growth business for us. And so certainly the lack of talking about it is not in any way, shape or form due to the lack of enthusiasm, excitement or success we have. And in many ways, it's a business that I think is a long, long way to go. I think the management has done a fabulous job, the ratings they get on some of the games are just incredible I mean they've got sometimes the earning of the third pick in the market and they're beating better games distributed on a wider basis and have found some really revolutionary and creative ways to produce cost-effectively the wide array of sports that are associated with it, develop a real following amongst some of the owner talent and shows that produce to support those shows. So they've done great, we couldn't be realistically couldn't feel more excited about it.
