headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Twenty-First Century Fox Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.Now I'd like to turn the conference over to our ho
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Twenty-First Century Fox Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Release. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
Now I'd like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; James Murdoch, Co-chief Operating Officer; and John Nallen, ou
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Chase Carey, President and Chief Operating Officer; James Murdoch, Co-chief Operating Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer.
First, we'll give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, and then we'll be happy to take questions from the investment community. 
This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to Twenty-First Century Fox's business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended March 31, 2015 identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ, and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filings.
Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing.
Finally, please note that certain financial measures used in this call such as segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release.
And with that, I'm pleased to turn it over to John.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Reed. Before we get into the specific earnings commentary, just a reminder that because of the sale of our DBS businesses to Sky this past November, our reported financial results for the third quarter this year do not include the consolidation of
componenttext:
Thanks, Reed. Before we get into the specific earnings commentary, just a reminder that because of the sale of our DBS businesses to Sky this past November, our reported financial results for the third quarter this year do not include the consolidation of these DBS businesses as compared to a full quarter consolidation a year ago. So similar to last quarter, to provide a more meaningful comparative analysis, we are providing total company adjusted revenue and adjusted EBITDA, which excludes the DBS businesses in all periods.
Now turning to the quarter results. Third quarter total company revenues were $6.8 billion, up $84 million compared to the year-ago adjusted result, reflecting double-digit increases at our Cable Networks segment and mid-single-digit increases at Film. This growth was mostly offset by lower Television segment revenues, where the prior-year results included approximately $350 million in revenues from the broadcast of the Super Bowl.
Total segment EBITDA for the third quarter was $1.68 billion, a 3% reduction versus the adjusted EBITDA from a year ago of $1.73 billion. This year's result reflects continued strong underlying Cable Network segment contributions and higher Film segment contributions. These increases were more than offset by reduced Television segment results, reflecting last year's Super Bowl broadcast as well as this year's impact of the investments in our new sports channels in India. Additionally, this quarter reflected the most unfavorable year-on-year comparisons so far of foreign exchange rates, and as a result, our overall total EBITDA growth rate was reduced by approximately 7 percentage points in the quarter.
From a bottom-line perspective, on a GAAP basis, we reported income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $990 million as compared to the $1.07 billion we reported a year ago. Equity earnings were $160 million higher than a year ago, primarily reflecting this year's inclusion of our share of Sky's gain on the sale of Sky Bet. Excluding the net income effects of Other, net as well as certain adjustments to equity earnings, including eliminating the gain on the Sky Bet sale and eliminating last year's gain from participating in Sky share repurchase program, third quarter adjusted earnings per share were $0.42 this year versus $0.47 in the prior year.
Now let me provide some comments on the performance at our businesses. Let's start with the Cable Networks, where our total segment revenues increased 14% from last year, highlighted by a 15% increase in affiliate revenues and 9% advertising revenue growth.
With respect to affiliate revenues, domestic affiliate fees increased 20%, primarily from higher average rates led by the RSNs, FX and FOX News as well as increases from the conversion of our new channels, FS1 and FXX. The inclusion of the YES Network for the full quarter this year also contributed to our growth. Excluding the contribution from YES, we had a mid-teens domestic affiliate fee increase.
Our reported international affiliate fees were up 2%, reflecting an underlying mid-teens local currency growth rate, which was mostly offset by unfavorable foreign exchange movements, particularly in Latin America and in Europe.
The 9% total cable ad revenue growth from the quarter was led by our international channels, where reported international advertising grew 24%, reflecting 29% growth on a local currency basis. This growth was primarily driven by increases at STAR from this year's broadcast of the ICC World Cup.
The third quarter domestic advertising revenues were at similar levels to a year ago, with increases of the sports networks, FOX News and FXX, essentially being offset by lower ad revenues at FX and the National Geographic Channel due to lower ratings.
Total Cable segment EBITDA in the third quarter of $1.23 billion was up 5% over the prior year, reflecting the solid revenue growth, which was partially offset by a planned 19% increase in expenses, primarily related to higher sports rights and entertainment programming costs. Around 60% of the increase in expenses came from STAR Sports, most notably, the cost of the Cricket World Cup rights. The negative comparative effect from the strengthening U.S. dollar impacted the segment growth rate by around 5%. EBITDA at our domestic cable channels increased 21% from higher contributions at FOX News and from our sports channels, including the impact of consolidating the YES Network for the full quarter. This EBITDA growth was partially offset by lower contributions from the FX Networks due to increased programming costs.
At the international channels, despite local currency growth at FIC, our reported international channel EBITDA contributions declined 60%, driven by both the sizable planned cricket investment we made at STAR Sports as well as the overall negative impact from foreign exchange rates, especially from Latin America.
At our Television segment, third quarter EBITDA was $141 million, roughly half the contribution generated in the third quarter a year ago. This decline principally reflects the absence of the revenue and earnings from the Super Bowl broadcast in the prior year as well as higher entertainment programming costs this year from a higher volume of original series, including Glee and Empire. Excluding last year's Super Bowl, segment revenues were consistent with the year-ago quarter, as strong retransmission consent revenue growth was offset by a 7% decline in ad revenues due to lower general entertainment ratings at the broadcast network.
Turning to our Film segment. We reported third quarter EBITDA of $382 million, an 8% increase over year-ago results as higher film studio contributions more than offset lower Television production results and the unfavorable impacts of foreign currency. Total segment revenues in the quarter increased $110 million or 5%, driven by several successful theatrical releases, including King's Men and Taken 3 as well as home entertainment revenues from Rio 2 and The Fault in Our Stars.
The reduced contributions from Television production are largely due to lower SVOD revenues this year reflecting last year's multi-series sale to Amazon, which included 24 and The Americans.
Now before I turn to guidance, let me make a couple of capital-related comments. We ended the quarter with $9.3 billion in cash and $19.1 billion in gross debt. These balances reflect strong cash generation from operating activities in the quarter alone of approximately $1.8 billion and share repurchases in the quarter of $2.1 billion.
Subsequent to the quarter, we've continued to actively repurchase shares. From July 1 through today, we've repurchased approximately $5.25 billion of FOXA shares and we have approximately $1.25 billion remaining on our current authorization. So we're on plan to complete the $6 billion buyback within the 12-month timeframe that we previously announced.
Now let me address our guidance update for fiscal 2015. And as a reminder, for guidance purposes, we are excluding the DBS businesses for the entirety of all periods, resulting in a base EBITDA for fiscal 2014 of $6.29 billion.
On our last quarters earnings call, we indicated that the strengthening dollar would have an adverse impact on our EBITDA growth for the year based on exchange rates at that time. Since that call, the dollar, on average, has continued to strengthen, although in recent days, it's begun to weaken against certain currencies. So this volatility makes it difficult to forecast with precision the impact on our results, but we estimate that foreign exchange rates could have up to an incremental 1 percentage point negative impact on our growth rate. Absent this potential impact, we are maintaining our guidance for our total segment EBITDA percentage growth rate for fiscal 2015 to be at the lower end of the mid-single-digit range above the $6.29 billion total segment EBITDA base level for fiscal 2014.
With that, let me turn it over to Chase.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Our results continue to be driven by competitive strength at our Cable Networks, strong affiliate fee growth and leadership in our content businesses, while we face headwinds due to both foreign currency and the turnaround efforts at our Bro
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Our results continue to be driven by competitive strength at our Cable Networks, strong affiliate fee growth and leadership in our content businesses, while we face headwinds due to both foreign currency and the turnaround efforts at our Broadcast business. Our third quarter results were further impacted by the absence of the Super Bowl this year and significant investments at STAR Sports in India, particularly the Cricket World Cup.
We will address our guidance for the next fiscal year on our year-end call in August. Therefore, I want to use the next few minutes address some specific issues.
As I noted a minute ago, we continue to have strong underlying growth at our cable channels driven by higher affiliate fees. We also continue to close agreements that meet or exceed our expectations for new and existing agreements. At the same time, there's increasing noise in the market about new over-the-top offers, skinny bundles and other new options for consumers to access content. It is important to provide a bit of insight when considering these issues.
First, we believe the current pay TV ecosystem is strong and the consumers continue to value choice and breadth in content. While we're seeing a small decline in pay TV subs, we believe the vast majority of customers will continue to want a bundle of channels that is priced appropriately as opposed to a limited number of premium-priced channels.
Second, our existing carriage agreements are carefully constructed, not only provide us with a fair value for our content, but also specify the terms in which our channels are packaged and distributed. Many agreements provide limited flexibility for customer retention or experimentation with alternative packages. Any plans to distribute our package or channels in other ways would require a significantly different pricing structure. Even with this, we do expect there'd be more choices for consumers. This means more competition for our content. It also provides us opportunities to expand our business by providing consumers a better experience and connecting with customers we may not reach today. Not everyone will benefit from these changes. We continue to believe that content will be the ultimate beneficiary of the growth of digital platforms and, that within the content world, those with must-have brands and content at scale will be the true winners. As both existing MVPDs and new entrants try to construct new consumer offers, those with broad-hit content and unique brands will be best positioned to come out on top. We believe we're uniquely positioned to be such a winner.
In the U.S. and, increasingly, internationally, we built our business around 5 key brands: Fox Sports, FOX News, FX, National Geographic and FOX, each of which is a market leader with unique strengths. At FOX Sports, we've locked up key local national and international rights well into the next decade. Our regional sports networks add a critical dimension to our sports business that truly distinguishes us. The sheer popularity of the RSNs have made that business a pillar of strength second to none for us. We've used our scale, experience and broad affiliate agreements to enable us to continue to grow these businesses.
FOX News and FX have also established themselves as true industry leaders. FOX News is as dominant as ever, beating CNN, MSNBC and HLN combined in prime-time viewers. At the FX Network, the quality, breadth and distinctiveness in the programming really make it a premium channel residing in the basic cable space. Additionally, our FXX channel has essentially doubled its viewership from a year ago. National Geographic is one of the most recognized brands in the world. And while the channel is still a work in progress, we believe we haven't come close to tapping its true potential.
The FOX Network is clearly on a turnaround in the entertainment side. Nonetheless, it continues to be a driving force with enormous upside. The sports side of the network has been further strengthened this year by adding the FIFA World Cup and U.S. Open Golf to our portfolio of NFL, MLB and NASCAR events.
On the entertainment side, this season's Gotham and, more recently, Empire, give us momentum as we head into next week's upfront and Dana Walden and Gary Newman have given the business a fresh energy and excitement. We are not the first broadcast network to fight through a turnaround and we're confident we are on our way.
The breadth and strength of our brands and content are also going to be critical as we navigate the changes to the advertising side of our business. Our product has never seen such demand. However, we don't yet have the ability to effectively monetize the growing viewership. We also need to realize the consumers in the digital world are not going to be captivate viewers that will sit through 16 minutes of ads an hour. Advertising will have to be more effective and engaging to justify a premium. We'll need to work more closely with advertisers to connect with consumers in ways they value and enjoy. 
Both the recent reorganization of our channels' ad sales group and our trueX acquisition are steps in this direction.
There will be short-term challenges such as those we're experiencing today in the advertising side of our business, which can create pressure as we work to develop new business models. However, for those that navigate this transition successfully, the media industry that emerges on the other side will be one with enormous growth potential and an incredibly exciting future. One of the keys to success will be the ability to be disciplined in the face of industry noise and to be willing to invest and build on positions of strength even in the face of uncertain times. This is a time to prioritize long-term gains over short-term pain. We need to resist the temptation to react the short-term disruptions that we can air long-term future. In many ways, it's a time to double down. 
We must also continue to invest aggressively in original content. Many have asked if the current level of original content adoption is sustainable. The obvious answer is that it is if we create the best content. We contend the winners in the content will be those with the management and infrastructure to maximize the value of that content. Our proven track record, management-bench strength, deep roster of talent relationships, unique library and worldwide set of leading industry network -- industry-leading networks will enable us to monetize content second to none.
We also need to control a much wider set of rights to the content we distribute. The days of slicing-and-dicing rights are over. In order to create the best consumer experience and maximize the value of our content and networks, we need to have the flexibility to come to the broadest set of rights. The best path to controlling own destiny is to create our own product. We will clearly continue to work with third parties, but the sweet spot is undoubtedly where we own and distribute our own content. Our leadership position in content gives us a big advantage in achieving that goal. 
In closing, we believe we are incredibly well-positioned and are confident that today's challenges represent real opportunities for the future. Thank you.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chase, last quarter you were fairly measured on the ad outlook for traditional medium. Now that we're further into the year, has your outlook changed at all? And is there any sense that some of the money that shifted over to digital may be coming back to
componenttext: Chase, last quarter you were fairly measured on the ad outlook for traditional medium. Now that we're further into the year, has your outlook changed at all? And is there any sense that some of the money that shifted over to digital may be coming back to TV due to some issues with ROI or reach?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say that there's a dramatic change. I mean, probably -- the ad market's probably were a little better in April. I mean, right now, you have the quiet that always exists, sort of before the upfront. So it's sort of heading into the upfront. It's
componenttext: I wouldn't say that there's a dramatic change. I mean, probably -- the ad market's probably were a little better in April. I mean, right now, you have the quiet that always exists, sort of before the upfront. So it's sort of heading into the upfront. It's tough to judge right now. But I think they are okay. I mean, clearly, we're going to a transition here. I mean, advertisers, without doubt, have more choices. They want more flexibility in some ways. You could say the upfront we're about to go into, while important, is probably a bit of an antiquated practice given where the world's heading. I think advertisers want more flexibility. I think, for us, I think it's increasingly important. That's why we restructured our group, that we really work with advertisers to figure out how do we create unique opportunities with unique messages that resonate. I think there's a degree more energy in it. But again, I think everybody's still trying to navigate this new space. There's no question everybody wants the attributes that are associated with the digital world. I think in some ways the promise is ahead of the reality. And I think some of that reality's got to get fleshed out and people have to understand. We have to do a better job of prioritizing, monetizing that viewership. I mean, we've taken steps. Certainly, it's become a not immaterial part of our business, but it's got to get -- we're in the middle of the first inning of what we need to do in terms of monetizing that ad inventory. We need to develop the capabilities to do it. But a lot of it's sort of prioritizing, focus and working with these advertisers to develop the right messages and the right communications for those advertisers.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That will come from the line of Jessica Reif Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: That will come from the line of Jessica Reif Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was actually thinking about that advertising question and how different the upfront will be this year. And I was just wondering, as an ad-on, if -- how are you guys approaching it, given -- I mean, there's obviously the measurement issues, but you also
componenttext: I was actually thinking about that advertising question and how different the upfront will be this year. And I was just wondering, as an ad-on, if -- how are you guys approaching it, given -- I mean, there's obviously the measurement issues, but you also -- what will the currency be? Do you think you'll be more cross-platform? How those programmatic plans were this year? And then since you restructured your ad division, do you think that most of deals will be across broadcasting cable?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think again, these changes usually are more incremental. I mean, people -- these are rights of the world's going to be. But people have to do business short-term, so I think the changes will be more incremental in nature. But clearly, we know that direc
componenttext: I think again, these changes usually are more incremental. I mean, people -- these are rights of the world's going to be. But people have to do business short-term, so I think the changes will be more incremental in nature. But clearly, we know that direction it's heading. I think all those things will be a bigger factor than they've been in the past, but it's going to take time. Again, you're sort of, in a lot of ways, we haven't developed a lot of the capabilities, not just measurement, but technology and other things to measure effectiveness, capabilities, delivered on the promise of it. We're better than we were, but it's still really early days. So I think all those things will be a part of it. Certainly, all the trends, you're talking currency, we need to clearly -- C3, we said before, isn't the answer and C7 isn't the answer. They're all directionally the answer of starting to measure the viewership outside the linear network. We've got a long, long way to go to really monetize every viewership in every shape and form we can to work clearly with the reorganization, to work with advertisers. And then to find ways, I think certainly, we will be much more looking across. I mean, the purpose of putting our ad sales together was to sell across our platforms. So -- and in many ways, if we're going to create unique relationships with advertisers, what we want to do is use the unique franchises we have across the breadth of them. That's how we create something that really takes advantage of our unique content and brands is to give an advertiser an ability to access customers across all our franchises and to develop then unique messages that resonate. Again, I think it's increasingly important we find ways to make advertising not an encumbrance to consumers, but sort of a value-added part of the experience. That's part of what trueX rings to us, is an ability to make the advertising experience one that is more valued. And part of the value just comes from making it more relevant. But all those are -- all those things have to be part of directionally where we're going. We're not going to get there in the next 2 months, but certainly, we expect to make steps. And in all honesty, we've made steps to date, but we have a long, long way to go.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think in cricket, actually, there -- we've got -- we're going to have our budget meetings. So I think the Indian leadership's in next week. So we'll see. The agreements are structured that some ways depends on what events are coming. So I'm actually
componenttext: And I think in cricket, actually, there -- we've got -- we're going to have our budget meetings. So I think the Indian leadership's in next week. So we'll see. The agreements are structured that some ways depends on what events are coming. So I'm actually not fluent. So we'll actually get a bit more visibility going forward next week on what they think is coming and where it's going because the -- unlike the U.S. or the NFL, you got 16 games. They schedule it sort of more determined on an ongoing basis for a lot of the events. I mean, the World Cup's planned, but the national team, country-on-country, and some of the other big events are sort of up all over time. So we'll get a better sense of that next week.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That will come from the line of Bryan Kraft with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: That will come from the line of Bryan Kraft with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just had 2 questions. Chase, I know you said you wanted to address the guidance on the next call, but you did talk about a mid-$7 billion target for EBITDA for fiscal '16 on your last call. I guess, I was just wondering what the confidence level is in sti
componenttext: Just had 2 questions. Chase, I know you said you wanted to address the guidance on the next call, but you did talk about a mid-$7 billion target for EBITDA for fiscal '16 on your last call. I guess, I was just wondering what the confidence level is in still achieving that kind of number for next year. And then I also had a follow-up question on advertising. What specifically are you seeing on scatter pricing right now? If you could talk about that. And do you see C7 as being the predominant currency? And does that even matter? Or do you end up just with lower pricing on C7 versus C3?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bryan, I guess in terms of the guidance, a we said, we really -- we do plan to address that at year-end. We're just beginning our budget reviews now. I mean, actually, the first budget meeting is later this week, so we haven't even had the first one. And
componenttext: Bryan, I guess in terms of the guidance, a we said, we really -- we do plan to address that at year-end. We're just beginning our budget reviews now. I mean, actually, the first budget meeting is later this week, so we haven't even had the first one. And as you get close to do it, we got to get a handle on -- there will be things that affect the budgets, such as the ongoing strength of the dollar, we'll have visibility to that; updated views on the ad markets, post the upfront specifics and our content release schedule; level of investments in content; all those things will come through. So I think we've historically -- which is why we give the guidance sort of at year end after we've gone through a budget process to get a handle on it. And I think that's probably where we're going to stick with it. Scatter market, I mean, the pricing's actually been pretty good. I mean, I think probably the volume probably is not quite as strong as the pricing. But pricing's actually -- in the scatter market's been pretty good. I think in terms of currency, I'm not going to predict C3 versus C7. I think probably -- the second part of your question, it's probably more relevant. I mean it matters, but at the end of the day, I think neither one's the answer. And there'd probably be some dynamics of pricing factored into what you put into it. What we need to do is make it a priority to monetize viewership, all the viewership that's occurring, which is why neither needed C3 nor C7 is the answer. To some degree, the product has to have -- really almost to be sold in a different way. It has to be sold in a premium basis. I mean, not just queuing up with what we're selling linearly. We need to -- [indiscernible] different world's going to have. It's going to have different ad loads and going to have different advertising ad [indiscernible] -- advertising messages with different capabilities that hopefully should be much more attractive. And in some degree, we have to move to figure out how do we get paid for the premium value of the advertising that can exist in the marketplace going forward. And a -- so things like C3 and C7 to me are small steps, but they're not the answer. I mean, yes, they're not irrelevant. So we do want to capture more of that viewership in the manner we can through at least reflecting the expanding viewership in all these digital platforms. But that's not the end goal. The end goal is to figure how do we get fairly compensated for the product that really is a product that everybody wants. I mean, at the end of the day, the product that consumers and advertisers all want to deal with is our product. We need the ability to -- we need to figure out a -- we need to build the capability to monetize the popularity of that viewership. And again, C7 is not an answer. It's a small step in the right direction. But just a small step.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Chase, at the Analyst Day, you set up 2 years of investing in cable networks followed by a period of strong margin expansion, and we're almost at the end of that 2 years of investment. And you went out of your way today to talk about investing to be ab
componenttext: So Chase, at the Analyst Day, you set up 2 years of investing in cable networks followed by a period of strong margin expansion, and we're almost at the end of that 2 years of investment. And you went out of your way today to talk about investing to be able to position of strength, time to double and down, expand the business by offering better experience in reaching customers you don't reach today. And I feel like to some extent, we're sort of dancing around the over-the-top strategy for the company. And what I'm wondering is, are you suggesting that investors brace for another investment cycle stacked on the end of this last one? And what do you think we should consider Fox's over-the-top strategy likely to be going forward? Any sense of cadence around this would be helpful.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't read more -- I mean, I think you're probably overreading things into it. I mean, I guess probably the investing comment is going -- and it's not solely speaking to this, probably is a comment, first and foremost, about the FOX Network. I mean,
componenttext: I wouldn't read more -- I mean, I think you're probably overreading things into it. I mean, I guess probably the investing comment is going -- and it's not solely speaking to this, probably is a comment, first and foremost, about the FOX Network. I mean, clearly, the FOX Network -- I mean you could -- we report the broadcast segment, so it's not a secret. The FOX Network is not where we think it should be and not where we planned for it to be. We think we've got some nice momentum with Empire and Gotham and a couple of things coming. We like the sports franchises we've added. We still look at FOX Network as a business that should be the shining light, that it's the top of the pyramid that drives our business forward. Clearly, it's not performed at such. It's taken -- its ratings declines in the last few years were not -- not that we planned on. We're excited about new management team. We made the changes to drive that business, and I think it's -- so I think certainly using that as the case in point probably is the most -- is probably the clearest case in point is, I think -- we think that's a great business. And we think we need to continue to have the backbone to invest to drive that business to what it can be as opposed to saying, how do we sort of hit a profit target in the next year for the FOX Network as opposed to investing to enable it to get to the right place 3 years from now. So I think it's probably talking more about that type of an investment. I think I guess, the only other comment I'd make is, in general -- and you go back to the Analyst Day, let's -- the world is fluid. I mean, I think you've -- you always got to be opportunistic. And you got to make judgments as you get to various places in time as what's the right decision, what's the competitive marketplace, what are the other industry dynamics that have occurred and how do you manage your business to build long-term value from what you know today. And certainly, today -- and I'm not -- we're just stating the facts, not -- it's not making any judgments about margins or anything else as opposed to -- today, clearly, there have been -- I think, there have been changes in the marketplace. Certainly, the impacts on ratings across Cable Networks have probably been larger than one would've expected a year ago, including me. I wouldn't have -- I think some of those shifts have been larger than would have anticipated. We saw the trends coming. And I think as the world evolves, you've got to adjust to it. And I think a lot of our businesses -- I mean, if you added things like investing in sports, and FS1's pretty much right on plan. The produced programming's still a work in progress. And we are bringing in new executive, we announced, in to be the point person for that. We knew creating programming takes time. Some of it's -- some of it's worked. Some of it hasn't. And we actually feel great about where it is and we're pretty much where we expect it to be. So I think in general, I think their business is clearly aren't where we expect it to be, the broadcast network. Obviously, the international channels have taken -- competitively are closer to where we are. They don't -- their financials aren't where we expected it to be because of the currency. But more broadly, I think we are continuing to adhere to things we talked about and -- but we're always going to -- I think we said it in the Analyst Day. I think you always want -- I think it's important that you continue to aggressively compete in the world, as you know more as the world evolves. I think in terms of over-the-top, I think that over-the-top is a very important part of our future. Now that being said, as I said in the prepared comments, we still think most consumers are going to want to bundle a programming. I don't think they want to buy Ã  la carte. They want to buy a bundle of programming. We think there'd be more people, more players offering bundles of programming. I think those bundles have to be ones that are concocted with the consumer in mind, not something that is artificially concocted by the content owner and a distributor that doesn't really make sense. The alignment of what that content is doesn't make sense to a consumer. So you have to figure out -- you're going to -- if these over-the-top players are going to be -- what are they bringing, in many ways -- certainly, bringing a better consumer experience. I think, in some ways, the Netflix and Hulus are sort of cases in point of a better -- the value of a better consumer experience. I mean -- and I think if you can go in the flip side and say the struggle with TV Everywhere have been an example of the challenge you have when you don't create the right consumer experience. So I think there can be over-the-top players that bring a new consumer experience that again, at its core, is still offering a bundle of programming, may not be exactly what's out there it's why -- and if you want to make sure you must-have content that has to be in that bundle if you're creating a bundle that really resonates with that consumer. And we do still think consumers want proactive choice, that we've got the content that will be a central part of any of those over-the-top bundles. But I think bringing -- obviously, the competition's good, but bringing a better -- bringing better experiences to the marketplace. If people can develop better user interfaces, that's a positive. And I mean, I always lauded DIRECTV when I was there. I mean, what -- one of the reasons DIRECTV I think competed successfully against the cable industry was it was better experience. And I think sort of easy-to-use and simplicity are probably some of the most underappreciated assets in the -- virtues in the business. Actually, we're excited about it. Look, we've got -- we, probably amongst may of our peers, have more firsthand experience in dealing directly -- we have businesses internationally that deal directly with consumers that create consumer interfaces and manage relationships with consumers. So we think over-the-top, for us specifically, is an interesting opportunity. We think working with third parties to create more competition and new experiences is an important opportunity. We also think there are customers that -- again, I think the predominant majority will want a bundle. I think there are consumers that probably are interested in alternatives. Everybody talks about the millennials. And I think the ability to create packages or offers that they speak to that generation is also an interesting opportunity. Obviously, we've -- they're consumers we don't reach today, and we want to be able to -- in an additive way, I think it's important -- everything we do is adding to the pie, not cannibalizing the pie, create offers that speak to customers that want something different. We think that'll be a relatively small minority, but it's important for us to do. And we look forward to developing all of that.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That will come from the line of David Bank with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: That will come from the line of David Bank with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chase, James, John, I think -- so look, Chase, I think, has been talking a fair amount this in a number of his comments that there has been focus on a lighter bundle. I think for us, particularly on the sort of very nascent OTT MVPD side, we're trying to
componenttext: Chase, James, John, I think -- so look, Chase, I think, has been talking a fair amount this in a number of his comments that there has been focus on a lighter bundle. I think for us, particularly on the sort of very nascent OTT MVPD side, we're trying to navigate this, and we don't have much to extrapolate from -- we have like basically -- Sling is kind of out there. Sony PlayStation Vue is out there. There's a lot of speculation around what might be on Apple. And FOX has a lot I think, of relatively kind of average-priced must-have programming, not outside the mean: the broadcast network O&Os, news, general entertainment, even national sports. But we don't really know where the RSNs fit in, and we don't have a lot of data to base them on, I guess outside of Sling and Sony; if you could talk about that. But how do you see the distribution landscape shaping up for the RSNs an OTT MVPD world? What's your confidence that the distribution model sustains itself?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I don't actually -- I mean, in all honesty, I don't think the -- I don't look at the RSNs really as -- I guess, they're geographically different. So they're different in that. Although, for us, I think our RSNs in aggregate cover 70% of the country.
componenttext: Look, I don't actually -- I mean, in all honesty, I don't think the -- I don't look at the RSNs really as -- I guess, they're geographically different. So they're different in that. Although, for us, I think our RSNs in aggregate cover 70% of the country. So in some ways, you could say the RSNs for us are a national business. I mean -- and I do think that strength in RSNs is a distinguishing feature for us against a lot of the other people. But I don't actually look at it [indiscernible] -- look, I think the RSNs represent great, must-have content. And I think that it is as important as any content that exists in a local market for a large segment of consumers. Obviously, any piece of content is relevant to everybody, but it is content second to none. It is -- and I think in some ways, I guess, we judge its importance when we -- as we engage with our distributors in the marketplace. And it has continued to be a critical part of our business. It continues a critical pillar of driving our business forward. Obviously, some others have stumbled in it. I think we've proven a capability, sort of the L.A. and Houston [indiscernible] points to, we've proven a capability that we know how to manage, we know how to navigate. I think our scale helps in this, and most of our agreements in place are long-term. I think over 80% of our agreements are into the 20s. I think we've -- and we know how to continue to renew them in terms that work. I think we've renewed about 20% of our team deals in the last couple of years. So it's a business that -- and again, we bring a lot of strength that would enable us to make these instances work, and that others, on a one-off basis obviously aren't -- our established relationships with MVPDs are all a part of that. So in many ways, I just -- I look at -- it is -- same way we'd look at the other channels, the other channels we have and being one of, if not, the most important drivers in the business. And we do just think again, that those array of channels are going to be our must-have content for consumers out there.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- it's James here. Just to add, David, it's -- I think it's consistent with the overall strategy for the last number of years in the business, which has been to concentrate meaningful investment in programming, be it entertainment, news, spo
componenttext: I think it's -- it's James here. Just to add, David, it's -- I think it's consistent with the overall strategy for the last number of years in the business, which has been to concentrate meaningful investment in programming, be it entertainment, news, sports or actual programming that is arranged around really big brands and distinctiveness that really matters. And I think we see the RSNs as sort of a separate category from that. It's really been in part and parcel of how we approach the marketplace, both in the United States and in other markets, as we've invested in sports around the place. And to Chase's point, the results of the RSNs and the results in our sports businesses around the world are validating that more as opposed to less.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think in some ways the noise around RSNs has really come off a couple of specifics. Look, I don't -- I think the -- single team RSN, I don't think they've been a great thing, and I think that's not really the business we built. And there are couple
componenttext: And I think in some ways the noise around RSNs has really come off a couple of specifics. Look, I don't -- I think the -- single team RSN, I don't think they've been a great thing, and I think that's not really the business we built. And there are couple of places where, I think the pricing -- and obviously, the places we passed on -- across the continent. So I think you do have to be disciplined to make judgments. So -- but I think if you manage it properly -- and again, I think the sort of 1-team RSNs are sort of a more limited phenomenon that have created broader noise. And I think in some degree positively, some of the events of the last year plus have been sobering for the business. And I don't think in many ways, helpful in terms of sobering some of the 1-team sort of open-ended euphoria.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: One-team and single-market, which is hard.
componenttext: One-team and single-market, which is hard.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go to the line of Michael Nathanson with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: We'll go to the line of Michael Nathanson with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have one for Chase. Let me focus this question on U.S. cable networks. If you look at cost growth as you predicted at your Investor Day, the past 2 years have been of your investment spending with double-digit cable cost growth. I wonder now you almost
componenttext: I have one for Chase. Let me focus this question on U.S. cable networks. If you look at cost growth as you predicted at your Investor Day, the past 2 years have been of your investment spending with double-digit cable cost growth. I wonder now you almost done with that investment cycle, what's the right way to think about cost growth domestically at cable going forward? Because in the past before the cycle started, you guys were mid to high single-digit expense growers. So that's I think one of the questions people want to get is, what's normalized spending, post the investment cycle?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think if you were -- I mean, I think if everything was ordinary course -- obviously, again, our broadcast network is not where we wanted to be. So -- but if you said the cable networks, I think probably back to that is probably sort of what you'd ex
componenttext: No, I think if you were -- I mean, I think if everything was ordinary course -- obviously, again, our broadcast network is not where we wanted to be. So -- but if you said the cable networks, I think probably back to that is probably sort of what you'd expect. And again, we've sort of had the ramp-up in sports and the ramp-up to take FX from 1 to 2 networks. But I think once you get past that, I think what you had before is sort of what it comes back to. And again, that's dependent on -- if there's new opportunities, obviously, they'll dictate new plans. But just in the world as defined as it is today, it all goes back to where it was.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And let me ask you about buybacks. Because I see if you go back and look at the $2 billion plus you spent this quarter, maybe the highest buyback quarter almost ever and back to previous News Corp, and given that you've $9 billion of cash in your bo
componenttext: Okay. And let me ask you about buybacks. Because I see if you go back and look at the $2 billion plus you spent this quarter, maybe the highest buyback quarter almost ever and back to previous News Corp, and given that you've $9 billion of cash in your books and you've accelerated to this quarter, what does that say about your goal for the next couple of years on buybacks? Is the $6 billion the right run rate? Or can we expect, with the stock prices and the cash generation that you'll start accelerating the rate of buyback?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, look -- I mean, we're not going to make predictive comments about it. I think we've said that we're going to continue to hear it. Pretty much, we'll address the next buyback when we get through this buyback. We'll address it with the board before obvi
componenttext: No, look -- I mean, we're not going to make predictive comments about it. I think we've said that we're going to continue to hear it. Pretty much, we'll address the next buyback when we get through this buyback. We'll address it with the board before obviously year-end, and we'll announce what we plan to do on that year-end call. But we're not going to ahead of the board. That's a cycle we're in and that's a cycle we're going to stick with.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015

componenttext: That'll be from Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you look at your hit shows like Empire or Gotham, can you give us some color on how much you think you can leverage those hits in the upfront in terms of getting better pricing across your lineup? And also, now that you have a better sense of what th
componenttext: When you look at your hit shows like Empire or Gotham, can you give us some color on how much you think you can leverage those hits in the upfront in terms of getting better pricing across your lineup? And also, now that you have a better sense of what the lineup is for next year, I guess any color on how we should expect program and expense in the broadcast network next year.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to put a number to them. Look, I guess what is clearly true in today's world is hits are more valuable than ever. Sort of second rate product is -- mediocre product is less valuable, and hits are more valuable than they've ever been. So when
componenttext: I'm not going to put a number to them. Look, I guess what is clearly true in today's world is hits are more valuable than ever. Sort of second rate product is -- mediocre product is less valuable, and hits are more valuable than they've ever been. So when you get a phenomenon like Empire, it's great. It obviously is a product that with all the platforms and all the abilities to access content wherever you want, it, many ways, becomes a must-have content for customers. So it's tremendously important. I'm not going to -- hits just continue to increase in importance. Look, we're excited -- I mean, we'll have this -- I'm not going to get -- 5 days from now, the whole schedule will be out. We're -- we couldn't be more excited by it. Dana and Gary obviously bring an incredible track record to the business. They've proven themselves over a decade plus, at the studio side. And I think we really will have some exciting things to talk about on Monday, and I'll let them sort of address them.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Will come from Tim Nollen with Macquarie.
componenttext: Will come from Tim Nollen with Macquarie.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig in a little bit into your international networks. A lot of the questions here have been focused a bit more on the U.S. side. But understanding the cricket investments that you've made recently and how that's gone for you, could you possibl
componenttext: I wanted to dig in a little bit into your international networks. A lot of the questions here have been focused a bit more on the U.S. side. But understanding the cricket investments that you've made recently and how that's gone for you, could you possibly breakout between STAR and FIC, kind of what proportion of your incremental costs are on sports versus non-sports program? I guess, what I'm getting at is, other than knowing that the Cricket World Cup and these other big sporting events have been major focuses for you, what more is to be done on general entertainment programming? And how should we think about the cost base of your investments in the international networks there, please?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the international side, clearly the ramp up in costs and those channels have been in sports. And it's actually true with both at FIC and STAR, but most notably, at STAR. As Chase said, as we look forward at -- in India in particular, there's -- there'l
componenttext: On the international side, clearly the ramp up in costs and those channels have been in sports. And it's actually true with both at FIC and STAR, but most notably, at STAR. As Chase said, as we look forward at -- in India in particular, there's -- there'll be more cricket investment as BCCI determines its tournaments. But we'll continue -- I don't think the expectation in India, on the entertainment side, should be a massive or a very significant increase in the programming investment on the entertainment side. But at FIC, we continue with strategy of investing in those networks. So FIC will continue to see programming increases on the entertainment side.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I just -- it's James here,  Tim. The -- I think as well -- just in terms of how those investments have gone, I think over the last little while as we've really added in the acquisition of the sports networks, the ESPN share and STAR India, ESPN Star S
componenttext: And I just -- it's James here,  Tim. The -- I think as well -- just in terms of how those investments have gone, I think over the last little while as we've really added in the acquisition of the sports networks, the ESPN share and STAR India, ESPN Star Sports as well as the Pan American Sports business in South America, it's really added a new dimension to all of the international channels businesses, including FIC and STAR, and has done well. And even though the investment in cricket, for example, has been very -- has been heavy, the results have been tremendous, and we've seen record viewership. We saw an incredible -- from an audience perspective, some really incredible results, and that's particularly in India, of over 600 million viewers for the World Cup. And also, that's a real platform to build new sports off of as well. So in the last year, investment, not just in Cricket, but in kabaddi, in domestic professional football -- I should say soccer, in India and the investment in sports across Asia and Latin America has been very, very effective, both with our affiliates, but also with advertisers and, most importantly, for customers.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. So sounds like from -- of also talking to previous comment you made that -- how you're very happy with the state of progress for your international network, STAR and FIC, both with heavy sports costs, I don't want to say done, but a lot of that bei
componenttext: Great. So sounds like from -- of also talking to previous comment you made that -- how you're very happy with the state of progress for your international network, STAR and FIC, both with heavy sports costs, I don't want to say done, but a lot of that being done in the last year or 2, is it safe to say it's a smoother investment process from here?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- I think the -- as you look at over the next couple of years, you'll see the ramp-up kind of normalize and we'll see -- in particular, where we have a real investment -- a loss on the sports business in India, as that normalizes, you really
componenttext: I think it's -- I think the -- as you look at over the next couple of years, you'll see the ramp-up kind of normalize and we'll see -- in particular, where we have a real investment -- a loss on the sports business in India, as that normalizes, you really start to expose the underlying profitability of the entertainment business, and that's really what drives the sort of double benefit as that goes towards much greater profitability. The other regions are less pronounced with respect to that shift.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, look -- I mean, I guess I'd also say, because when you talk about sort of -- I mean, it almost sounds like you're talking about a business that's maturing and the reverse is true. I mean, if you go to a place like -- I mean, Asia in general -
componenttext: Yes, I mean, look -- I mean, I guess I'd also say, because when you talk about sort of -- I mean, it almost sounds like you're talking about a business that's maturing and the reverse is true. I mean, if you go to a place like -- I mean, Asia in general -- so if you go to India, in many ways, what sports is giving us is an ability to play a bigger role in shaping the whole market place. And so the whole digitalization is defining of packages, how you sell, how you get paid, how various content is offered and paid for by consumers, is all still being built. I mean, across Asia, in many ways, the next generation of growth is coming onto these, I'll call them over-the-top digital platforms. And in some places like Japan, sort of, cable -- I mean, cable matured at sort of 20% to 25% penetration, and all the energy now is coming in various subscription digital platforms, so these are businesses. So yes, I think we have got a good handle on it, but I do -- there's more to need to understand. These are -- in many of these places, these are businesses that are still very much in early-stage growth forms, and a lot of the business models and rules and practices are all still being developed. And again, one of the value-adding key content like sports is it gives us a unique role, if these things are being developed. And as I said in the prepared comments, I think it's in those things -- you want to make sure you're strong as those markets take shape and form and new paths evolve.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're going to the line of Michael Morris with Guggenheim.
componenttext: We're going to the line of Michael Morris with Guggenheim.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions about domestic sports. One of the questions we get is about there being such an increase in inventory lately and that the demand's not there to match it on the advertising side. So would you be willing to share in the past quarter wh
componenttext: A couple of questions about domestic sports. One of the questions we get is about there being such an increase in inventory lately and that the demand's not there to match it on the advertising side. So would you be willing to share in the past quarter what the advertising at broadcast and at cable, what the growth look like for your sports products versus general entertainment? And then as we look into '16, I know that you're not giving guidance or changing the guidance, but generally speaking, when you think about the operating profit outlook at the Cable Networks, how much of that do you expect to come from your sports businesses versus the other businesses?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Outlook? Let me look for the quarter.
componenttext: Outlook? Let me look for the quarter.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sports, I mean, I guess, sports in general -- I mean is a -- obviously, because it includes the RSNs, and certainly, FS1 is pretty much on track for us. I don't know that I have a percentage. I know I don't give a percentage. I don't think we break it dow
componenttext: Sports, I mean, I guess, sports in general -- I mean is a -- obviously, because it includes the RSNs, and certainly, FS1 is pretty much on track for us. I don't know that I have a percentage. I know I don't give a percentage. I don't think we break it down like that. But certainly, a significant part of the overall cable space. I think in terms of advertising, sports, in general -- and again, it's not one-size-fits-all. We have an array of sports. I mean, right now we're selling golf and the World Cup, and it's probably exceeding our expectations. One of the benefits about sports is clearly some of the things that exist on scripted entertainment, in terms of being able to -- most people don't watch live sports 3 days later. So some of the -- and to some degree, there aren't a lot of substitutions. If you want to watch the Women's World Cup or the U.S. Open, then there isn't really a second choice that's going to satisfy you if you don't watch that. So I think those attributes have stood the test of time pretty well. I don't actually -- I'm not sure the -- there's obviously been some expansion in the NFL adding Thursday night. I'm not sure. I guess going beyond that, I'm trying to think what would be the real expansion in sports inventory in the marketplace.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, other than news sports channels, but I think [indiscernible] selling events -- the reason we invest in premium events that deliver those unique mass audiences is because we think they continue to maintain their premium pricing and there's a lot of
componenttext: I mean, other than news sports channels, but I think [indiscernible] selling events -- the reason we invest in premium events that deliver those unique mass audiences is because we think they continue to maintain their premium pricing and there's a lot of demand for them.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we have more sports inventory, but to some degree, it's not new inventory. I mean, the U.S. Open was in the marketplace. So we may be selling more inventory, but I don't think that from a marketplace perspective, you'd look at it in the same
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we have more sports inventory, but to some degree, it's not new inventory. I mean, the U.S. Open was in the marketplace. So we may be selling more inventory, but I don't think that from a marketplace perspective, you'd look at it in the same way. And I think sports continues to distinguish itself pretty well. Though different sports are in different -- not one-size-fits-all, obviously. There's different stories is around different sports.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Michael, this is John. Just in the quarter, realize we'll take the comp of the Super Bowl out of this. But from a broadcast side, advertising was healthy in sports. There wasn't any dramatic trend one way or the other. And then on the regionals, as yo
componenttext: And Michael, this is John. Just in the quarter, realize we'll take the comp of the Super Bowl out of this. But from a broadcast side, advertising was healthy in sports. There wasn't any dramatic trend one way or the other. And then on the regionals, as you probably know, such a substantial amount of that business is affiliate-fee driven. Advertising doesn't really move the needle one way or the other on it. So...

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually ratings -- I mean, although -- ratings have been great. I mean, realistically, both the NBA and the NHL overall, probably exceeded our targets. And MLB is off to -- both our national and regional MLB product -- again, you got a lot of teams, so i
componenttext: Actually ratings -- I mean, although -- ratings have been great. I mean, realistically, both the NBA and the NHL overall, probably exceeded our targets. And MLB is off to -- both our national and regional MLB product -- again, you got a lot of teams, so it's not true for all. But in general, it's off to a great start.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So overall, I would have characterized the sports market for us in the quarter as pretty good.
componenttext: Yes. So overall, I would have characterized the sports market for us in the quarter as pretty good.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That'll come from Anthony DiClemente with Nomura.
componenttext: That'll come from Anthony DiClemente with Nomura.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 2. Talking about moving to over-the-top for the RSNs, I'm just wondering, the right structures seem to change a bit with the leagues. I'm thinking of MLB for in-market streaming rights. And I just wanted to ask about that. I think there's been some
componenttext: I have 2. Talking about moving to over-the-top for the RSNs, I'm just wondering, the right structures seem to change a bit with the leagues. I'm thinking of MLB for in-market streaming rights. And I just wanted to ask about that. I think there's been some tension between Fox Sports and MLB in terms of getting MLB games streamed in-market. And I think you guys would prefer to authenticate those games. And I think if I have it right, they'd prefer to keep them open and eliminate the authentication wall. So just wondering if you could talk a little bit about that and give us a sense for what you're thinking about the value of those rights. And then just kind of along that theme, you guys have a number of valuable and growing streaming digital properties inside the company. I mean just as many of your big-cat media peers do. I'm referring to FOX NOW, Fox Sports GO, FXNOW. Are any of those streaming apps gaining critical mass, where it might make sense for you guys to give us more disclosure around users, growth in users, hours watched, things like that, things that might be helpful to us in order to maybe highlight the value of the viewership or just value of those businesses as they sit inside of the corporation?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the rights issues, we basically -- look, I don't think there's as much tension as you apply. Obviously, there are issues in every sports league we do business with. There are always issues we work through. Clearly, we'd like to resolve -- we'd like to
componenttext: On the rights issues, we basically -- look, I don't think there's as much tension as you apply. Obviously, there are issues in every sports league we do business with. There are always issues we work through. Clearly, we'd like to resolve -- we'd like to expand the offering we have in the marketplace to provide really the experience consumers want. We're engaged with baseball. We hope -- we believe we will -- and I don't think we're -- we don't have as dramatically different views as -- or plans as you imply. I'm not going to get too deep into it. I'd just say we're actively engaged, and I think we're confident. We have baseball. We'll get to a place that works for both of us and enables us to bring to consumers the experience they want. And -- but it's -- sometimes these things take time, but we are working on it.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on your second question, just about disclosure around -- on these digital assets and performance metrics there, I think some of it kind of goes back to some questions that we addressed earlier on in this call around currency, around what metrics and m
componenttext: And on your second question, just about disclosure around -- on these digital assets and performance metrics there, I think some of it kind of goes back to some questions that we addressed earlier on in this call around currency, around what metrics and measurements are going to be important and are going to emerge, not just for us, but for the industry. I do think we see very, very encouraging audience growth on the digital side of the business, both in terms of authenticated streaming apps like you mentioned fox.com, FOX NOW, FXNOW and so on. And also our joint venture with Disney and Comcast, Hulu is really experiencing some great growth and is really monetizing high-quality video views in new, extended windows that we think are very -- we think is very, very encouraging. So I think we will get to a place, probably pretty soon, where we will want to talk more regularly about some of those metrics. But the definition of those metrics between what advertisers care about, what we care what, but the ad products are and how we measure and report streams, hours, unique viewers, et cetera, are all things that we're kind of knotting through right now.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go to the line of David Miller with Topeka Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go to the line of David Miller with Topeka Capital Markets.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the Big Ten network. I think this is a really special asset, and I'm a little surprised you guys never call it out. I mean it really equates to kind of a Pan American national RSN, just given all the Big Ten alumni that are out there. S
componenttext: Just a question on the Big Ten network. I think this is a really special asset, and I'm a little surprised you guys never call it out. I mean it really equates to kind of a Pan American national RSN, just given all the Big Ten alumni that are out there. So would you be willing to just kind of talk of any statistics you might be willing to share on the call in terms of what the addressable market is for Big Ten alumni that are out there, and what the penetration rate of the network has been thus far?  My understanding is it's been a huge success with Big Ten alumni, but I'm just wondering what the penetration rate has been thus far. And are you getting pricing power from the MVPDs?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, May 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, certainly -- I mean, you're right. We don't mention it. I don't we'll disclose facts in any individual network. It's been great. I mean, we love the Big Ten. And it's been a great relationship on the business. It's been a great success, probabl
componenttext: Yes, look, certainly -- I mean, you're right. We don't mention it. I don't we'll disclose facts in any individual network. It's been great. I mean, we love the Big Ten. And it's been a great relationship on the business. It's been a great success, probably our most recent efforts. And in some degree, the Big Ten is always -- sort of had 2 footprints. It's sort of the in-market geographies of where the schools are and then the wider universe that exists. Consumers in Florida and Arizona are obviously outside the Big Ten markets. I think we -- the distribution has been great. I think we've achieved every goal we set out for. Our most recent initiative was to expand it Northeast. With Rutgers and Maryland coming on, we've essentially hit or exceeded every target we had for -- so widening out that, what I call the "in-market footprint" for the Big Ten. And we think to continue to be a great upside for -- the Big Ten continues to distinguish itself. If you look at Ohio State, you look at March Madness, the strength in the history of those schools is just second to none. And we think that is truly a unique conference with unique institutions, and it continues to have great upside. It continues to be an exciting growth business for us. And so certainly, the lack of talking about it is not, in any way, shape or form, due to the lack of enthusiasm, excitement or success we've had. And in many ways, it's a business that I think has a long, long way to go. I think the management's done a fabulous job. I mean, the ratings they get on some of the games are just incredible. I mean, they've got -- in a way, sometimes earning over the third pick in the market, and they're beating -- better games distributed on a wider basis, and have found some really revolutionary and creative ways to produce cost-effectively the wide array of sports that are associated with it, developed a real following amongst some of the owner talent and the shows they produce to support those shows. So they've done it great. We couldn't be -- realistically couldn't feel more excited about it.
