headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. So one for James. I think investors want to give you more credit for STAR in India, but every time it looks like profit growth is going to take off, there's something new to invest in, and it's all worked out with sports or regional network
componenttext: Two questions. So one for James. I think investors want to give you more credit for STAR in India, but every time it looks like profit growth is going to take off, there's something new to invest in, and it's all worked out with sports or regional networks or building out more channels. And I think that's been the story of the better part of 20 years. So just I think, James, as you look out over the next few years, is, essentially, the build-out of the platform in India done, and margin starts to grow along with revenue? Or is there potentially more to invest in India that we should make sure we think about our models? And I'll just ask a second one for John. I know -- I hate to rehash Ben's question, but I'm math challenged. So my take, Cable Networks at mid-teens, and minus $200 million on Film, and flat on TV, Other up a little bit, I get 7% growth, $6.95 billion. Is that mid-single digits in your mind, or am I just math challenged?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me jump on that one. I'm not about to fill in Excel spreadsheets for a lot of people. But there's a range that mid-single digits is in. And I think given the number of data points that we've given, which is, I mean, pretty significant, and reflect on
componenttext: Let me jump on that one. I'm not about to fill in Excel spreadsheets for a lot of people. But there's a range that mid-single digits is in. And I think given the number of data points that we've given, which is, I mean, pretty significant, and reflect on it, I think you can get to a range in mid-single that we are running the business toward.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Doug, thanks for your question about India. I think -- look, I think like it's a fair -- it's a good question. We are enthusiasts about the business there. I think I would say it's probably been -- I don't know if it's in 20 years or it's 15 years ago, we
componenttext: Doug, thanks for your question about India. I think -- look, I think like it's a fair -- it's a good question. We are enthusiasts about the business there. I think I would say it's probably been -- I don't know if it's in 20 years or it's 15 years ago, we started broadcasting in Hindi and created STAR Plus. And that really just put us on the pathway to turning around STAR TV overall and particularly creating something in India that can be profitable, and really lift our Asian business. Remember, before that, it was a big -- a heavy loss maker. So I think over the last 15 years, we were able to kind of organically invest in programming, organically invest in some new channels in certain areas and got to a pretty good place. Certainly, over the last 6 or 7 years, we've really dialed it up in terms of how we invest there and what we want to do. And you're right, listen, I mean, the regional language business is something that we thought was important for us. We did that in a combination of acquisitions with Asianet and, more recently, MATV; but also, organically, creating STAR Pravah, STAR Jalsha and so forth, some organic offshoots in regional languages. I think at this point, we're really seeing the scale of the sports investment, which is really a bigger organic investment than anything we've done there in the past peak. And we have good visibility around the revenue growth around the business and the amelioration of the rate of growth in the sports investment going forward. So I do think that when we look out in '17, '18 and beyond, you can see real operating leverage in terms of profits in the India business come through. Now that said, we are -- we're big believers in the marketplace. And if we saw opportunities there that can materially enhance the value of the business, we would have to be very thoughtful about them. But I think, from an organic investment point of view, outside of the digital investment in hotstar and really growing that, you're seeing a peak in the Television business given the scale of the sports investment we've made. And we don't see any new major sports rights in the very near-term horizon that would materially change that. We've successfully exited the CLT20 competition this year and launched the second season of Kabaddi, actually, at a very cost-effective rate, which is year-on-year up 45% in its early matches, so we think that's pretty good. So I think we're still very much on track to see $0.5 billion or so of EBITDA in India within the next sort of 3 years or so and a real velocity towards $1 billion of EBITDA shortly thereafter, around the end of the decade, at the beginning of the next one.

componenttext: James, you mentioned June being a big month for FS1. As you guys continue to build out FS1, do you think you want more sports rights? I mean, some investors wonder if you'd consider bidding on Thursday Night Football if and when it comes up. And then, John, if you just indulge up one more question about the guidance, can you talk about what's in the budget for Cable advertising? I know you talked about Television. What's embedded in Cable advertising that's in your fiscal '16 outlook?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. The -- thanks very much. The thing on sports rights, look, I think we're pretty -- as we've said before about Fox Sports 1, we're very clear and transparent around what we were investing in and the rights packages that we had acquired and that
componenttext: Yes, okay. The -- thanks very much. The thing on sports rights, look, I think we're pretty -- as we've said before about Fox Sports 1, we're very clear and transparent around what we were investing in and the rights packages that we had acquired and that we're pretty happy with them. So on Fox Sports 1, we don't see anything in the near term that is terribly material, that we need to go and do to achieve our plans. The portfolio is really coming through now, and we're starting to see the impact of the investments and deals that we've made over the last 18 months to 2 years as those things kind of roll through in Fox Sports 1. With respect to Thursday Night Football, first of all, without getting into idle speculation, but I would imagine that a lot of that would've -- would end up being in broadcast and not on Fox Sports 1, so it's a slightly different question. But it's very -- we've been a partner of the NFL for many, many years. We love the NFL products. We think our customers love football. We know they do. And it remains and continues to be a really unique offering for customers. And we're always interested in finding ways that make sense to enhance what we can do and to try to do more with really unique events, like the NFL. And I think we're seeing encouraging signs now in the summertime around the new NFL season in terms of pricing and advertising, and we remain very, very committed to the sport. So if there were opportunities that made sense, we would, of course, consider them.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Anthony, on the -- you picked the one metric, of course, that I didn't offer, but I will give it to you then. On advertising, we're expecting mid- to high-single digits coming out of the domestic portfolio. FS1 and FS2 were important there. As is Fox News
componenttext: Anthony, on the -- you picked the one metric, of course, that I didn't offer, but I will give it to you then. On advertising, we're expecting mid- to high-single digits coming out of the domestic portfolio. FS1 and FS2 were important there. As is Fox News, I mean, given what is turning in to be a big political year and, probably, a massive viewership coming in the next day to that network, that -- those will be drivers of our advertising gains. Internationally, we're probably in the mid-teens range, and STAR, particularly, will continue to be the growth driver behind that.

componenttext: I had one for James and Lachlan and another for John. James or Lachlan,  Sky, how do you see it fitting in with the strategic portfolio at this point? How do you think about the potential to spin it off at some point? Or would it make more sense to own more? You talked about not getting credit for it in your valuation. And then, John, I just wanted to ask you what's reflected in the guidance as far as currency exchange rates and hedges. In other words, is the guidance reflective of some combination of current spot rates and hedges that you've put in place? Or is it based on current spot rates at this point, with some cushion maybe from the hedges? I just wanted to get a little more color on that.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: 'Thanks very much, Bryan. It's James. On Sky, look, I think we've been pretty clear about this in the past, and I think I'll be consistent today. Obviously, we do get a little frustrated that the credit and the value doesn't necessarily flow through. Bu
componenttext:
'
Thanks very much, Bryan. It's James. On Sky, look, I think we've been pretty clear about this in the past, and I think I'll be consistent today. Obviously, we do get a little frustrated that the credit and the value doesn't necessarily flow through. But at the same time, we believe the business is a dynamic and growing business and an exciting one. We've been very focused on completing the transaction at last year, taking our consolidated assets at Sky Deutschland and Sky Italia and combining those with what was BSkyB, that is now Sky plc, and we think that's been very, very attractive for Sky and Sky shareholders and very, very attractive for us and our shareholders. And we're very focused on supporting the company in terms of completing that integration and really dialing up the velocity at which that business can operate and perform. And I think you saw their results last week, and that is all going reasonably well. So we like the business. We think it's a very strong business and one that has a huge amount of headroom for growth. That said, these unconsolidated assets are something that, a number of years ago, we set about to simplify. And we've done that in a variety of places around the world, with a number of assets that we've either divested of or acquired the balance of. But today, we have no immediate plans around that, and we're focused very much on supporting Sky in its growth. And we think that's creating a lot of value over the long term for us although, to your point, not necessarily realized in our stock price today.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Bryan, as you think about foreign exchange for us, your focus should be more on current spot rates. That's the way we generally price this. We do have a moderate, I'd describe it as, hedging program focused on 4 particular currencies: sterling, euro,
componenttext: And Bryan, as you think about foreign exchange for us, your focus should be more on current spot rates. That's the way we generally price this. We do have a moderate, I'd describe it as, hedging program focused on 4 particular currencies: sterling, euro, real and peso. But to be honest, we'd like to -- if foreign exchange rates change, we left enough room to capture the upside. But current rates is really the place that you should focus as far as analyzing where we'd be on foreign exchange.

componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Reed. And thank you, everyone, for being on the call today and taking the time. Lachlan and John and I just thought we'd like to leave you with a few quick points of -- a few comments of, really, reinforcement. First of all, we finished 2015
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Reed. And thank you, everyone, for being on the call today and taking the time. Lachlan and John and I just thought we'd like to leave you with a few quick points of -- a few comments of, really, reinforcement. First of all, we finished 2015 having achieved many of our goals and, we think, with a really good position for the future. And hopefully, we've been able to flesh a little bit of that out for you today. Secondly, the financial profile of the business is strong, and our approach to capital allocation has been and will be consistent. And thirdly, our focus is very much on execution. And our energy and our enterprise are being applied to this strategy of creative excellence, customer focus and also global scale. So all of us here are very alive to the opportunities, and we're super aligned and energized about what's before us. So I look forward to speaking to you all in the future, as we all do, and thank you very much for your time.

componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, welcome to the Twenty-First Century Fox first quarter 2016 earnings release conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I would now like to join the conferenc
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, welcome to the Twenty-First Century Fox first quarter 2016 earnings release conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to join the conference over to your host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Executive Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Greg. Hello everyone, and welcome to our fiscal 2016 earnings conference call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer.First, we
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Greg. Hello everyone, and welcome to our fiscal 2016 earnings conference call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer.
First, we'll give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, and we will be happy to take questions from the investment community.
This call may include certain forward-looking statements with respect to Twenty-First Century Fox's business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended September 30, 2015, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ, and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filings.
Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-K filing.  Finally, please note that certain financial measures used in this call such as the segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often be referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release.
And with that, I'm pleased to turn it over to Lachlan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Reed, and good morning, everyone, and good afternoon to those of you might be in different time zones. Please to join you today from Los Angeles to report our first fiscal quarter earnings.I'm going to take a few -- make a few comme
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Reed, and good morning, everyone, and good afternoon to those of you might be in different time zones. Please to join you today from Los Angeles to report our first fiscal quarter earnings.
I'm going to take a few -- make a few comments and turn the call over to John and James, who are both in London. We've made good progress this quarter. Our performance underscores the strength of our business and the durability of the growth strategies we have pursued over the last number of years and continued to do so.
But even with progress, we are all united in the view that this is a time of transformative change in our industry. It's the kind of change that demands equal measures that we are thinking and of calculated risk-taking. In this quarter, we've applied both to good effect.  And there are some essential points that must be considered. While demand for the type of high-quality storytelling, news and live sport that we produce continues to grow, our viewers are increasingly choosing when and how they experience our programming. Live viewing of television is contracting as a percentage of total viewing, especially in the younger demographics coveted by advertisers. The definition of ratings success has evolved from overnight ratings to 3-day and 7-day ratings to more accurately reflect how programming is being consumed and they will need to evolve further.
Take for example, the Season 2 Premiere of our breakout hit, Empire. It reached 12 million total viewers in Live Plus same day, a great number. But that figure more than doubled to 25 million when we look at 30-day multi platform viewing. We see similar lifts across our networks when we look at actual consumption across a spectrum of viewing when compared to the current Live Plus three-day industry-standard.  Using Nielson Online Live Plus 7-day ratings, the FOX Network is up a couple of percent year-over-year and excluding sports, we are up almost 10%, but tells also only half of the picture. 
Our FOX Networks average nonlinear audience has risen by about 1/3 year-over-year. It's a testament to the fact that premium broadcast content is in more demand than ever but also illustrates the need for the industry to move to modern ratings currency that reflects today's consumption of media in a way that is highly measurable and relevant to advertisers.
Driving part of this change is without a doubt, the emergence of over-the-top services, such as Hulu and Netflix. Another byproduct of these services is clearly the maturing of the traditional large cable bundle. But we see this trend as having less impact on FOX as a group, then perhaps, on others. That's because our key U.S. brands, FOX, Fox News, Fox Sports, National Geographic and the FX Suite, are in great demand, due in large part, to years of significant programming and marketing investment.  In fact, this quarter's results reflect increases in our aggregate number of U.S. domestic subscribers compared to a year ago of over 1%, with subscriber additions at our younger, less distributor channels more than offsetting the overall 1% to 2% declines impacting the overall industry.
And internationally, we also continue to see subscription growth, and are benefiting from demographic trends and pay Television gains in high-growth markets.
Overall, we feel exceptionally well-positioned with robust demand for our quality programming, leadership across entertainment, sports and news, and enhanced digital product focus and strong brands, and that we have made an focus of our investment. We look forward to continuing to make strides against our strategic plan to continue to return real value to our shareholders over the remainder of this fiscal period and beyond.
And with that, I'll now hand over to John and James in London for their comments and for questions.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lachlan. It's John, and good morning, everyone. Starting off, I'll remind you that because of the sale of our DBS businesses to Sky last November, our reported financial results for the first quarter are not like-for-like. So as we've done in the
componenttext:
Thanks, Lachlan. It's John, and good morning, everyone. Starting off, I'll remind you that because of the sale of our DBS businesses to Sky last November, our reported financial results for the first quarter are not like-for-like. So as we've done in the past, we're providing total company adjusted revenue and adjusted EBITDA, which excludes the DBS businesses in the prior year period.
Most of my comments that will follow will be on this adjusted basis.
So first quarter adjusted revenues decreased by $406 million to $6.1 billion as continued revenue growth in the Cable network segment, was more than offset by lower revenue in the Film segment. Note that the absence of Shine and overall adverse foreign currency movements, each negatively impacted quarterly revenues by approximately $200 million. Together, these approximate the total year-over-year quarterly revenue decline.
Total segment adjusted EBITDA for the first quarter was $1.54 billion, a $37 million decrease from a year ago. This decline reflects double-digit growth at the Cable Networks and Television segments, which were more than offset by lower contributions at the Film segment. This year's results include slightly more than a $100 million negative impact from unfavorable foreign currency movements. Absent this impact, our overall growth rate would be 5%.
From a bottom line perspective, we reported income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $678 million or $0.34 per share. Excluding the net income effects in both years of Other net and of equity earnings adjustments, primarily related to Sky's acquisitions and dispositions, first quarter adjusted EPS was $0.38 this year, down $0.01 from the comparable $0.39 a year ago. And overall, with this first quarter now completed, we're holding to the financial guidance expectations we provided to you on our last call.
And now let me provide with some additional comments on the performance at our operating segments for the first quarter. And let's start with the Cable Networks, where total segment EBITDA of $1.31 billion was up 26% on segment revenue growth of 7%. Domestic revenues increased 10% in the aggregate, led by affiliate fee growth of 11% and advertising increases of 4%. EBITDA at our domestic channels increased 19% over the prior year, reflecting these higher revenues in conjunction with total cost increases of only 4%, led by lower costs at the FX Channel.
First quarter reported international affiliate fee and ad revenues were both essentially even with last year. However, excluding the effects of foreign exchange, local currency affiliate fees and advertising revenues were each up around 10%.
Reported international channel EBITDA contributions increased over 50%, even after reflecting an approximate $60 million negative impact from foreign exchange. This recorded growth was largely due to lower sports programming costs at STAR Sports from the absence of last year's India England cricket series. 
Elsewhere, double-digit local currency EBITDA growth at the STAR entertainment channels and at the Fox International Channels, were essentially offset by the negative impact from foreign currency, principally from Latin America and from the euro.
Turning to our Television segment. First quarter EBITDA was $196 million, 13% higher than prior year results. This improvement largely reflects continued strong retransmission consent revenue growth and lower programming expenses at the FOX broadcast network and stations, which were partially offset by a 5% decline in segment advertising revenues. This advertising decline reflects the expected impact of 1 last week of the NFL due to a later regular-season start, which we get back in the third quarter and lower political ad revenues at the stations due to the midterm elections in the prior year.
At the Film segment, we reported first quarter EBITDA of $149 million, $309 million below last year. This decline is primarily driven by challenging comparisons to the prior year, which included significant contributions from the theatrical release of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes and the Home Entertainment release of Rio 2, compared to reduced theatrical contributions this year that included the underperformance of Fantastic Four.  This quarter was also impacted by the inclusion of significant pre-releasing costs in advance of these successful October theatrical release of The Martian. 
Our TV production contributions were also lower in the quarter, primarily due to lower Cable syndication revenues owing to last year's sale of How I Met Your Mother.
Overall, revenues for the Film segment decreased by 28%, with close to half of this decline reflecting both the absence of revenues from Shine which we merged with Endemol last December, and foreign currency movements.
Shifting over to our buyback activities, and since July 1 through today, we've repurchased approximately $2.1 billion of FOXA shares and that we are on plan to complete the authorized a $5 billion buyback within the 12 months time frame that we've previously announced. 
Subsequent to quarter end, we issued $1 billion and long-term debt, and we repaid at $200 million of maturities, with approximately $500 million of further maturities over the next year.
With regards to the financial guidance, as I said earlier, with 1 quarter under our belt, we're holding to the expectations we gave you 3 months ago. Specifically, we continue to anticipate a total company segment EBITDA percentage growth rate for fiscal 2016 to be in the mid-single-digit range above the $6.49 billion we reported from fiscal 2015, and that number excludes the impact of the DBS segment contributions.
Now foreign currency certainly do we can since our August call, and this volatility continues to be a risk to keep an eye on as the year goes forward. Our underlying business operating trends have generally been progressing as expected in the aggregate.
As you know, when Twenty-First Century FOX was formed in 2013, we provided our 3-year goals and our guidance, and have updated you on those in each of the years on that cycle. As we look to the end of the 3-year period, upon the completion of this fiscal year, I'd like to touch on our approach to financial guidance going forward.
Looking back to 3 years had ups and downs, led by currency impacts, which absorbed hundreds of millions of growth dollars and had structural changes to our portfolio of businesses. But through that period, we have been and we'll continue to be transparent and direct about the trends we are seeing and impact on our outlook. We are very confident in our ability to execute against the opportunities we have ahead to sustain long-term growth, but we don't want to chase the short-term targets through changes in our operating plan, merely because our currency rate changes, of movie release, of ships are underperformed, so we modify our approach to SVOD Licensing. It's not good for our management team and it's not good for our shareholders.  So beginning with fiscal 2017, we will modify our approach to financial guidance to eliminate our emphasis on a specific dollar annual earnings target. Instead, we'll provide you with quantitative and qualitative information on those key areas where we have good visibility and on the trends and initiatives in our businesses. We'll also provide insight into where we'll be focusing our resources to maximize opportunity through both organic innovation and through investment.  And of course, we'll also continue to provide details around our annual Capital Allocation Plan and our targets.
And now let me turn it to James.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, John, and thanks Lachlan. And good morning, everyone, and thank you all for joining us.As you heard from Lachlan and John, the investments we've been making in our core brands, in all our key markets are progressing and producing retur
componenttext:
Thanks very much, John, and thanks Lachlan. And good morning, everyone, and thank you all for joining us.
As you heard from Lachlan and John, the investments we've been making in our core brands, in all our key markets are progressing and producing returns, and we continue to push the pace of these initiatives as we see meaningful opportunity ahead of us.
On the short-term front, as you heard from John's review, we continue to make progress against the fiscal 2016 financial objectives. We expect strong growth in our core cable franchises, promising forward movement in our TV broadcast segment, offset by some currency headwinds and short-term performance in the film business, which as you know, we measure over a longer period, as results can be lumpy due to the timings and individual pictures' performance.
We also continue to execute on our key strategic priorities. Specifically, to create compelling and unique storytelling, to enhance the customer experience of our digital video brands, and to leverage our leadership position in developing markets where we see the greatest opportunities, particularly India and Latin America.  So we've seen good momentum in our domestic Cable portfolio, where our overall EBITDA growth is up 19% versus a year ago. This growth led by revenue gains, is a clear result of the investments we've made and the work the team has done and continue to do, to bolster the customer offerings of our core brands. It also reflects increases in our aggregate number of domestic subscribers compared to a year ago of over 1%.
Looking forward, as Lachlan noted, we anticipate that some of the conversations we're having with new streaming distribution services not yet to market will result in revenue that will augment the existing viewing alternatives. Now I'd like to update you on the progress we're making at a few of our key brands.
Our domestic Sports Business continued to deliver, and has increasingly become a critical component for distributors. In aggregate, our brands currently provide more than 25% of all sports viewing in the U.S., national and local combined. I noticed there have been some recent attention of the potential disruption from the digital the submission of sports. 
Last week, Yahoo! and the NFL announced that they had 33.6 million streams or 15.2 million unique views on their NFL web stream game. So in digital numbers are comparable basis for TV ratings, Yahoo! average 1.6 million U.S. viewers per minute, but at the same day, on average, 18 million viewers per minute were watching the NFL on FOX.
As FS1 is making real headway as well, and is on or above plan by pretty much all metrics. Over the past quarter, we strengthened our audience engagement, extending last spring' ssuccesses from the broadcast of the Women's World Cup and U.S. Gulf -- U.S. Open Golf with strong MLB regular and postseason events. Nationally, regular season baseball viewership on FBC and FS1 increased 16% and 22%, respectively, over last year's level. As a New Yorker and as broadcaster, I'm disappointed, of course, with the world series, finishing 5 games. But unfortunately, there's no changing that now. But even with pure games, this year's World Series averaged close to 15 million viewers, more than last year's full seven-game performance, and ranked as the best five-game average since 2009 -- on the Yankees, beat the Phillies in 6 games. 
Locally, our regional sports networks our commanding presence, as demonstrated by our regular season baseball telecast on VRSN, with 13 out of our 15 teams ranking at or near the top of local content ratings.  And this year's World Series champion, the Kansas City Royals, carried on FOX Sports Midwest, scored the highest regular-season local TV ratings of any RSN in 13 years. We look forward to welcoming them in all our RSN MLB teams back for spring training. What's clear from this, is that our sports brands are a fundamental differentiator for 21 CF, and they'll continue to deliver returns for years to come.
At the FX suite of channels, will continue to deliver exciting new originals to audiences everywhere. And in particular, the American Horror story franchise continues to be a ratings and critical phenomenon. They won 5 Emmy awards in September and more recently, its fifth installment, debuted as the second most-watched telecast in FX Networks' history in the key 18 to 49 demo. And the Premiere has reached more than 15 million total viewers to date across all platforms. 
The reception at Fargo is getting some form routing, is also very encouraging. And I encourage all of you to watch the show. It's really one of the best and most exciting pieces of storytelling on air anywhere.
We look forward to calendar 2016 as well, with some truly great new and returning shows, including Ryan Murphy's American Crime Story, The People Versus O.J. Simpson, and the Americans on FX and It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia on FXX. 
Fox News continues to go from strength to strength. The August GOP debate delivered a record of 24 million total viewers, making it the #1 highest-rated non-sports cable telecast of all time. This summer, Fox News was the number 1 on Channel across our basic cable for 5 consecutive weeks ago The Kelly File and Hannity, both reached ratings high this past quarter since debuting in their current time spots.
And the new FOX Business schedule is gaining momentum, and the channel is hosting another Republican debate on November 10. And we think it's really a great opportunity to showcase and differentiate FOX Business in terms of depth and quality and production.
Outside of the U.S., our channels have continued their growth trajectory. At STAR, the entertainment channels generated double-digit revenue and profit increases on the strength of original programming. STAR Sports Poker Buddy Season 2 continue the successful on strong ratings growth. And we expect the business to take like meaningful profit progress this year, in line with the goals we've discussed with you in the past.
The Fox International Channels, even with some regional economic headwinds, grew its unique paying subscribers by 13% over a year ago level, now approaching 300 million, while also delivering double-digit local currency revenue and profit growth.
More broadly, we're working hard to build on the strength of our brand portfolio. A few months ago, we announced the agreement to expand our successful joint venture with the National Geographic Society. Our plan is to form National Geographic partners, which combines the National Geographic Society's branded media asset, including one of the most recognized magazines in the road any substantial digital footprints with the National Geographic Channels, among the most widely distributed Television services globally, is an enormous opportunity for the company.
The new limited Run Series breakthrough, which brings to life scientific and technological discovery through some of the biggest names in film, including Ron Howard, Brian Grazer and Brett Ratner -- exemplifies the kind of storytelling that is unique to National Geographic. Combining all of these consumer-facing assets into one entity, would drive greater opportunities to leverage one of the world's most recognized and treasured brands, especially in a nonlinear world.  The integration planning and implementation is moving along, and we're on track to close the transaction in the next few weeks.
Turning to our U.S. Broadcast business. Trends this fall season are encouraging. While still early, we're seeing positive results driven by new programming and our investment in our returning shows. We're happy with the performance of Empire at second outing, the show really is a phenomenon. And it's 1 borne out of our bizarre to support storytellers and our appetite for taking creative risks. 
Beyond Empire, FOX has a number of new series that have provided significant gains year-over-year for us. Rosewood, Scream Queens, Grandfathered and The Grinder, have driven percentage increases anywhere from 21% to 78% compared to the same time slot last year.
It's fair to say that Minority Report has been a disappointment, and we've shortened the series order, and expect to have new reprogramming in the second half. While last year is not the benchmark we would aspire to measure against, nonetheless, total viewership growth, live, multi-platform and time-shifted to date, is up 10% year-on-year. 
As with every fall  broadcast season, a lot of attention has paid to the overnight ratings reports that measure the linear viewership of the new series Premieres. And we're focusing on saying, as Lachlan said, more in total viewership and driving overall consumption on multi-platform multi-day basis. 
The FOX Network is unique and that it attracts the youngest audience of any major broadcast network, perhaps, more than any other network, we're seeing significant audience growth from multi-platform viewing and from extended C3 and C7. For example, in addition to the Empire 30-day numbers as Lachlan talked about, Scream Queens more than doubled its live audience, over 130%, when including viewership across all platforms.  We're seeing similar numbers for other shows. And in fact, more than 50% of our ad inventory is now sold in the C7 window. It's true that much of this viewership is monetized today at a lower level than what we would like. And as I've said before, the important thing is to grow the audience, and our capabilities with respect to selling that audience are improving.
We're on track to grow our nonlinear ad revenue by around 40% this fiscal, this includes inventory across Hulu, VOD, FX Now, FOX NOW, Fox Sports To Go and Fox Sports Digital. We think it's important to create and distribute together, and I'm pleased that approximately 70% of our new prime time shows are from our own studio, 20th Century Fox Television, up from about 50% last year.  The full-time value -- the full lifetime value of these assets is something we're very focused on.
TCFTV and its subsidiaries continue to benefit from the overall strong demand prescriptive programming producing 36 series for 12 networks this season. While a little more than half of these series -- 64%, are supporting FOX channels, we continue to be a major provider of shows to others, with hip series such as Homeland, Modern Family and Fresh Off The Boat. Quality storytelling has never been more in demand.
Moving to the film studio. The first quarter film earnings were well below a year ago, reflecting release timing in the lack of a major success full release. However, the recent success of The Martian, and a very solid slate of upcoming features, gives us comfort here. Looking ahead, we're bringing Charlie Brown to the big screen this weekend with The Peanuts Movie, and with that, have the next installment of the very successful Alvin and the Chipmunks franchise in December, and the holiday release of Joy, which reunites Jennifer Lawrence with David O Russell once again.
Also in December, The Revenant with Leonardo DiCaprio in a wonderful film by Alejandro Ngiri-2 [ph], the very promising Deadpool this February, and we then wrap up the fiscal year with 2 big global franchises with X-Men: Apocalypse and the long-awaited sequel Independence Day Resurgence.
And looking a little further ahead, we'll also be releasing franchise extensions for Ice Age in the summer of 2016, the Planet of the Apes, Aliens, Maze Runner, King's Men and of course, Avatar, over the next few years. 
It's worth noting that the film industry is gaining strength, and the calendar year-to-date consumer spending on digital home entertainment up mid-teens for the industry, and a bit higher for us. We're making progress as well and our nonconsolidated businesses. The combination of the 3 Sky businesses is producing strong results, and together, these businesses are thriving, added around 1 million paid-for subscription products this quarter, and achieving the best overall U.K. sub-growth we've seen in 4 years, in addition to strong customer growth in Germany and steady performance in Italy.  Sky is truly setting the pace in digital Television across Europe.
And Hulu continues to grow, both subscribers and engagement aggressively. Year-to-date until September, total viewing at Hulu is up 85% [ph] versus prior year, and the subscriber additions are up more than 60%. And the Endemol Shine Group, our joint venture with Apollo, continues to deliver high-quality programming globally with non-scripted content such as Hunted, being picked up by CBS in the U.S. and new scripted programming, such as the Frankenstein Chronicles, preselling extremely well. Established titles, such as Big Brother, are traveling further than ever before, but the pilot series due to air in China for the first time this fall.
So while there's still much to do, we feel good about progress in the company overall, and about where we're headed. So with that, we'll hand it over to all of you for any questions you might have. Reed?

So there's nothing that's changed in the 3-month that would cause us to change that outlook

So the most dramatic decline internationally would've been STAR Sports, right in line with what we're expecting.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson from UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson from UBS.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean Lachlan mentioned, transformative change. I think investors are trying to understand the pace of that change and how aggressively you might investigate that imperative. And I'd note that John mentioned changing approach to SVOD licensing as potenti
componenttext: I mean Lachlan mentioned, transformative change. I think investors are trying to understand the pace of that change and how aggressively you might investigate that imperative. And I'd note that John mentioned changing approach to SVOD licensing as potentially, as one of the items that could impact growth in the future. At the same time last quarter, you talked about some of the growth drivers for fiscal '17, can you help investors understand over the last few months -- anything new in terms of your philosophy about how you're balance sheet, driving growth after 3 investment cycle versus the need to invest in digital going forward?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Doug. Look, I think as Lachlan mentioned, it is a kind of changes we've all -- as we all know in the business. But I think when we look at the present state of the business, with respect to the growth that we're seeing in really, IP Stre
componenttext: Thanks very much, Doug. Look, I think as Lachlan mentioned, it is a kind of changes we've all -- as we all know in the business. But I think when we look at the present state of the business, with respect to the growth that we're seeing in really, IP Stream video consumption, these are something that we're very excited about. And we have been pretty aggressive about trying to create growth there, investing in our capability with respect to monetizing that viewership, and doing it in a better way, developing new products for customers, as well as with partners, for example, at our Hulu partnership -- growing that business very aggressively and seeing very good result at this point. So I think when we think about investing in these areas, so you already -- you've already seen a lot of that in these sort of numbers and within our kind of inorganic internal investments as we think about how we make programming, what rights we seek to control, and then how we want to sell those things. With respect to specific decisions around windowing, SVOD partners, how we're exporting programming across the full lifetime of the programming, those are things that continually evolve. And I think it's really important for us to be able to be disruptive in those areas. I think it's important for us but to cling to business rules that inevitably change and have been changing over the last number of decades. in the business and an industry that's been characterized more than anything else, by really, wave after wave, of technological change that fundamentally, creates better products for customers, creates more competition downstream. And we think in that environment, we've always been best served to be able to innovate and disrupt ourselves. So I think with respect to how we think about investment -- and I don't want to get into -- I don't want to get into a backdoor way into '17 guidance. But I would say that we look at -- the sorts of things we've been doing around growing our capability, as well as licensing to new entrants in the marketplace on the right business terms and also, increasing the business that we do with many of our existing partners who distribute our content. These are the sorts of things we're focused on, and I think you'll see the more activity with respect to that, as those agreements are concluded and adjusted and as we signed new ways to distribute the products going forward over the next year.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Richard Greenfield from BTIG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Richard Greenfield from BTIG.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is really more of a follow-up on just another broad picture thinking of the SVoD topic. Why not, as you think about it, why not actually start building your own direct-to-consumer service? I know you've talked about it for a long time. But wondering
componenttext: This is really more of a follow-up on just another broad picture thinking of the SVoD topic. Why not, as you think about it, why not actually start building your own direct-to-consumer service? I know you've talked about it for a long time. But wondering -- you continue to license content to Hulu, among other platforms. I guess the big picture, why Hulu, especially now that Hulu has an ad-free option? Why is Hulu better than licensing to Netflix or to Amazon? And why did you allow Hulu to do an ad-free option, I guess? I'm curious why that was something the partnership wanted.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich, for the question. I guess -- i just had to step back a little bit. I mean, first of all, I think -- as I said earlier, we believe very strongly in Hulu and in Hulu's prospects. And as I said just a second ago, in response to Doug's question,
componenttext: Thanks, Rich, for the question. I guess -- i just had to step back a little bit. I mean, first of all, I think -- as I said earlier, we believe very strongly in Hulu and in Hulu's prospects. And as I said just a second ago, in response to Doug's question, it's really crucial that we don't become overly beholden to our own incumbency. And I think that's a real -- for; any business, that's trying to move fast and trying to growth. That's a real danger that one has to be very alive to. And we have to be willing to take some risks but also, to be innovative and to be disruptive. And I think as leaders of the business, and I think I speak for all of the leaders within the business, which is although the way through the business, because everybody has a responsibility to lead -- we have to be disruptors if we're going to grow. So when we look at growing the IP Streaming -- sort of our growing kind of business in IP streaming in the future, we're pretty excited about the innovation that we can bring to that marketplace. And we're working hard across the board, both internally, when we think about developing our authenticated apps, potentially, the direct-to-consumer offerings. Some of our competitors have been out there with those -- we haven't done that yet here. But for example, in India with hotstar, we've been very aggressive in building out a mobile video platform that we control and that we reach the customers with directly. And we're working hard within Hulu as well to both grow the business absolutely, but also to grow the offerings of the business. And we're really excited about our progress there. With respect to your question about ads, we're also really pleased with the progress we're making with respect to sort of ad innovation, to vote with premium ad-free services which Hulu announced and launched, but also with expanding the opt-in engagement advertising that we've talked about in the past to the Hulu platform which we just announced yesterday. And that's in addition to our own authenticated apps services. So fundamentally, in advertising, that these innovations are about empowering the audience to decide the value of their attention, and that makes sense to them. And it also makes a lot of sense to us. And we think pricing models around retention are going to be developing, and we want to be at the forefront of developing those, of an understanding how those work, and how we can create the best return. And the scale of the Hulu inventory there and the scale of the Hulu audience, is a great place to be innovating in that regard. And they've been really embracing that.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And you have mentioned -- I think you mentioned that Hulu subs are up 60% year-over-year, which is are in terms of net adds, are up 60% which is an impressive number. How much is the -- I know it's very recent times, but how significant is the ad-free pro
componenttext: And you have mentioned -- I think you mentioned that Hulu subs are up 60% year-over-year, which is are in terms of net adds, are up 60% which is an impressive number. How much is the -- I know it's very recent times, but how significant is the ad-free product driving incremental subscribers?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, they have -- Hulu hasn't disclosed those numbers at this point. I think I'll leave it to them and obviously, in the spring, with the upfront, is just going to be a lot of attention to that. But the growth is good, and we're -- I think, I would say w
componenttext: Look, they have -- Hulu hasn't disclosed those numbers at this point. I think I'll leave it to them and obviously, in the spring, with the upfront, is just going to be a lot of attention to that. But the growth is good, and we're -- I think, I would say we're at this point, pretty comfortable with the mix of growth, in terms of ad-free versus ad supported. And look, I think our commitment to Hulu is self-evident. We've invested a lot of it. We continue to license to it, where it makes the most sense, for our creative partners and us to do so. But also, we want to grow our app distribution as well. And I think we're seeking the license rights to distributors of all kinds, if it's on the right terms. And I think the other thing that's changing, and maybe this is to the heart of your question is, that the SVOD Licensing business itself is changing pretty quickly. And it's also the surprising new approaches and new ways, I think that we can provide a great service to customers that you'll see over the next little while. So in that environment, of all of that going on, I think our opportunities do lie in kind of leaning in and being disruptive ourselves, and not being afraid of that. And look, I think it's consistent with the way we've managed -- the way the business has grown over many, many years, from disrupting the U.S. Broadcast business with Fox Broadcasting so many years ago, to disrupting the European Television business with the 3 different Skys, and disrupting advertising and the Broadcast business today, with Hulu and other things over the current period in the next few years -- I think is a real opportunity to create enormous value. So look, I think that's one of the most important sort of cultural traits in our business, and it's one that we're going to continue to encourage and nurture, so I think it has to exist everywhere in this company.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Morris from Guggenheim Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Morris from Guggenheim Partners.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: One follow-up on Hulu and really, just understanding your comfort with the price of the product relative to utility given that it's really become a great consumer product and a robust product. At $12, it feels like it could potentially be cannibalistic to
componenttext: One follow-up on Hulu and really, just understanding your comfort with the price of the product relative to utility given that it's really become a great consumer product and a robust product. At $12, it feels like it could potentially be cannibalistic to your existing business model. So how do you get comfort, number 1, that you're not in fact, leading yourselves on a path of cannibalism? And two, maybe what levers you -- what you're looking for -- what levers you could pull to both deliver the quality experience, but also protect your economics? And then just 1 quick housekeeping. Is there anything on the domestic affiliate revenue side that's seasonal in terms of puts and takes, or is that number continue to be pretty steady with respect to absolute dollar and growth?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Michael. Look, just to clarify Hulu, I think one of the things that's important to note is that the current -- the way the business looks today with all of the different services in Subscription Video On Demand, as well as the MBpd marke
componenttext: Thanks very much, Michael. Look, just to clarify Hulu, I think one of the things that's important to note is that the current -- the way the business looks today with all of the different services in Subscription Video On Demand, as well as the MBpd marketplace, all of these services are going to change. And I think you've seen competitors take the pricing, you've seen new tiers and new products emerge. And I think it's important to note that it's not necessarily steady-state, in fact, it's one of pretty rapid evolution and innovation. So I think with respect to the ad free pricing at Hulu and the delta between the ad supported and the ad free, as you imagine, that was a source of robust debate. But at the end of the day, the business just had to move forward and try. And we're learning a lot from that. And I think pricing may change but also, as I mentioned before, we're very focused on thinking about how can these services also expand their offerings and create new price points with new contents or other things in them? So I think that's going to evolve and I wouldn't necessarily say it's a steady-state today. With respect to cannibalization, cannibalism -- I'll refrain from commenting on -- I think it's inevitable that new services and new competition both grow the overall market but also impact customers to other services. And we're very focused on how do we think about monetization in that environment, and how do we make sure that overall -- I mean, look at the whole business, our approach to growing the streaming business very aggressively, is one that's going to be more attractive for us? And personally, I think overtime, it's not necessarily a straight line, I think over time from the streaming entertainment business and streaming television businesses is much more attractive with opportunities for innovation, in terms of ad vote, ad pricing, subscription pricing, premium ad free models, as well as the discoverability of our programming across -- for customers. It's just a very attractive -- it's a very attractive set of attributes for customers, and I think, for our business as well. And -- but it's pretty early days in terms of finding all of the different ways that we can move it forward and we can innovate there. And your second question...

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a housekeeping point. Michael, the question on the affiliate fees. So we said at the beginning of the year, like on Michael's question, that we would have low double-digit affiliate fee growth for the year, and will be led by the U.S., this is right
componenttext: It's a housekeeping point. Michael, the question on the affiliate fees. So we said at the beginning of the year, like on Michael's question, that we would have low double-digit affiliate fee growth for the year, and will be led by the U.S., this is right in line with that. So there's nothing unusually seasonal about the growth we experienced in the quarter against what we expect to happen for the year.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of David Bank from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of David Bank from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to actually, follow up on the answer to your last question regarding innovation, in particular, James. You guys have always been ahead of the curve on giving us some really useful color around viewership, around nontraditional platforms -- you did
componenttext: I want to actually, follow up on the answer to your last question regarding innovation, in particular, James. You guys have always been ahead of the curve on giving us some really useful color around viewership, around nontraditional platforms -- you did more so today. I'm trying to figure out how we can use them to model the business? So if I go back to something, I think you guys said total viewership on FOX broadcasting network was up like 10%. Can you remind us how much of that was sort of -- was in the traditional C3, C7 window, whatever the Nielsen kind of -- the Nielsen window you sold it in? And then can you give us what the viewership was outside that window and remind us of what the monetization of that viewership is, or at least, give us a sense of what the potential upside of the monetization is, given that you know what the audience is, and you must have a sense of where you can monetize it over time? And lastly, Lachlan talked about the growth in nonlinear viewership. What are you doing with the data? You must be coming up with some pretty interesting data from the growth in this nonlinear viewership, that I would imagine, is extremely valuable in both monetization and devising a strategy for building your business going forward. How do you think about the data?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, David. So with respect to the break-in -- so for the first of all, it is more complicated, right? So when you said "Can we help you with your modeling, how will that work?" I'm speaking to myself. Yes, maybe you could help us modeling. I
componenttext: Thanks very much, David. So with respect to the break-in -- so for the first of all, it is more complicated, right? So when you said "Can we help you with your modeling, how will that work?" I'm speaking to myself. Yes, maybe you could help us modeling. It's -- what's complicated about it is -- and I really -- I think it illustrates the point around measurement systems evolving that Lachlan made earlier, which is -- what we're really focused on is what was our total audience last night and the day before and last week? And that was made up of customers and viewers watching live things, things a day old, things 4 days old, things 30 days old, and in some cases, things many months old. And what you want to review is get a picture of that overall viewership. And it's not easy to come by, and it lags because the measurement systems and all of those things don't always think -- when we don't get those numbers in the most timely way that we would like. So the total picture of the audience is more complex. That said -- just to break it down a little bit for you -- in the season to date, the live viewing, as I've mentioned before, was just under half, right? So 50% was more than that. And so it's about -- I think live viewing was about 40 -- high-40s percentage there. And then Hulu made up, sort of in the teens, and the balance was VOD -- a very small amount broad authenticated apps, which we're working on authentication pathways and stuff to improve there, and some time shifting on DVR. So the balance is definitely moving towards, obviously, time-shifted and on-demand. And from a sales point of view, about half of our inventory was sold on a C7 basis in the period. So that's sort of where that breaks down, but it's something that's really evolving. And I think when we think about how we instrument the business going forward and how we measure the business, and then deal with advertisers and all of our clients -- customers on that, those are things that are going to continue to evolve. But we're very focused on the total audience in a given time period, and then we build that up. So when we said to you that total audience was up 10% in the season today, but the same original programming, that really was the accumulated viewership, literally, on a per minute basis, relative to the previous year. And a lot of that was driven by the growth in seven-day and 30-day viewership there. And look, we think that it's really, really encouraging that the audience is moving towards these On Demand platform and in particular, where they're moving towards Hulu, where we can really innovate and monetize that audience. And with respect to your second question just on data, you're right, it is -- it  is very interesting. And when we're -- and it's -- it's interesting. It's very, very early days because the consumption curve is pretty dramatic. And that's something that we are -- we're really using today to understand both how we use our air better in terms of promo inventory, sales inventory, et cetera, how we're going to say our customers move between different shows and different platforms. But there are also gaps in that data -- obviously, working with third-party partners, but that is a big focus for us. And we think it's one of the -- the data opportunity is one of the great characteristics of an IT streaming TV business in the future, is the ability to have that data -- the ability to use that to improve your products and services and monetize the viewership and the audience in the right way. With respect to pricing, the attention of the audience, correct me, item for demo for advertisers.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
