componenttext: Yes. I don't want to be so precise to go down to channel levels, but what I called out and I think James called out and we called out in the earnings releases is we did have a significant decline focused on STAR Sports because of the absence of the cost of the cricket series. So the most dramatic decline internationally would've been in STAR Sports, right in line with what we were expecting.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson from UBS.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, Lachlan mentioned transformative change. I think investors are trying to understand the pace of that change and how aggressively you might investigate that imperative. And I'd note that John mentioned changing approach to SVOD licensing as potenti
componenttext: I mean, Lachlan mentioned transformative change. I think investors are trying to understand the pace of that change and how aggressively you might investigate that imperative. And I'd note that John mentioned changing approach to SVOD licensing as potentially one of the items that could impact growth in the future. At the same time last quarter, you talked about some of the growth drivers for fiscal '17. Can you help investors understand, over the last few months, anything new in terms of your philosophy about how you're balancing, driving growth after a 3-year investment cycle versus the need to invest in digital going forward?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Doug. Look, I think as Lachlan mentioned, it is a time of change as we've all -- as we all know in the business. But I think when we look at the present state of the business, with respect to the growth that we're seeing in really IP str
componenttext: Thanks very much, Doug. Look, I think as Lachlan mentioned, it is a time of change as we've all -- as we all know in the business. But I think when we look at the present state of the business, with respect to the growth that we're seeing in really IP streaming video consumption, this is something that we're very excited about. And we have been pretty aggressive about trying to create growth there, investing in our capability with respect to monetizing that viewership and doing it in a better way, developing new products for customers, as well as with partners, for example, at our Hulu partnership, growing that business very aggressively and seeing very good results at this point. So I think when we think about investing in these areas, that you already -- you've already seen a lot of that in the sort of numbers and within our kind of -- within our organic internal investments as we think about how we make programming, what rights we seek to control and then how we want to sell those things. With respect to specific decisions around windowing, SVOD partners, how we're exploiting programming across the full lifetime of the programming, those are things that continually evolve. And I think it's really important for us to be able to be disruptive in those areas. I think it's important for us not to cling to business rules that inevitably change and have been changing over the last number of decades, being in a business and an industry that's been characterized, more than anything else, by really wave after wave of technological change that fundamentally creates better products for customers, creates more competition downstream. And we think in that environment, we've always been best served to be able to innovate and disrupt ourselves. So I think with respect to how we think about investment, I don't want to get into -- I don't want to get into sort of a backdoor way into '17 guidance. But I would say that we look at the sorts of things we've been doing around growing our capability as well as licensing to new entrants in the marketplace on the right business terms and also increasing the business that we do with many of our existing partners who distribute our content. These are the sorts of things we're focused on, and I think you'll see more activity with respect to that as those agreements are concluded and adjusted and as we find new ways to distribute the product going forward over the next year.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rich Greenfield from BTIG.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rich Greenfield from BTIG.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is really more of a follow-up on just kind of broad picture thinking of the SVOD topic. Why not, as you think about it, why not actually start building your own direct-to-consumer service? I know you've talked about it for a long time, but wondering
componenttext: This is really more of a follow-up on just kind of broad picture thinking of the SVOD topic. Why not, as you think about it, why not actually start building your own direct-to-consumer service? I know you've talked about it for a long time, but wondering -- you continue to license content to Hulu, among other platforms. I guess, big picture, why Hulu, especially now that Hulu has an ad-free option? Why is Hulu better than licensing to Netflix or to Amazon? And why did you allow Hulu to do an ad-free option? I guess I'm curious why that was something the partnership wanted.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich, for the question. I guess -- I just had to step back a little bit. I mean, first of all, I think, as I said earlier, we believe very strongly in Hulu and in Hulu's prospects. And as I said just a second ago, in response to Doug's question, i
componenttext: Thanks, Rich, for the question. I guess -- I just had to step back a little bit. I mean, first of all, I think, as I said earlier, we believe very strongly in Hulu and in Hulu's prospects. And as I said just a second ago, in response to Doug's question, it's really crucial that we don't become overly beholden to our own incumbency. And I think that's a real -- for any business that's trying to move fast and trying to grow, that's a real danger that one has to be very alive to. And we have to be willing to take some risks but also to be innovative and to be disruptive. And I think as leaders of the business, and I think I speak for all of the leaders within the business, which is all the way through the business because everybody has a responsibility to lead, we have to be disruptors if we're going to grow. So when we look at growing the IP streaming -- sort of our growing kind of business in IP streaming in the future, we're pretty excited about the innovation that we can bring to that marketplace. And we're working hard across the board, both internally, when we think about developing our authenticated apps, potentially, the direct-to-consumer offerings. Some of our competitors have been out there with those, we haven't done that yet here. But for example, in India with hotstar, we've been very aggressive in building out a mobile video platform that we control and that we reach the customers with directly. And we're working hard within Hulu as well to both grow the business absolutely, but also to grow the offerings of the business. And we're really excited about our progress there. With respect to your question about ads, we're also really pleased with the progress we're making with respect to sort of ad innovation, to vote with premium ad-free services, which Hulu announced and launched, but also with expanding the opt-in engagement advertising that we've talked about in the past, to the Hulu platform, which we just announced yesterday. And that's in addition to our own authenticated apps services. So fundamentally, in advertising, these innovations are about empowering the audience to decide the value of their attention, and that makes sense to them. And it also makes a lot of sense to us. And we think pricing models around retention are going to be developing, and we want to be at the forefront of developing those and understanding how those work and how we can create the best return. And the scale of the Hulu inventory there and the scale of the Hulu audience is a great place to be innovating in that regard, and they've been really embracing that.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And you have mentioned -- I think you mentioned that Hulu subs are up 60% year-over-year, which, in terms of net adds, are up 60%, which is an impressive number. How much is the -- I know it's very recent times, but how significant is the ad-free product
componenttext: And you have mentioned -- I think you mentioned that Hulu subs are up 60% year-over-year, which, in terms of net adds, are up 60%, which is an impressive number. How much is the -- I know it's very recent times, but how significant is the ad-free product driving incremental subscribers?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, they have -- Hulu hasn't disclosed those numbers at this point. I think I'll leave it to them. And obviously, in the spring, with the upfront, there's going to be a lot of attention to that. But the growth is good, and we're -- I think I would say w
componenttext: Look, they have -- Hulu hasn't disclosed those numbers at this point. I think I'll leave it to them. And obviously, in the spring, with the upfront, there's going to be a lot of attention to that. But the growth is good, and we're -- I think I would say we're, at this point, pretty comfortable with the mix of growth in terms of ad-free versus ad supported. And look, I think our commitment to Hulu is self-evident. We've invested a lot in it. We continue to license to it, where it makes the most sense for our creative partners and us to do so. But also, we want to grow our app distribution as well. And I think we're seeking to license rights to distributors of all kinds, if it's on the right terms. And I think the other thing that's changing, and maybe this is to the heart of your question, is that the SVOD licensing business itself is changing pretty quickly. And there's also the surprising new approaches and new ways I think that we can provide a great service to customers that you'll see over the next little while. So I would say in that environment, of all of that going on, I think our opportunities do lie in kind of leaning in and being disruptive ourselves and not being afraid of that. And look, I think it's consistent with the way we've managed and the way the business has grown over many, many years, from disrupting the U.S. Broadcast business with Fox Broadcasting so many years ago, to disrupting the European Television business with the 3 different Skys and disrupting advertising and the Broadcast business today with Hulu and other things over the current period in the next few years, I think, is a real opportunity to create enormous value. So look, I think that's one of the most important sort of cultural traits in our business, and it's one that we're going to continue to encourage and nurture. So I think it has to exist everywhere in this company.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Morris from Guggenheim Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Morris from Guggenheim Partners.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: One follow-up on Hulu and really just understanding your comfort with the price of the product relative to the utility, given that it's really become a great consumer product and a robust product. At $12, it feels like it could potentially be cannibalisti
componenttext: One follow-up on Hulu and really just understanding your comfort with the price of the product relative to the utility, given that it's really become a great consumer product and a robust product. At $12, it feels like it could potentially be cannibalistic to your existing business model. So how do you get comfort, number one, that you're not in fact leading yourselves on a path of cannibalism? And two, maybe what levers you -- what you're looking for -- what levers you could pull to both deliver that quality experience, but also protect your economics? And then just one quick housekeeping. Is there anything on the domestic affiliate revenue side that's seasonal in terms of puts and takes? Or does that number continue to be pretty steady with respect to absolute dollar and growth?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Michael. Look, just to clarify, I think one of the things that's important to note is that the current -- the way the business looks today with all of the different services in subscription video on demand as well as the MBPD marketplace
componenttext: Thanks very much, Michael. Look, just to clarify, I think one of the things that's important to note is that the current -- the way the business looks today with all of the different services in subscription video on demand as well as the MBPD marketplace, all of these services are going to change. And I think you've seen competitors take pricing. You've seen new tiers and new products emerge. And I think it's important to note that it's not necessarily a steady state. In fact, it's one of pretty rapid evolution and innovation. So I think with respect to the ad-free pricing at Hulu and the delta between ad supported and the ad-free, as you would imagine, that was a source of robust debate. But at the end of the day, the business just had to move forward and try. And we're learning a lot from that. And I think pricing may change but also, as I mentioned before, we're very focused on thinking about how can these services also expand their offerings and create new price points with new contents or other things in them? So I think that's going to evolve and I wouldn't necessarily say it's a steady-state today. With respect to cannibalization, cannibalism -- I'll refrain from commenting on -- I think it's inevitable that new services and new competition both grow the overall market but also impact customers to other services. And we're very focused on how do we think about monetization in that environment and how do we make sure that overall -- I mean, look at the whole business, our approach to growing the streaming business very aggressively is one that's going to be more attractive for us? And personally, I think over time, it's not necessarily a straight line. I think over time, the streaming entertainment business and streaming television business is much more attractive with opportunities for innovation in terms of ad loads, ad pricing, subscription pricing, premium ad-free models as well as the discoverability of our programming across -- for customers. It's just a very attractive -- it's had a very attractive set of attributes for customers and, I think, for our business as well. And -- but it's pretty early days in terms of finding all of the different ways that we can move it forward and we can innovate there. And your second question...

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a housekeeping point. Michael, the question on the affiliate fees, so we said at the beginning of the year, like on Michael's question, that we would have low double-digit affiliate fee growth for the year and will be led by the U.S., this is right i
componenttext: It's a housekeeping point. Michael, the question on the affiliate fees, so we said at the beginning of the year, like on Michael's question, that we would have low double-digit affiliate fee growth for the year and will be led by the U.S., this is right in line with that. So there's nothing unusually seasonal about the growth we experienced in the quarter against what we expect to happen for the year.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of David Bank from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of David Bank from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to actually follow up on the answer to your last question regarding innovation, in particular, James. You guys have always been ahead of the curve on giving us some really useful color around viewership, around nontraditional platforms. You did mor
componenttext: I want to actually follow up on the answer to your last question regarding innovation, in particular, James. You guys have always been ahead of the curve on giving us some really useful color around viewership, around nontraditional platforms. You did more so today. I'm trying to figure out how we can use them to model the business. So if I go back to something, I think you guys said total viewership on FOX Broadcasting Network was up like 10%. Can you remind us how much of that was sort of -- was in the traditional C3, C7 window, whatever the Nielsen kind of -- the Nielsen window you sold it in? And then can you give us what the viewership was outside that window and remind us of what the monetization of that viewership is, or at least, give us a sense of what the potential upside of the monetization is, given that you know what the audience is and you must have a sense of where you can monetize it over time? And lastly, Lachlan talked about the growth in nonlinear viewership. What are you doing with the data? You must be coming up with some pretty interesting data from the growth in this nonlinear viewership that I would imagine is extremely valuable in both monetization and devising a strategy for building your business going forward. How do you think about the data?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, David. So with respect to the breakdown -- so first of all, it is more complicated, right? So when you said "Can we help you with modeling? How all that works." So I was thinking to myself, yes, maybe you could help us modeling how it wo
componenttext: Thanks very much, David. So with respect to the breakdown -- so first of all, it is more complicated, right? So when you said "Can we help you with modeling? How all that works." So I was thinking to myself, yes, maybe you could help us modeling how it works. It's -- what's complicated about it is we're -- and I really -- I think it illustrates the point around measurement systems evolving, that Lachlan made earlier, which is that what we're really focused on is what was our total audience last night and the day before and last week? And that was made up of customers and viewers watching live things. Things a day old, things 4 days old, things 30 days old, and in some cases, things many months old. And what you want to really do is get a picture of that overall viewership. But it's not easy to come by, and it lags because the measurement systems and all of those things don't always sync up and we don't get those numbers in the most timely way that we would like. So the total picture of the audience is more complex. That said, just to break it down a little bit for you, in the season to date, the live viewing, as I've mentioned before, was just under half, right? So 50% was more than that. And so it's about -- I think live viewing was about 40 -- high-40s percentage there. And then Hulu made up sort of in the teens, and the balance was VOD, a very small amount for our authenticated apps, which we're working on authentication pathways and stuff to improve there, and sometimes shifting on DVR. So the balance is definitely moving towards, obviously, time-shifted and on-demand. And from a sales point of view, about half of our inventory was sold on a C7 basis in the period. So that's sort of where that breaks down, but it is something that's really evolving. And I think when we think about how we instrument the business going forward and how we measure the business and then deal with advertisers and all of our clients and customers on that, those are things that are going to continue to evolve. But we're very focused on the total audience in a given time period and then we build that up. So when we said to you that total audience was up 10% in the season to date for entertainment programming, that really was the accumulated viewership literally on a per minute basis relative to the previous year. And a lot of that was driven by the growth in 7-day and 30-day viewership there. And look, we think that it's really, really encouraging that the audience is moving toward these on-demand platforms, and in particular, where they're moving towards Hulu, where we can really innovate and monetize that audience. And with respect to your second question, just on data, you're right, it is -- it's very interesting. And when we're -- and it's -- but it's interesting. It's very, very early days because the consumption curve is pretty dramatic. And that's something that we're really using today to understand both how we use our air better in terms of promo inventory, sales inventory, et cetera, how we understand how customers move between different shows and different platforms. But there are also gaps in that data, obviously, working with third-party partners, but that is a big focus for us. And we think it's one of the -- data opportunity is one of the great characteristics of an IT streaming TV business in the future, is the ability to have that data, the ability to use that to improve your products and services and monetize the viewership and the audience in the right way with respect to pricing the attention of the audience correctly, either for them or for advertisers.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ben Swinburne from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones, or hopefully, quick. John, last quarter, you gave some assumptions around the guidance, particularly on advertising the TV. I think you've said it will be flattish; cable or domestic cable, up mid- to high single digits. Is that still y
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones, or hopefully, quick. John, last quarter, you gave some assumptions around the guidance, particularly on advertising the TV. I think you've said it will be flattish; cable or domestic cable, up mid- to high single digits. Is that still your expectation after a quarter?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is early days, we're 3 months into it. A lot of the -- obviously, a lot of the network programming is still ahead of us. But at this point, we're still on that zone.
componenttext: Yes, it is early days, we're 3 months into it. A lot of the -- obviously, a lot of the network programming is still ahead of us. But at this point, we're still on that zone.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just, James, bringing the conversation more to the here and now. A couple of years ago, you guys decided to invest and turn this, I think, the Speed channel into Fox Sports 1. You made a lot of investments at FX and that family of networks
componenttext: Great. And then just, James, bringing the conversation more to the here and now. A couple of years ago, you guys decided to invest and turn this, I think, the Speed channel into Fox Sports 1. You made a lot of investments at FX and that family of networks. And that's really, I think in the eyes of the investor, driving growth over the next few years. I'm wondering if you can just talk about where we are in the sort of EBITDA trajectory, particularly for those -- not new assets per se, but assets that probably were profitable. You invested a lot into them and now we're hoping to see sort of the harvest of those investments over the next few years. Any color you can add would be helpful as we think about sort of the medium term.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Ben. I think the -- I'd add another sort of -- I'd add another stool for that -- leg to that stool, I guess, which is the investment that we've made in India in STAR, which is also one of the things that has been the investment we were makin
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Ben. I think the -- I'd add another sort of -- I'd add another stool for that -- leg to that stool, I guess, which is the investment that we've made in India in STAR, which is also one of the things that has been the investment we were making, but also, I think, when you look forward, generates a lot of growth. So with respect to FS1, Fox Sports 1, fully -- is fully in profit for the full year this year, and we think that's great achievement. We've invested a lot in programming, a lot in putting a great product on screen for people. And I think the launch and the first -- in the first 2 years of this project, as I said in my comments earlier, has really gone to plan or ahead of plan pretty much across the board, both in terms of audience as well as the P&L. So that's sort of where that is, and we see really good growth there going forward. Now obviously, one of the key things that drives that is affiliate fee increases. We have a lot of visibility on a lot of that. But there -- as the -- as new affiliate agreements come -- go forward, both in terms of distribution and price, we see an opportunity to grow there. But those will come in steps. FX, we think, is really the FX suite. More broadly, is really one of the kind of core creative franchises in the business today, and we think it's very, very promising. We see good growth there. But obviously, the investments in originals has been very high and that's something that has impacted profit other than that it would be. And at STAR, we really took 100% of the profit in the entertainment business and invested it in building a sports business there after the acquisition of ESPN Star Sports. We're seeing very, very good progress there. Last year or the year just gone was really the peak year of investments in that. So as we see continued growth in the entertainment business there and the growth rate of cost in the -- or rather, the cost spike in the sports business ameliorate pretty dramatically, with that, you kind of get a double whammy there. And the growth of the STAR business in terms of EBITDA will be substantial this year and for the next few years as that sports investment kind of backs out. So I think I would say we feel really good about all of those things. And most importantly, I think as we looked at these a number of years ago and said, listen, we're going to invest in these core brands. We're going to invest in getting -- we're going to invest actually in getting out of a lot of smaller brands, little things that weren't really moving the dial for customers, we think that's been really successful. And when I look at our discussions with our wholesale distributors, when I look at the way we're licensing, when I look at the volume and quality of the product that we have at our hands -- in our hands now, it's really -- it's paying dividends in the marketplace as we negotiate new distribution contracts, as we license things in a new way and as we grow the audience overall, as I detailed earlier.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Janedis from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Janedis from Jefferies.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's been a lot of discussion about the health of the ad market. And now that you've got a couple of years of FS1 on top of the rest of the portfolio, can you talk about the health of sports ad market relative to the entertainment piece? And to what ex
componenttext: There's been a lot of discussion about the health of the ad market. And now that you've got a couple of years of FS1 on top of the rest of the portfolio, can you talk about the health of sports ad market relative to the entertainment piece? And to what extent increased programming across TV broadly on the sports front may be affecting pricing power or the balance between supply and demand?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Look, I think the health of the sports advertising business is pretty good. We've seen -- I would say they're pretty much across the board in our sports portfolio. And I think it speaks to the increased scarcity of big live events, mass even
componenttext: Thanks, John. Look, I think the health of the sports advertising business is pretty good. We've seen -- I would say they're pretty much across the board in our sports portfolio. And I think it speaks to the increased scarcity of big live events, mass events that can deliver big audiences consistently. And at this point, I think it's early days in the season, obviously, in the NFL, but it feels reasonably good and strong going forward. As John mentioned before, we had 1 week less than the year before, but that reverses out or we get that week back later in the season. So I think it's -- I think it looks reasonably healthy. And the baseball ratings I mentioned earlier and revenue associated with that was pretty strong. So I'd feel -- I think we feel pretty good about it. And the big events on FS1 like the Women's World Cup, things like that, have been really tremendous. I mean, the other day, I think it was just last Sunday, we had a really tremendous day of sports on the network and on FS1. And all-in, it was a $100 million day. So that felt -- that's pretty good.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Then maybe a quick follow-up also, James. Regarding your comments around multi-platform viewing and audience, can you talk about when you expect some of the Nielsen changes to kick in from a measurement perspective? And is it the assumption that modelizat
componenttext: Then maybe a quick follow-up also, James. Regarding your comments around multi-platform viewing and audience, can you talk about when you expect some of the Nielsen changes to kick in from a measurement perspective? And is it the assumption that modelization quickly follows as the bulk of the upfront? It just seems like the modelization piece is perpetually a year away.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- I wouldn't say perpetually a year away, but I think it necessarily lags the audience growth. And you'd generally try to focus on audience growth and then create a center of gravity, create demand around that audience. And I think that's t
componenttext: Well, I think -- I wouldn't say perpetually a year away, but I think it necessarily lags the audience growth. And you'd generally try to focus on audience growth and then create a center of gravity, create demand around that audience. And I think that's through the way we've approached it. So I feel actually pretty good in the progress there. And I would say that the Nielsen changes -- C7 changes, et cetera, are relevant. But just as relevant is our ability, moving to the question before, is our ability to gather up the data around viewing and, frankly, articulate that in a clear way to clients and advertisers and also give them the tools that are easy for them to start to innovate and experiment themselves. We're really happy to be able to get engagement units launched on Hulu or, I announced it yesterday, and we have Mondelez as a -- a number of Mondelez brands really as the sort of launch partner to do that. And there's a good volume of inventory there. So actually, I think this is picking up pretty quickly. And it's a combination, not just of the Nielsen -- it's a combination of the Nielsen ratings changes and getting a currency there that's established, but also a lot of other viewership data coming from a variety of platforms. And we work with all of those, we work with the third-party services, from Rentrak, et cetera, but also our own internal data in terms of what we're streaming and how we're doing it and those numbers there. So it's a blend of all of those things. And so far, we're seeing a reasonably good appetite for that, although it is -- it's obviously coming from a smaller base.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alexia Quadrani from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alexia Quadrani from JPMorgan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question is on the RSNs. You highlighted this recent strength at your RSNs around the World Series. I guess, can you give us some perspective on how we should think of the RSNs from a financial view versus your other cable properties and how demand for
componenttext: My question is on the RSNs. You highlighted this recent strength at your RSNs around the World Series. I guess, can you give us some perspective on how we should think of the RSNs from a financial view versus your other cable properties and how demand for advertising rate volume versus -- and also demand -- how the outlook for maybe sub revenue looks, just maybe relative to your other better cable businesses?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: For the RSNs, look, we're very fond of our RSNs, as we've talked about before. I think they -- the performance of the RSNs that I outlined earlier is super encouraging. We're seeing ratings growth from a competitive perspective, real leadership in a lot o
componenttext: For the RSNs, look, we're very fond of our RSNs, as we've talked about before. I think they -- the performance of the RSNs that I outlined earlier is super encouraging. We're seeing ratings growth from a competitive perspective, real leadership in a lot of those local markets. And it really just speaks to the fact that the RSN business is a business built around the tribal nature of sports and the passion that people have for these teams and these brands. And what we tried to do is balance the portfolio so that we have strength in the right regions. We try to balance the long term of that business with respect to renewals, team agreements, et cetera, so that we can provide a lot of value for our team partners there and get the value in the marketplace for them. The majority of that business from a revenue perspective is affiliate revenues. So it's less driven by ratings. And really, the local ratings are more a measure of demand and really help us with respect to pricing on a wholesale basis, whereas most of them are not big advertising businesses because they are generally very, very local.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that question comes from the line of Todd Juenger from Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Okay, that question comes from the line of Todd Juenger from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll try and keep it brief, seeing the time. So just quickly, on the Television operating expense line, just wonder if you could help us from the outside understand anything that helps drive that actually down, I guess, year-over-year. I mean, there seems
componenttext: I'll try and keep it brief, seeing the time. So just quickly, on the Television operating expense line, just wonder if you could help us from the outside understand anything that helps drive that actually down, I guess, year-over-year. I mean, there seems to be plenty of exciting new shows on your networks -- in your broadcast network. And so anything on timing related or just efficiencies there, what's going on, would be helpful. And then secondly, real quickly, and this one -- James, I know you already talked a lot about STAR, so just to put one final punctuation, right, it's such a big incremental contributor of cash flow growth apparently over the next many years, when we think about that $1 billion number that was mentioned a couple of years ago. Anything you could say on the trajectory between now and then, what drives that? Is it just the steady rate of subscriber growth with less cost? Is there marketing investment? Is there some inflection required? Anything to think about the pacing of that, when we'll see it, will be helpful.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Todd, let me deal with the STAR answer first. Look, I think the inflection point was really this year when we hit the sort of peak sports investment because the business generally, on an underlying basis, the entertainment business is already well o
componenttext: Okay. Todd, let me deal with the STAR answer first. Look, I think the inflection point was really this year when we hit the sort of peak sports investment because the business generally, on an underlying basis, the entertainment business is already well on its way. And it's substantially profitable [ph], I think we've disclosed this, over $300 million this year, so I think in EBITDA. So it's really the eating -- the taking that investment and taking all that profit and reinvesting that into creating this new kind of -- this new business in sports, which we think really adds a totally new dimension and a real sense of scale -- a real scale to the business there. The inflection point is when that peaks, and that peaked this year. So we see -- yes, this last year that just ended. So when we look at the future of that business, while I'm not going to say it's a straight line. There's always some ups and downs here and there. But the profit growth will start to be significant this year and will continue towards that $1 billion target at the present conditions, if you kind of -- being consistent towards the end of this decade or thereabouts the turn of the decade. So I think that feels reasonably good. It's totally dependent on continued creative excellence across that business, so there is a lot of execution risk, as there is in all these businesses. But we've got -- we feel very, very good about the products we have, about the brands, about the company there. And we want to aim high with it. We think it can really change our lives.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Todd, on your question on the TV OpEx, the -- there's a few factors driving on a comparative basis. First, at the network, earlier in the quarter, we had lower costing programming, repeats versus some of the original programming we had a year ago, same
componenttext: So Todd, on your question on the TV OpEx, the -- there's a few factors driving on a comparative basis. First, at the network, earlier in the quarter, we had lower costing programming, repeats versus some of the original programming we had a year ago, same quarter. We've got lower programming at the station group, given that some programming is just rolling off there. And of course, given the revenue impact, we have lower costs for the NFL week, moving from this quarter to the following -- to the third quarter. Offsetting that, we did have higher marketing costs at the network, given that we launched clearly a schedule that had more new series than we've had in several years. So that balanced a bit of the cost reduction from the earlier ones.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Todd. At this point, we are out of time. And I want to thank everybody for joining today's call.
componenttext: Thank you, Todd. At this point, we are out of time. And I want to thank everybody for joining today's call.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, everyone.
componenttext: Thanks very much, everyone.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this conference will be available for replay after 11:00 a.m. Eastern Time today through November 14. You may access the AT&T Teleconference replay system at any time by dialing 1 (800) 475-6701 and entering the access code 371866. International participants dial (320) 365-3844. That does conclude your conference for today. Thank you for your participation and for using AT&T Executive Teleconference. You may now disconnect.
